questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of British Life?
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: Democracy; The rule of law; Individual liberty; Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs; Participation in community life.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Only members of the public who have their name on the electoral register can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster in the House of Lords
questions.explanation: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What are TWO of the activities that you might be involved in when canvassing?
questions.explanation: Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates - for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support. This is called 'canvassing'.

possible_answers.text: Handing out leaflets in the street
Knocking on people's doors and asking for their support
Getting paid for each vote obtained in commission
Getting paid for the time spent advertising

correct_answers: Handing out leaflets in the street
Knocking on people's doors and asking for their support

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which TWO things are you required to have to apply for ILR or British Citizenship?
questions.explanation: In order to apply for ILR or Naturalization as a British Citizen you must have a valid life in the UK pass certificate and good knowledge of English language

possible_answers.text: A relative in the UK with a British Passport
A Life in the UK pass certificate

correct_answers: A Life in the UK pass certificate

questions.question: Which process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways?
questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways. Manufacturing jobs became the main source of employment in Britain.

questions.question: The invasion of which country by Germany provoked UK to declare war on Germany in 1939?
questions.explanation: When Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are minor criminal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland heard?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Opposition is the second largest party in the House of Commons
questions.explanation: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the Opposition. The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

questions.question: Which prehistoric monument still stands in the English county of Wiltshire?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

questions.question: Robert Stephenson and George were famous pioneers of which industry?
questions.explanation: Just before Victoria came to the throne, the father and son George and Robert Stephenson pioneered the railway engine and a major expansion of the railways took place in the Victorian period. Railways were built throughout the Empire.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Conservative Party is a political party in the UK
questions.explanation: The main political parties include: Conservative Party, the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats, or one of the parties representing Scottish, Welsh or Northern Irish interests.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The name or photograph of cases heard in the Youth Court can be published in the newspapers once the young person has been found guilty
questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

questions.question: What are traditional pub games? (Select TWO)
questions.explanation: Most communities will have a 'local' pub that is a natural focal point for social activities. Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

questions.question: Where was Rudyard Kipling born?
questions.explanation: Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. He wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

questions.question: What was Isaac Newton famous for?
questions.explanation: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica (Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow. Many of his discoveries are still important for modern science.

questions.question: Where in Scotland is known as the home of golf?
questions.explanation: St Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

questions.question: Where does the UK government sit?
questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

questions.question: Who was the Prime Minister during 1945-1951?
questions.explanation: Clement Attlee was born in London in 1883. He was Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951 and led the Labour Party for 20 years.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Lord of the Rings'?
questions.explanation: The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best-loved novel in 2003.

questions.question: Which organization looks after the Edinburgh Castle?
questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Castle has a long history, dating back to the early Middle Ages. It is looked after by Historic Scotland, a Scottish government agency.

questions.question: What does an aged population have an impact on?
questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

questions.question: What party won the election in 1945 (After WWII)?
questions.explanation: In 1945 the British people elected a Labour government. The new Prime Minister was Clement Attlee, who promised to introduce the welfare state outlined in the Beveridge Report. In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When did Queen Elizabeth II celebrate her Diamond Jubilee?
questions.explanation: Big Ben tower is named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What do you have to pay tax on in the UK?
questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes: wages from paid employment; profits from self-employment, taxable benefits; pensions; income from property, savings and dividends.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these is NOT part of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: The US is not part of the Commonwealth.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: You can find copies of Hansard report in large libraries and on the Internet
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries and online.

questions.question: Queen Mary was a Protestant and persecuted Catholics (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary')
questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary'). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

questions.question: Where is Sutton Hoo?
questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth.

questions.question: Wales wasn't under Anglo-Saxon rule
questions.explanation: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have devolved administrations which give them full control over all policies and laws
questions.explanation: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.question: Who captained the English cricket team and holds a number of records, both for batting and bowling?
questions.explanation: Sir Ian Botham (1955-) captained the English cricket team and holds a number of English Test cricket records, both for batting and for bowling.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Prime Minister cannot be changed until the next General election
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister can be changed if the MPs in the governing party decide to do so, or if he or she wishes to resign.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO of the following are protected by law from discrimination?
questions.explanation: UK laws ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland
questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

questions.question: What is the name given to rented additional land which people use to grow fruit and vegetable?
questions.explanation: A lot of people have gardens at home and will spend their free time looking after them. Some people rent additional land called 'an allotment', where they grow fruit and vegetables. Gardening and flower shows range from major national exhibitions to small local events.

questions.question: Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. What was this known as?
questions.explanation: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of the statements is true?
questions.explanation: Solicitors' charges are usually based on how much time they spend on a case. It is very important to find out at the start how much a case is likely to cost.

possible_answers.text: Solicitors' charges are based on how serious the case is
Solicitors' charges are based on how much time they spend on a case

correct_answers: Solicitors' charges are based on how much time they spend on a case

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What area is the Home Secretary responsible for?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments. These include: Chancellor of the Exchequer: responsible for the economy; Home Secretary:responsible for crime, policing and immigration; Foreign Secretary: responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries; other ministers (called 'Secretaries of State') are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

questions.question: Which battle did William the Conqueror fight in?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.question: What is the Turner Prize given for?
questions.explanation: The Turner Prize is recognised as one of the most prestigious visual art awards in Europe. Previous winners include Damien Hirst and Richard Wright.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the main purpose of the Opposition?
questions.explanation: The opposition form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

possible_answers.text: To represent the people of the UK

questions.question: What is the 'Divine Right of Kings'?
questions.explanation: Divine Right of Kings' is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

possible_answers.text: Reduced the power of the nobles
Reduced the power of the King
The King was Appointed by God

correct_answers: The King was Appointed by God

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: It is a civil offence to carry a weapon
questions.explanation: It is a criminal offence to carry a weapon.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does a jury in England, Wales and Northern Ireland have?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

questions.question: Constituencies which had hardly any voters were called 'Pocket Boroughs'
questions.explanation: Some constituencies were controlled by a single wealthy family. These were called 'pocket boroughs'. Other constituencies had hardly any voters and were called 'rotten boroughs'.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Can the devolved administrations control sectors such as immigration, foreign affairs and taxation?
questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

possible_answers.text: Only if the local people support them

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections
questions.explanation: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Forced marriages are an offence in the UK
questions.explanation: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership. Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
questions.explanation: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. They have usually had an important career in politics, business, law or another profession. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

possible_answers.text: Life peers are appointed by the Prime Minister on the advice of the monarchy
Life peers are appointed by the monarchy on the advice of the Prime Minister

correct_answers: Life peers are appointed by the monarchy on the advice of the Prime Minister

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How can you visit the Welsh Assembly?
questions.explanation: The Senedd is an open building. You can book guided tours or seats in the public galleries for the Welsh Assembly. To make a booking, contact the Assembly Booking Service

possible_answers.text: By queuing at the public entrance all day

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which political party is still known as the Tories?
questions.explanation: The modern Conservative Party is still sometimes referred to as the Tories

questions.question: Which TWO of these were introduced before the First World War in 1914?
questions.explanation: Financial help for the unemployed, old-age pensions and free school meals were just a few of the important measures introduced.

questions.question: There is no upper age limit for doing jury service
questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

questions.question: Which of these is correct in the chronological order?
questions.explanation: Magna Carta(1215), The Black Death (1348), The Canterbury Tales(1400)

possible_answers.text: The Black Death, Canterbury Tales, Magna Carta
Canterbury Tales, the Black Death, Magna Carta
Magna Carta, the Black Death, Canterbury Tales,
The Black Death, Magna Carta, Canterbury Tales

correct_answers: Magna Carta, the Black Death, Canterbury Tales,

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these TWO countries are Commonwealth Members?
questions.explanation: Cameroon and Namibia are members of the Commonwealth

questions.question: What does Eid al-Fitr celebrate?
questions.explanation: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast. The date when it takes place changes every year. Muslims attend special services and meals.

possible_answers.text: That the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to
The founding of the Muslim community

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In which year did the UK join the European Union (EU)?
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the minimum age for serving on a jury?
questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

questions.question: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690. This event is celebrated in which country?
questions.explanation: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which one is not a valid UK coin?
questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

questions.question: Who was the Prime minister and inspiration leader during the World War Two?
questions.explanation: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship. He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.

questions.question: What is the Grand National?
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: You can contact MPs only at their office in the House of Commons
questions.explanation: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons.

questions.question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Who ordered to write the Book of Common Prayer?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.

questions.question: What was the main crop in Ireland in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, many people in Ireland depended on potatoes as a large part of their diet. In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

questions.question: What was the most important principle of the Enlightenment?
questions.explanation: One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them.

possible_answers.text: Freedom of religion and political views

correct_answers: Freedom of religion and political views

questions.question: Which of the events is the landing of allied forces in Normandy?
questions.explanation: On 6 June 1944, allied forces landed in Normandy (this event is often referred to as 'D-Day').

questions.question: What did R. A. Butler introduce?
questions.explanation: R.A. Butler oversaw the introduction of the Education Act 1944 (often called 'The Butler Act'), which introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

possible_answers.text: Free university education in the UK

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is considered ineligible to do jury service?
questions.explanation: Everyone who is summoned to do jury service must do it unless they are not eligible (for example, because they have a criminal conviction) or they provide a good reason to be excused, such as ill health.

questions.question: In which year was the first Union Flag created?
questions.explanation: The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

questions.question: What is the correct order of the Patron Saints' Days? (Starting from January)
questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their patron saint's day as an official holiday. Events are held across Scotland, Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, especially where there are a lot of people of Scottish, Northern Irish and Irish heritage.

possible_answers.text: St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St Andrew's Day, St George's Day
St George's Day, St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St Andrew's Day
St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St George's Day, St Andrew's Day
St Patrick's Day, St David's Day, St Andrew's Day, St George's Day

correct_answers: St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St George's Day, St Andrew's Day

questions.question: In the 20th century, what did Sir Edwin Lutyens design to be the seat of government in India?
questions.explanation: In the 20th century, Sir Edwin Lutyens had an influence throughout the British Empire. He designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India. After the First World War, he was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

questions.question: Select TWO early members of the Royal Society
questions.explanation: Charles II was interested in science. During his reign, the Royal Society was formed to promote 'natural knowledge'. This is the oldest surviving scientific society in the world. Among its early members were Sir Edmund Halley, who successfully predicted the return of the comet now called Halley's Comet, and Sir Isaac Newton.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who resides in 10 Downing Street?
questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

questions.question: What is Boxing Day?(Choose TWO)
questions.explanation: Boxing Day is the day after Christmas Day and is a public holiday.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

questions.question: Where were the MacDonalds of Glencoe originally from?
questions.explanation: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed. The memory of this massacre meant some Scots distrusted the new government.

questions.question: You should respect someone's right in court. In return, you are offered the right to a fair trial.
questions.explanation: You should always respect everyone rights in court. Vise versa everyone should respect your rights.

questions.question: Which of these countries did NOT fight on the side of the Allied Powers during the First World War?
questions.explanation: The Allies fought against the Central Powers - mainly Germany, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, the Ottoman Empire and later Bulgaria.

questions.question: In the Church of Scotland, who is the Moderator?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

possible_answers.text: The chairperson of the General Assembly, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of the Church
A key figure who is responsible for all relations with the Church of England
A financial overseer who has overall responsibility for the accounts of the Church
The spiritual leader of the Church, who is appointed for life

correct_answers: The chairperson of the General Assembly, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of the Church

questions.question: What is the name of the first major railway built in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Great Western Railway is the name of the first major railway built in Britain.

questions.question: The UK has a declining elderly population
questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

questions.question: The Man Booker Prize is awarded in which area?
questions.explanation: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually for the best fiction novel written by an author from the Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. It has been awarded since 1968. Past winners include Ian McEwan, Hilary Mantel and Julian Barnes.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which two things should you do if you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK?
questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law; respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions; treat others with fairness; look after yourself and your family; look after the area in which you live and the environment.

possible_answers.text: Look after the area in which you live and the environment
Look after yourself and your family

correct_answers: Look after the area in which you live and the environment
Look after yourself and your family

questions.question: Christmas Day, which celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, is on which day?
questions.explanation: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

questions.question: What term arose after the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What is the fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: The rule of law is one of the fundamental principles of British Life.

questions.question: Which word comes from the Viking language?
questions.explanation: Grimsby and Scunthorpe are the examples of words that come from the Viking languages.

questions.question: Who designed the Clifton Suspension Bridge?
questions.explanation: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway and the Clifton Suspension Bridge.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What happens if an MP dies or resigns?
questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

possible_answers.text: The closest MP will have to cover
A new General Election is held

questions.question: How many times has the UK hosted the Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London.

questions.question: What does the 'R' Plate stand for?
questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an 'R' plate (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

questions.question: When did the Vikings first attack Britain?
questions.explanation: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

questions.question: When was the Emancipation Act signed?
questions.explanation: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire. The Royal Navy stopped slave ships from other countries, freed the slaves and punished the slave traders.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does the UN Security Council have?
questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security. There are 15 members on the UN Security Council, which recommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace. The UK is one of five permanent members of the Security Council.

questions.question: Who had the title 'Lord Protector'?
questions.explanation: After his campaign in Ireland and victory over Charles II at Worcester, Cromwell was recognised as the leader of the new republic. He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.

questions.question: When did William of Orange invade England?
questions.explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king.

questions.question: The process 'Highland Clearances' happened due to rebellion of slaves
questions.explanation: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

questions.question: What prehistoric village (off the north coast of Scotland) has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age?
questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question: In what county can you see a hill fort at Maiden Castle?
questions.explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

questions.question: What is the 'Grand National'?
questions.explanation: The Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr are well known horse racing events.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: On which TWO occasions will there be a fresh election, called a by-election, in MP's constituency?
questions.explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years. If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency. MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How is the Speaker elected?
questions.explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief Officer of the House of Commons. The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP. The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

possible_answers.text: The Archbishop of Canterbury chooses the Speaker

questions.question: Why was the Habeas Corpus Act (1679) so important?
questions.explanation: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for 'you must present the person in court'. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

possible_answers.text: It gave women their property rights
It gave women the right to vote
It guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully
It limited the power of the monarch

correct_answers: It guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully

questions.question: At what age did Queen Victoria become Queen of the UK?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years. At the date of writing (2013) this is the longest reign of any British monarch. Her reign is known as the Victorian Age.

questions.question: During the Victorian period, transport link improved, enabling goods and people to move easily around the country
questions.explanation: The statement is true

questions.question: What was the more probable use for the Stonehenge?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

possible_answers.text: A special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

correct_answers: A special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

questions.question: John Constable (1776-1837) founded the modern Police force in England
questions.explanation: John Constable (1776-1837) was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the east of England.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When was the Parliament of Northern Ireland first established?
questions.explanation: A Northern Ireland Parliament was established in 1922, when Ireland was divided, but it was abolished in 1972, shortly after the Troubles broke out in 1969. The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998.

questions.question: How old do you have to be to buy a lottery ticket or a scratch card?
questions.explanation: People under 18 (Changed in 2021) are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery. This includes buying Scratch Cards.

questions.question: When is St David's day?
questions.explanation: St David's day is on the 1st of March. He is a Patron St of Wales.

questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
questions.explanation: The Chartists demanded the vote for the working classes and other people without property.

possible_answers.text: The right to vote for the 21 year olds
The right to vote for the working class
The right to vote for the women
The right to vote for the 18 year olds

correct_answers: The right to vote for the working class

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What do you need to apply for UK citizenship?
questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to: speak and read English; have a good understanding of life in the UK.

possible_answers.text: Be able to use computers in English

questions.question: Who won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Sir Steve Redgrave won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain's greatest Olympians.

questions.question: When did the WWI begin?
questions.explanation: The first World War began in 1914 and ended in 1918.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Where did the supporters of Charles Edward Stuart come from?
questions.explanation: Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army.

questions.question: What is the official name of the country?
questions.explanation: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

possible_answers.text: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

correct_answers: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the British Constitution often described as?
questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government.

questions.question: What was the population of the UK in 1998?
questions.explanation: Population growth in the UK (Year, Population): (1600, Just over 4 million), (1700, 5 million), (1801, 8 million), (1851, 20 million), (1901, 40 million), (1951, 50 million), (1998, 57 million), (2005, Just under 60 million), (2010, Just over 62 million).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO words appear in the first two lines of the national anthem 'God save the Queen/King'?
questions.explanation: The first verse is: 'God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King!'.

questions.question: What % of the UK population does Wales account for?
questions.explanation: As per 2021 census, the UK population at mid-year was estimated to be 67.0 million, an increase of 3.7 million (5.9%) on the population in mid-2011. Wales accounted for 3,064,000 people - just above 4.5% of the UK population.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Members in the Welsh Assembly can speak English and Welsh, and all publications of the Assembly are in both languages
questions.explanation: The statement is true

questions.question: How old was the Queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart when her father died and she became Queen?
questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called 'Mary, Queen of Scots') was a Catholic. She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen.

questions.question: When was the first public film shown in the UK?
questions.explanation: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular. From the beginning, film makers became famous for clever special effects and this continues to be an area of British expertise.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the name given to the PM's country house?
questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

questions.question: How long did the Hundred Years War last for?
questions.explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years). One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: All Acts of Parliament are made in who's name?
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the King makes a speech which summarises the government’s policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

questions.question: In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London?
questions.explanation: During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul's Cathedral.

questions.question: Which TWO are facts about King William II of Scotland?
questions.explanation: James II's elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.

possible_answers.text: He was married to the young daughter of King James II of England, Wales and Ireland
He was defeated by King James II of England when the latter tried to take back the crown
He was William of Orange before he became King William III of England. Wales and Ireland
He was the Protestant rule of the Netherlands before he became King William II of Scotland

correct_answers: He was William of Orange before he became King William III of England. Wales and Ireland
He was the Protestant rule of the Netherlands before he became King William II of Scotland

questions.question: Eid al-Fitr and Eid ul Adha are festivals celebrated by which religion?
questions.explanation: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast. The date when it takes place changes every year. Muslims attend special services and meals. Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to. It reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God. Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during this festival. In Britain this has to be done in a slaughterhouse.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: It is compulsory to join National Citizen Service programme for 16 and 17 year olds
questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are all minor criminal cases heard in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What's the objective of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

possible_answers.text: Achieve goals in democracy and development
Allow visa free migration across the member states

correct_answers: Achieve goals in democracy and development

questions.question: Which one of the following is the most famous play written by Shakespeare?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.

questions.question: What marked the beginning of 'constitutional monarchy'?
questions.explanation: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called 'constitutional monarchy'.

questions.question: Who sat in the House of Lords in the middle ages?
questions.explanation: The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these charities works with children?
questions.explanation: The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) works with children.

questions.question: Who won the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose. The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.

questions.question: Which country(s) did Britain fight against during the Battle of Trafalgar?
questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

questions.question: What is an important part of the UK character?
questions.explanation: The traditions of comedy and satire, and the ability to laugh at ourselves, are an important part of the UK character.

possible_answers.text: The ability to laugh at ourselves
To have fish and chips every lunch
Go to the pub every Friday

correct_answers: The ability to laugh at ourselves

questions.question: When is the Bonfire Night celebrated?
questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: Where did many of the Viking settle after they got defeated?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings. Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain - especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw (many places names there, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages).

questions.question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Civil servants are expected to be politically neutral, what core values should they have?
questions.explanation: Civil servants are expected to carry out their role with dedication and a commitment to the civil service and its core values. These are: integrity, honesty, objectivity and impartiality (including being politically neutral).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who chairs the debates in the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief Officer of the House of Commons. The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP. The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does the Welsh Assembly have?
questions.explanation: The Welsh Assembly has 60 members, with forty members chosen to represent individual Senedd constituencies, and twenty to represent the five electoral regions of the Senedd in Wales.

questions.question: On what day does 'Lent' begin?
questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day. Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

questions.question: Select TWO famous Athletes
questions.explanation: Sir Roger Bannister (1929-) was the first man in the world to run a mile in under four minutes, in 1954. Mo Farah (1983-) is a British distance runner, born in Somalia. He won gold medals in the 2012 Olympics for the 5,000 and 10,000 metres and is the first Briton to win the Olympic gold medal in the 10,000 metres.

questions.question: Sir Kingsley Amis was a famous English novelist and poet who wrote more than 20 novels, including 'Lucky Jim'
questions.explanation: Sir Kingsley Amis (1922-95) was an English novelist and poet. He wrote more than 20 novels. The most well-known is Lucky Jim.

questions.question: What is the Church of England also known as in Scotland and the US?
questions.explanation: In England, there is a constitutional link between Church and state. The official Church of the state is the Church of England (called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States). It is a Protestant Church and has existed since the Reformation in the 1530s

questions.question: The Patron Saints' days are NOT public holidays in which TWO countries?
questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their Patron Saint's day as an official holiday. While the Patron Saints' days are no longer public holidays in England and Wales, they are still celebrated. Parades and small festivals are held all over the two countries.

questions.question: What percentage of the workforce are women?
questions.explanation: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce. On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. More women than men study at university.

questions.question: What is a traditional pub game?
questions.explanation: Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

questions.question: When did a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes fail in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament?
questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: What tells us about how people lived just after the Norman Conquest?
questions.explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland, why was this postponed?
questions.explanation: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland. It was opposed by the Protestants in the north of Ireland, who threatened to resist Home Rule by force. The outbreak of the First World War led the British government to postpone any changes in Ireland. Irish Nationalists were not willing to wait and in 1916 there was an uprising (the Easter Rising) against the British in Dublin. A guerilla war against the British army and the police in Ireland followed. In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries.

possible_answers.text: The Scottish people also wanted to self-govern
The outbreak of World War I

correct_answers: The outbreak of World War I

questions.question: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.
questions.explanation: A constitution is a set of principles by which a country is governed. It includes all of the institutions that are responsible for running the country and how their power is kept in check. The constitution also includes laws and conventions. The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.

questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote; elections every year; for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

possible_answers.text: Anyone to be able to stand as an MP
Every man to have a vote

correct_answers: Every man to have a vote

questions.question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
questions.explanation: The United Kingdom consists of Wales,England,Scotland and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: Who became one of the most popular monarchs in the 16th century?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada.

questions.question: When did the BBC start the first radio broadcast?
questions.explanation: The BBC started radio broadcasts in 1922 and began the world's first regular television service in 1936.

questions.question: Where do the Laurence Olivier Awards take place?
questions.explanation: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director, best actor and best actress. The awards are named after the British actor Sir Laurence Olivier, later Lord Olivier, who was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays.

questions.question: Who were the first people to start living in Britain?
questions.explanation: The first people to live in Britain were hunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

questions.question: Where can you find Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni statue?
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: When did the 'Battle of the Boyne' happen?
questions.explanation: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army. William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

questions.question: When did Queen Victoria become queen?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years.

questions.question: Which British TV shows are popular in the UK now?
questions.explanation: Popular programmes include regular soap operas such as Coronation Street and EastEnders.

questions.question: What was build as part of the UK's celebration of the new millennium?
questions.explanation: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall. It was originally built as part of the UK's celebration of the new millennium and continues to be an important part of New Year celebrations.

questions.question: What became the symbol of the House of Tudor?
questions.explanation: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose. The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485 the House of Lancaster won. The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

questions.question: Which Patron Saint day is on the 17th of March?
questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

questions.question: After the Emancipation Act, how many Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the slaves?
questions.explanation: The Emancipation Act of 1833 abolished slavery throughout British Empire. William Wilberforce was leading abolitionist and Quakers set up first anti-slavery groups. More than 2 million migrants came from India and China to replace labour force.

questions.question: Which TWO are NOT part of the UK?
questions.explanation: The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: What do many theatres produce at Christmas time?
questions.explanation: One British tradition is the pantomime. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences. One of the traditional characters is the Dame, a woman played by a man. There is often also a pantomime horse or cow played by two actors in the same costume.

questions.question: Winston Churchill lost the General Election in 1945
questions.explanation: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship. He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.

questions.question: Who was the monarch when the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England. A version of this book is still used in some churches today.

questions.question: Britain became fully democratic in the 19th century
questions.explanation: The UK has had a fully democratic voting system since 1928 (20th century). The present voting age of 18 was set in 1969 and (with a few exceptions) all UK-born and naturalised adult citizens have the right to vote.

questions.question: When did motor-car racing start in the UK?
questions.explanation: Motor-car racing in the UK started in 1902. The UK continues to be a world leader in the development and manufacture of motor-sport technology. A Formula 1 Grand Prix event is held in the UK each year and a number of British Grand Prix drivers have won the Formula 1 World Championship. Recent British winners include Damon Hill, Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these drugs can you buy or sell legally in UK?
questions.explanation: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK.

questions.question: Which sport often refers to the phrase 'rain stopped play'?
questions.explanation: You may come across expressions such as 'rain stopped play', 'batting on a sticky wicket', 'playing a straight bat', 'bowled a googly' or 'it's just not cricket', which have passed into everyday usage. The most famous cricket competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

questions.question: Who was Thomas Gainsborough?
questions.explanation: Thomas Gainsborough (1727-88) was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenery.

possible_answers.text: Was a landscape painter in modern style
Painted pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours
Was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenery
Is best known for his large bronze abstract sculptures

correct_answers: Was a portrait painter who often painted people in country or garden scenery

questions.question: What is the most famous competition which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia?
questions.explanation: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The idiosyncratic nature of the game and its complex laws are said to reflect the best of the British character and sense of fair play. You may come across expressions such as 'rain stopped play', 'batting on a sticky wicket', 'playing a straight bat', 'bowled a googly' or 'it's just not cricket', which have passed into everyday usage. The most famous competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Lord of the Rings'?
questions.explanation: The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best-loved novel in 2003.

questions.question: Where did the people of the Bronze Age bury their dead?
questions.explanation: People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What does the UK offer to its residents?
questions.explanation: In return, the UK offers: freedom of belief and religion, freedom of speech, freedom from unfair discrimination, a right to a fair trial, a right to join in the election of a government.

questions.question: When were the women given the right to vote at the same age as men?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: What is known as the Bessemer process?
questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

questions.question: Which party formed the government in 2010?
questions.explanation: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What organisations try to influence government policy?
questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are the youth cases heard in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In Scotland a system called the Children's Hearings System is used to deal with children and young people who have committed an offence.

possible_answers.text: There is a Children's Hearings System

correct_answers: There is a Children's Hearings System

questions.question: When did Scotland abolish the authority of the Pope?
questions.explanation: Scotland had also been strongly influenced by Protestant ideas. In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.

questions.question: Which play was written by Shakespeare?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet. Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V); To be or not to be (Hamlet); A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet); All the world's a stage (As You Like It); The darling buds of May (Sonnet 18, Shall I Compare Thee To a Summer's Day).

questions.question: Where is the Eden Project located?
questions.explanation: The Eden Project is located in Cornwall, in the south west of England. Its biomes, which are like giant greenhouses, house plants from all over the world. The Eden Project is also a charity which runs environmental and social projects internationally.

questions.question: Which TWO scientists led a team which was the first to clone an animal?
questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep. This has led to further research into the possible use of cloning to preserve endangered species and for medical purposes.

questions.question: When did the American colonies declare independence?
questions.explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Monarch is responsible for the opening of the new parliamentary session each year
questions.explanation: The Monarch has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Monarch makes a speech which summarises the government’s policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in her/his name.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is the next heir to the throne?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952 (in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee - 60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. Her eldest son, King Charles III (previously the Prince of Wales) became the new monarch. His elder son, William, Prince of Wales is next in line.

questions.question: Henry VIII's fourth wife, Anne of Cleves was a Spanish princess
questions.explanation: Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.

questions.question: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers began to colonise which part of the world?
questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.

questions.question: In which years did British Film Studios flourish?
questions.explanation: British studios flourished in the 1930s. The 1950s and 1960s were a high point for British comedies, including Passport to Pimlico, The Ladykillers and, later, the Carry On films.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The jury decides whether a person is 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard
questions.explanation: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of 'not proven' is also possible. If the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty. The judge is only responsible for interpreting the law.

questions.question: How many Olympic gold medals has the Scottish cyclist, Sir Chris Hoy, won?
questions.explanation: Sir Chris Hoy (1976-) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

questions.question: During the WWII, the evacuation of more than 300,000 British and French soldiers from France gave rise to which phrase?
questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. Although many lives and a lot of equipment were lost, the evacuation was a success and meant that Britain was better able to continue the fight against the Germans. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

questions.question: Which film or film franchise produced in UK has been the biggest gross earner?
questions.explanation: Many of the films now produced in the UK are made by foreign companies, using British expertise. Some of the most commercially successful films of all time, including the two highest-grossing film franchises (Harry Potter and James Bond), have been produced in the UK.

questions.question: What is the reason for more ageing population? Choose Two Answers
questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is 'God Save the King/Queen'. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King/Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: 'God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King!'.

questions.question: What did the 'Bill of Rights' confirm?
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

questions.question: When did people learn how to make bronze?
questions.explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze

questions.question: When is Valentine's Day?
questions.explanation: Valentine's Day, 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they secretly admire.

questions.question: Which Scottish poet wrote 'The Bruce'?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, many people continued to speak Gaelic and the Scots language also developed. A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often do you have to take the MOT test for an old vehicle?
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

questions.question: When did Britain become separated from the continent?
questions.explanation: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.

questions.question: When did many Scottish people leave for North America?
questions.explanation: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

questions.question: What is the most famous rugby tournament?
questions.explanation: The most famous rugby union competition is the Six Nations Championship between England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France and Italy. The Super League is the most well-known rugby league (club) competition.

questions.question: Where can you see the 'Bayeux Tapestry' today?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is an example of a Criminal Offence?
questions.explanation: Examples of criminal laws are: Carrying a weapon, selling or buying drugs, racial crime, selling tobacco to under 18s, smoking/drinking in public in inappropriate places, buying alcohol for under 18s.

questions.question: Who was Isambard Kingdom Brunel?
questions.explanation: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships.

questions.question: The Union Flag is made up of Welsh, Scottish, Irish and English crosses
questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

questions.question: Scotland and Wales remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule
questions.explanation: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

questions.question: Oliver Cromwell took the title 'King of Ireland'
questions.explanation: Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658. Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'

questions.question: On Valentine's Day people exchange gifts and cards and send anonymous cards to people they secretly admire
questions.explanation: Valentine's Day, 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they secretly admire.

questions.question: Who wrote music for George VI and Queen Elizabeth II?
questions.explanation: Sir William Walton (1902-83) wrote a wide range of music, from film scores to opera. He wrote marches for the coronations of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth II but his best-known works are probably Facade, which became a ballet, and Balthazar's Feast, which is intended to be sung by a large choir.

questions.question: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel
questions.explanation: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When did hereditary peers lose the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

questions.question: Which official holiday is celebrated on the 30th November in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their patron saint's day as an official holiday. Events are held across Scotland, Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, especially where there are a lot of people of Scottish, Northern Irish and Irish heritage.

questions.question: When is St George's Day?
