questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

questions.question: Who led the invasion of England in 1066?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.question: Who was Catherine of Aragon (the first of Henry VIII's six wives)?
questions.explanation: Catherine was a Spanish princess. She and Henry had a number of children but only one, Mary, survived. When Catherine was too old to give him another child, Henry decided to divorce her, hoping that another wife would give him a son to be his heir.

questions.question: What is Sir Isaac Newton's famous published work?
questions.explanation: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ('Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow

questions.question: Who is Sir Edward Elgar(1857-1934)?
questions.explanation: Sir Edward Elgar (1857-1934) was born in Worcester, England. His best-known work is probably the Pomp and Circumstance Marches. March No 1 (Land of Hope and Glory) is usually played at the Last Night of the Proms at the Royal Albert Hall.

questions.question: Nick Park created the 'Wallace and Gromit' film. What kind of film was it?
questions.explanation: Britain continues to be particularly strong in special effects and animation. One example is the work of Nick Park, who has won four Oscars for his animated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

questions.question: What Palace was a cast-iron and plate-glass building originally erected in Hyde Park, London, England, to house the Great Exhibition of 1851?
questions.explanation: British industry led the world in the 19th century. The UK produced more than half of the world's iron, coal and cotton cloth. The UK also became a centre for financial services, including insurance and banking. In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass. Exhibits ranged from huge machines to handmade goods. Countries from all over the world showed their goods but most of the objects were made in Britain.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: World Wide Web was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955-) who is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

questions.question: What percentage of the population has a grandparent born outside of the UK?
questions.explanation: Post-war immigration means that nearly 10% of the population has a parent or grandparent born outside the UK.

questions.question: Where can you find the ship HMS Victory now?
questions.explanation: HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth. It was Admiral Nelson's ship.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How long can you use an EU driving licence for?
questions.explanation: If your driving licence is from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid, subject to UK licence renewal requirements (at the age of 70, or three years after the driver becomes resident). If you have a licence from any other country, you may use it in the UK for up to 12 months.

questions.question: What does the Turner Prize celebrate?
questions.explanation: The Turner Prize was established in 1984 and celebrates contemporary art.

questions.question: Who discovered Insulin?
questions.explanation: The Scottish physician and researcher John MacLeod (1876-1935) was the co-discoverer of insulin, used to treat diabetes.

questions.question: When did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: Which of these is an Anglo-Saxon poem?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon poem 'Beowulf' tells of its hero's battles against monsters and is still translated into modern English.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which court deals with the most serious cases in Scotland?
questions.explanation: The most serious cases in Scotland, such as murder, are heard at a High Court with a judge and jury.

questions.question: What was the 'Black Death'?
questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

questions.question: The Bill of Rights confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the King's power
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

questions.question: When William of Orange re-conquered Ireland (in 1690) he took the title 'William the Conqueror'
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

questions.question: Why is 1928 an important date for women's rights?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

possible_answers.text: Women could vote at 21, the same age as men
Women could vote at 18, the same age as men
Women could vote if they were over 30 years old

correct_answers: Women could vote at 21, the same age as men

questions.question: English laws and the English language were introduced in Wales by the middle of which century?
questions.explanation: By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.

questions.question: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished glassworkers
questions.explanation: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkers

questions.question: Whose powers were increased by the Bill of Rights of 1689?
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant. A new Parliament had to be elected at least every three years.

questions.question: What is Diwali?
questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

questions.question: Charles Dickens, Thomas Hardy and Jane Austen are famous writers
questions.explanation: They are all famous authors and writers.

questions.question: Where is the Royal Crescent is located?
questions.explanation: In the 18th century, simpler designs became popular. The Scottish architect Robert Adam influenced the development of architecture in the UK, Europe and America. He designed the inside decoration as well as the building itself in great houses such as Dumfries House in Scotland. His ideas influenced architects in cities such as Bath, where the Royal Crescent was built.

questions.question: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome. Where did he spread Christianity?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons were not Christians when they first came to Britain but, during this period, missionaries came to Britain to preach about Christianity. Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Which pair won gold medals for Ice dancing at the Olympic Games in 1984 and in four consecutive world championships?
questions.explanation: Jayne Torvill (1957-) and Christopher Dean (1958-) won gold medals for ice dancing at the Olympic Games in 1984 and in four consecutive world championships.

questions.question: Which TWO are associated with rugby?
questions.explanation: The most famous rugby union competition is the Six Nations Championship between England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France and Italy. The Super League is the most well-known rugby league (club) competition.

questions.question: The band called Beatles was popular and some alteration to social laws occurred during which period?
questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as 'the Swinging Sixties'. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland. The position of women in the workplace also improved.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

questions.question: What did the Statute of Rhuddlan do?
questions.explanation: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

questions.question: Which of these was a British plane in WWII?
questions.explanation: The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain were the Spitfire and the Hurricane - which were designed and built in Britain.

questions.question: Which is not a Protestant Christian group?
questions.explanation: There is no established Church in Wales or Northern Ireland. Other Protestant Christian groups in the UK are Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers. There are also other denominations of Christianity, the biggest of which is Roman Catholic.

questions.question: What is the capital of Scotland?
questions.explanation: Edinburgh is the capital city of Scotland.

questions.question: When did the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms establish in Britain?
questions.explanation: Britain was invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons. The languages they spoke are the basis of modern-day English. Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.

questions.question: Where can you visit Admiral Nelson's ship , HMS Victory?
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelson's ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth

questions.question: What time do Public Houses open at?
questions.explanation: Public houses (pubs) are an important part of the UK social culture. Pubs are usually open during the day from 11.00 am (12 noon on Sundays).

questions.question: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, what English county does it stand in?
questions.explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What do you have to pay tax on in the UK?
questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes: wages from paid employment; profits from self-employment, taxable benefits; pensions; income from property, savings and dividends.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: On election day, you will get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in front of the polling officer
questions.explanation: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification. You will then get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in privately

questions.question: Which popular yearly sporting event takes place between Oxford and Cambridge universities?
questions.explanation: Rowing is also popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport. There is a popular yearly race on the Thames between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

questions.question: Dame Ellen MacArthur is famous for her achievements in which sport?
questions.explanation: Dame Ellen MacArthur (1976-) is a yachtswoman and in 2004 became the fastest person to sail around the world single handed.

questions.question: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games three times. When did the UK host the games in the 20th century? (Choose TWO)
questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London. The British team was very successful, across a wide range of Olympic sports, finishing third in the medal table.

questions.question: When did the first farmers start settling in Britain?
questions.explanation: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe. These people built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

questions.question: What followed the Bronze Age?
questions.explanation: The Bronze Age was followed by the Iron Age, when people learned how to make weapons and tools out of iron.

questions.question: James VI of Scotland was not related to Queen Elizabeth I of England
questions.explanation: Mary was suspected of murdering her husband and fled to England. She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland. Mary was Elizabeth I's cousin.

questions.question: Which of these flowers is closely associated with Remembrance Day?
questions.explanation: The poppy has become the symbol of Remembrance worn during the weeks leading to Remembrance Sunday and Armistice Day.

questions.question: Who, in 1810 opened the first curry house in Britain called 'The Hindoostane Coffee House' in George Street, London?
questions.explanation: In 1810 Sake Dean Mahomet opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

questions.question: Which TWO are correct about King Henry's wives?
questions.explanation: 3 of the wives were called Catherine and 2 were called Anne.

possible_answers.text: Two of the wives were sisters

questions.question: Ralph Vaughan Williams was strongly influenced by traditional English folk music
questions.explanation: Ralph Vaughan Williams (1872-1958) wrote music for orchestras and choirs. He was strongly influenced by traditional English folk music.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What's the Monarch's yearly parliamentary speech for?
questions.explanation: The King has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Monarch makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

possible_answers.text: Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year
Give advice to the general public on upcoming legislations
Summarise all of the last year's policies

correct_answers: Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How can you arrange to get a National Insurance number?
questions.explanation: If you have permission to work in the UK, you will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

possible_answers.text: Contact the Department for Work and Pensions

correct_answers: Contact the Department for Work and Pensions

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How can you contact your MP?
questions.explanation: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons

questions.question: Where is the Cenotaph located?
questions.explanation: The Cenotaph can be visited in London in Whitehall.

questions.question: What proportion of the population died because of the Black Death?
questions.explanation: One third of the population of England and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales died because of the Black Death.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How long does it take to give blood?
questions.explanation: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses, it takes about an hour to do so.

questions.question: What country is Swansea in?
questions.explanation: Swansea is a Welsh city.

questions.question: How is the New Year often called in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. His best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.question: What did the Magna Carta do?
questions.explanation: The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king's power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

questions.question: Which of these is known as West End in London?
questions.explanation: There are theatres in most towns and cities throughout the UK, ranging from the large to the small. London's West End, also known as 'Theatreland', is particularly well known.

questions.question: The King James' Bible is a new translation of the Bible into English
questions.explanation: One achievement of King James' reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'. It was not the first English Bible but is a version which continues to be used in many Protestant churches today.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: For which TWO subjects are the Secretaries of State responsible?
questions.explanation: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

questions.question: Which TWO kings believed in the 'Divine Right of Kings'?
questions.explanation: James I and his son Charles I were less skilled politically. Both believed in the 'Divine Right of Kings': the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. They thought that the king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

questions.question: Which TWO of these aircrafts were used by Britain in WWII?
questions.explanation: The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain(1940) were the Spitfire and the Hurricane - which were designed and built in Britain.

questions.question: During Queen Elizabeth I's reign the English (1588) defeated a large fleet of ships. Where did the ships come from?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: People don't celebrate Christmas as much as they used to before
questions.explanation: Christmas remains very popular in the UK. People usually spend the day at home and eat a special meal, which often includes roast turkey, Christmas pudding and mince pies.

questions.question: Which TWO British Actors have recently won Oscars?
questions.explanation: British actors continue to be popular and continue to win awards throughout the world. Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for Public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

possible_answers.text: People found guilty of all criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office
People found guilty of certain criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office

correct_answers: People found guilty of certain criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In Northern Ireland, Deputy District Judges hear minor criminal cases
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court. In Northern Ireland, cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Big Ben was named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth I
questions.explanation: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London. Many people call the clock Big Ben as well. The clock is over 150 years old and is a popular tourist attraction. The clock tower is named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

questions.question: The Lake District is the largest national park in Scotland
questions.explanation: The Lake District is England's largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors. The biggest stretch of water is Windermere. In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain's favourite view.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the minimum age for going into betting shops or gambling clubs?
questions.explanation: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the name of the charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK?
questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Every MP in the UK has his/her own constituency
questions.explanation: Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs from the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In the UK, under the Individual Electoral Registration (IER) system, every eligible person is individually responsible for their own registration.
questions.explanation: The Individual Electoral Registration system replaced the old "head of household" method where one person could register everyone in the home. Now, each eligible person is legally responsible for their own registration.

questions.question: Who helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) in 1903?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU).

questions.question: The Union Jack is comprised of four countries' crosses. They are: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
questions.explanation: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack. The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. It is still used today as the official flag of the UK.

questions.question: Who was one of the founders of England's naval tradition?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition. His ship (The Golden Hind) was one of the first to sail around the world.

questions.question: How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have in the middle ages?
questions.explanation: In the middle ages the Scottish Parliament had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

questions.question: Which clan was killed because of not taking an oath?
questions.explanation: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What information about you is asked at the polling station?
questions.explanation: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification.

possible_answers.text: Your name, contact details and age

questions.question: What treaty was signed in 1707?
questions.explanation: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was therefore agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

possible_answers.text: The Act for Government of Wales

questions.question: Which was the last successful invasion of Britain?
questions.explanation: The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

questions.question: When was the time of growing patriotism?
questions.explanation: The Elizabethan period in England was a time of growing patriotism: a feeling of pride in being English. English explorers sought new trade routes and tried to expand British trade into the Spanish colonies in the Americas.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO changes did the Chartists campaign for?
questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote; elections every year; for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

possible_answers.text: For every woman to have the vote

questions.question: The Corn Laws were repealed in 1846. These had prevented the import of cheap grain
questions.explanation: The statement is true.

questions.question: What are Halloween lanterns traditionally made out of?
questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Speaker also represents Parliament on ceremonial occasions
questions.explanation: The Speaker keeps order during political debates to make sure the rules are followed. This includes making sure the opposition (see The government) has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses. The Speaker also represents Parliament on ceremonial occasions.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: You must treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, age, religion, disability, class or sexual orientation
questions.explanation: The statement is true.

questions.question: In the 2021 England and Wales census, what percentage of people identified themselves as Christian?
questions.explanation: The 2021 Census results released so far show that 46% of people in England and Wales (from a total sampled 60 million) identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 37% stated not to follow any religion and 0.5% of people followed another religion

questions.question: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country
questions.explanation: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country. The English first went to Ireland as troops to help the Irish king and remained to build their own settlements. By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin. Some of the important lords in other parts of Ireland accepted the authority of the English king.

questions.question: Who led the Scottish, in 1314, to defeat the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Reform Act of 1832 took away the automatic right of hereditary peers to attend the House of Lords
questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs and more parliamentary seats were given to the towns and cities.

questions.question: The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for the whole lifetime to speak on behalf of that Church.
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

questions.question: The Protestants formed their own churches during the Reformation
questions.explanation: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church. The Protestants formed their own churches. They read the Bible in their own languages instead of in Latin; they did not pray to saints or at shrines; and they believed that a person's own relationship with God was more important than submitting to the authority of the Church. Protestant ideas gradually gained strength in England, Wales and Scotland during the 16th century.

questions.question: If you wish to be a permanent resident of the UK, you should look after yourself. In return you are guaranteed a job
questions.explanation: You are not guaranteed a job if you settle in the UK.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What did the Beveridge Report of 1942, by William Beveridge, provide the basis for?
questions.explanation: William Beveridge (later Lord Beveridge) was a British economist and social reformer. He served briefly as a Liberal MP and was subsequently the leader of the Liberals in the House of Lords but is best known for the 1942 report Social Insurance and Allied Services (known as the Beveridge Report). The report was commissioned by the wartime government in 1941. It recommended that the government should find ways of fighting the five 'Giant Evils' of Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness and provided the basis of the modern welfare state.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO are safe places to go and stay in for anyone facing domestic violence?
questions.explanation: It is important for anyone facing domestic violence to get help as soon as possible. A solicitor or the Citizens Advice Bureau can explain the available options. In some areas there are safe places to go and stay in, called refuges or shelters.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How are members of Parliament (MPs) elected?
questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected. The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The European Union was originally called the EEC
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

questions.question: Which Admiral's Column is in Trafalgar Square, London?
questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle. Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square, London, is a monument to him. His ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which TWO are British Overseas territories?
questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

questions.question: Which flag has a white cross on a blue background?
questions.explanation: Scottish flag has a white cross on a blue background because St Andrew was the Patron Saint of Scotland.

questions.question: Where does the Fringe take place?
questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Festival takes place in Edinburgh, Scotland, every summer. The most well-known is the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, also known as the Fringe.

questions.question: When did the Roman army leave Britain?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

questions.question: What helped the progress of the industrial revolution?
questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: What was the estimated population of the British Empire?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

questions.question: How many times did Sir Jackie Stewart win the Formula 1 championship?
questions.explanation: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939-) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times.

questions.question: Who was R. A. Butler?
questions.explanation: Richard Austen Butler (later Lord Butler) was born in 1902. He became a Conservative MP in 1923 and held several positions before becoming responsible for education in 1941.

questions.question: What county is 'Maiden Castle' in?
questions.explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

questions.question: What country did Britain fight against during the Crimean War?
questions.explanation: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs. Many soldiers died from illnesses they caught in the hospitals, rather than from war wounds. Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during this war.

questions.question: The Medieval Period is referred to the period after the Norman Conquest up until what year?
questions.explanation: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period). It was a time of almost constant war.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In Northern Ireland, minor cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court. In Northern Ireland, cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How long does it take to give blood?
questions.explanation: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses. Giving blood only takes about an hour to do.

questions.question: Falkland Islands are a Crown Dependency
questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these statements is incorrect?
questions.explanation: Owing money is a civil offence

possible_answers.text: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin is illegal in the UK
It's a criminal offence to offend one's religion or ethnic origin
It's a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind
It's a criminal offence to owe someone money

correct_answers: It's a criminal offence to owe someone money

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO countries took part in the development of Concorde?
questions.explanation: The 1960s was also a time of technological progress. Britain and France developed the world's only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde. New styles of architecture, including high-rise buildings and the use of concrete and steel, became common.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.explanation: The king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

possible_answers.text: Charles I's army was defeated at the Battle of Marston Moor but won the Battle of Naseby
Parliament won the English Civil War

correct_answers: Parliament won the English Civil War

questions.question: What is the highest denomination of coins one can find in the UK?
questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

questions.question: Sir Ian Botham is famous for his achievements in which sport?
questions.explanation: Sir Ian Botham (1955-) captained the English cricket team and holds a number of English Test cricket records, both for batting and for bowling.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: National Trust is a charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside
questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

questions.question: What character did Charlie Chaplin play?
questions.explanation: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

questions.question: Who ran 1 mile in 4 minutes in 1954?
questions.explanation: Sir Roger Bannister (1929-) was the first man in the world to run a mile in under four minutes, in 1954.

questions.question: Queen Elizabeth I was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants
questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary'). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When did the UK join the EU?
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

questions.question: Who defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo?
questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is 'God Save the King/Queen'. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King/Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: 'God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King!'.

questions.question: Who was the first Danish King?
questions.explanation: The first Danish King was Cnut, also called Canute.

questions.question: How long is Hanukkah celebrated for?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

questions.question: How old do you have to be to buy a lottery ticket or a scratch card?
questions.explanation: As of 2021, people under 18 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery (Previously 16). This includes buying Scratch Cards.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many 'local authorities' does the city of London have?
questions.explanation: London has 33 local authorities, with the Greater London Authority and the Mayor of London coordinating policies across the capital.

questions.question: Who developed important Economics ideas?
questions.explanation: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

questions.question: What happens at 11:00 on the Remembrance Day?
questions.explanation: Remembrance Day, 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies. Originally it commemorated the dead of the First World War, which ended on 11 November 1918. People wear poppies (the red flower found on the battlefields of the First World War). At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the Emancipation Act?
questions.explanation: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

possible_answers.text: Abolish slavery in the British Empire
No one could be held prisoner unlawfully

correct_answers: Abolish slavery in the British Empire

questions.question: Who was the first 'Scottish King'?
questions.explanation: In the north, the threat of attack by Vikings had encouraged the people to unite under one king, Kenneth MacAlpin. The term Scotland began to be used to describe that country.

questions.question: When was the famous satirical magazine 'Punch' published?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, satirical magazines began to be published. The most famous was 'Punch', which was published for the first time in the 1840s. Today, political cartoons continue to be published in newspapers, and magazines such as Private Eye continue the tradition of satire.

questions.question: How old do you have to be to go into betting shops or gambling clubs?
questions.explanation: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

questions.question: Which TWO are used when making Haggis?
questions.explanation: Scottish Traditional Food: Haggis, a sheep's stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

questions.question: What are the 40 days before Easter known as?
questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day. Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

questions.question: As per 2021 England and Wales census, what's the percetage of Jewish or Buddhist people in the UK?
questions.explanation: In the 2021 England and Wales census, around 525,000 people from the sampled population of 60 million identified as Sikh. 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (6.5%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register
questions.explanation: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register. If you are eligible to vote, you can register by contacting your local council electoral registration Office.

questions.question: In what year did the Troubles break out?
questions.explanation: Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland. The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as 'the Troubles'.

questions.question: The Welsh language, spoken in Wales and is taught in schools and universities, is a completely different language from English
questions.explanation: The English language has many accents and dialects. In Wales, many people speak Welsh - a completely different language from English - and it is taught in schools and universities. In Scotland, Gaelic (again, a different language) is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In which TWO countries were PCCs elected in?
questions.explanation: In November 2012, the public elected Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) in England and Wales. These are directly elected individuals who are responsible for the delivery of an efficient and effective police force that reflects the needs of their local communities. PCCs set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the Chief Constable.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When did newspapers begin to operate without a government licence?
questions.explanation: This was also an important time for the development of a free press (newspapers and other publications which are not controlled by the government). From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

questions.question: In which country was Charles II residing before he was invited to England by the Parliament?
questions.explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

questions.question: During Queen Elizabeth's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world had ever seen
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: You need to be a member of a political party to be able to stand for election as an MP
questions.explanation: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties.

questions.question: You are not responsible for cleaning up after your pet in public places
questions.explanation: The owner is responsible for keeping the dog under control and for cleaning up after the animal in a public place.

questions.question: Who was Henry Purcell?
questions.explanation: Henry Purcell (1659-95) was the organist at Westminster Abbey. He wrote church music and operas.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What is the responsibility that you have as a UK citizen?
questions.explanation: Flowing from the fundamental principles are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK and which we expect all residents to respect. If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law; respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions; treat others with fairness; look after yourself and your family; look after the area in which you live and the environment.

possible_answers.text: Look after yourself and your family

correct_answers: Look after yourself and your family

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many member states does the UN have?
questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which is an example of a Civil Offence?
questions.explanation: Examples of civil laws are - Housing law: this includes disputes between landlords and tenants over issues such as repairs and eviction; Consumer rights: an example of this is a dispute about faulty goods or services; Employment law: these cases include disputes over wages and cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace; Debt: people might be taken to court if they owe money to someone.

questions.question: Who built the Hadrian's Wall to keep out the Picts?
questions.explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.question: What is Diwali often called?
questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

questions.question: What is the maximum fine if you watch TV without a valid TV licence?
questions.explanation: You will receive a fine of up to £1,000 if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

questions.question: What county does Stonehenge stand in?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

questions.question: What does the York Minster have?
questions.explanation: York Minster had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints.

questions.question: Which was a crucial aerial battle against the Germans?
questions.explanation: The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called 'the Battle of Britain'.

questions.question: By which year did the English rule an area around Dublin called the Pale?
questions.explanation: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country. The English first went to Ireland as troops to help the Irish king and remained to build their own settlements. By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin. Some of the important lords in other parts of Ireland accepted the authority of the English king.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who appoints the members of the Cabinet?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments which together form the cabinet.

questions.question: When were women given the right to vote at the same age as men?
questions.explanation: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: Which house won the War of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often are Elections for the European parliament held?
questions.explanation: Elections for the European Parliament are also held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs).

questions.question: Which TWO materials did the UK produce more than half of the world in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: British industry led the world in the 19th century. The UK produced more than half of the world's iron, coal and cotton cloth.

questions.question: When was a Turing machine invented?
questions.explanation: A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s. The theory was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer.

questions.question: Queen Elizabeth II was married to Prince Phillip
questions.explanation: The statement is true

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election
questions.explanation: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition. The leader of the opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: It is illegal for shops and businesses to not accept the banknotes of Northern Ireland and Scotland
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The devolved governments do not have the power to legislate on any issues but can advise and encourage
questions.explanation: Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The anthem 'God save the King/Queen' can only be played in presence of the Monarch
questions.explanation: You can play the Anthem in anyone's presence

questions.question: What is the Cenotaph associated with?
questions.explanation: After the First World War, Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen/King, politicians and foreign ambassadors

questions.question: Which of these venues is located in Scotland?
questions.explanation: The Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) is located in Glasgow, Scotland.

questions.question: Which of these are 'Crown Dependencies'?
questions.explanation: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man are closely related to the UK but are not part of it. They have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

possible_answers.text: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man

correct_answers: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man

questions.question: Who was the first woman Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK. She was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.

questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote;elections every year;for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

possible_answers.text: Anyone to be able to stand as an MP
Every man to have a vote

correct_answers: Every man to have a vote

questions.question: When did the Romans successfully invade Britain?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the country house owned by the Prime Minister called?
questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

questions.question: Who led the team of scientists to 'split the atom' for the first time?
questions.explanation: Scientists led by Ernest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to 'split the atom' and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

questions.question: When is Vaisakhi celebrated?
questions.explanation: Vaisakhi (also spelled Baisakhi) is a Sikh festival which celebrates the founding of the Sikh community known as the Khalsa. It is celebrated on 14 April each year with parades, dancing and singing.

questions.question: What were the refugees that came from France between 1680 and 1720 called?
questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where can you get help from if you are facing domestic violence?
questions.explanation: It is important for anyone facing domestic violence to get help as soon as possible. A solicitor or the Citizens Advice Bureau can explain the available options.

questions.question: Mary Stuart (also known as 'Mary, Queen of Scots') fled to England. She was suspected of trying to take over the throne and was kept a prisoner for 20 years
questions.explanation: The statement is true.

questions.question: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans
questions.explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.question: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question: Which TWO of these are cycling athletes?
questions.explanation: Sir Chris Hoy (1976-) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles. Bradley Wiggins (1980-) is a cyclist. In 2012, he became the first Briton to win the Tour de France. He has won seven Olympic medals, including gold medals in the 2004, 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In Scotland, judges developed 'common law' by following previous decisions. It was referred to as 'unwritten'
questions.explanation: In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition. In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: You need to buy a TV Licence if there are no TVs in your house but you watch TV programs on your mobile phone
questions.explanation: You must pay for a licence to watch TV through any medium.

questions.question: Which TWO of these are English civil war battles?
questions.explanation: During the civil war, the king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which TWO of these are core values and responsibilities of the British society?
questions.explanation: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities include: to obey and respect the law; to be aware of the rights of others and respect those rights; to treat others with fairness; to behave responsibly; to help and protect your family; to respect and preserve the environment; to treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, religion, age, disability, class or sexual orientation; to work to provide for yourself and your family; to help others; to vote in local and national government elections.

possible_answers.text: Always share the same views as your partner
To vote in local and national government elections
To work to provide for yourself and your family

correct_answers: To vote in local and national government elections
To work to provide for yourself and your family

questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.question: There is a dragon on the official flag of Wales
questions.explanation: here is also an official Welsh flag, which shows a Welsh dragon. The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO of these roles, in the UK, are unpaid?
questions.explanation: You can volunteer with the police, and become a special constable or a lay (non-police) representative. You can also apply to become a Magistrate.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: You have to be 21 years old to stand as an MP
questions.explanation: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties. These are the Conservative Party, the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats, or one of the parties representing Scottish, Welsh or Northern Irish interests.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are the minor criminal cases dealt with in England, Wales and N. Ireland?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The National Citizen Service programme gives 16 and 17 year olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills
questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project

questions.question: What was the population of the UK in 1901?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK was 40 million in 1901.

questions.question: When is Halloween celebrated?
questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

questions.question: When was the first coin in Britain made?
questions.explanation: The Iron Age people made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What programme helps teenagers develop their skills?
questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When were women given the right to vote at the age of 18?
questions.explanation: By 1918, the voting franchise was extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

questions.question: Which of these words is based on Norman words?
questions.explanation: Some words in modern English - for example, 'park' and 'beauty' - are based on Norman French words. Others - for example, 'apple', 'cow' and 'summer' - are based on Anglo-Saxon words.

questions.question: Where is the Hadrian Wall?
questions.explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.question: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

questions.question: Puritans are a group of Catholics who advocate complex religious doctrine and worship
questions.explanation: Puritans, a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship.

questions.question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explanation: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there. Britain gained control over Canada, and the East India Company, originally set up to trade, gained control of large parts of India.

questions.question: Easter eggs are often given as presents at Easter as a symbol of new life
questions.explanation: Easter is also celebrated by people who are not religious. 'Easter eggs' are chocolate eggs often given as presents at Easter as a symbol of new life.

questions.question: How many counties in Ireland remained in the UK under Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries. The six counties in the north which were mainly Protestant remained part of the UK under the name Northern Ireland. The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.

questions.question: Why is 1969 a very important year in British history?
questions.explanation: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

possible_answers.text: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 30
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, same as men
Women were given the right to vote

correct_answers: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Blood and organ donations are compulsory in the UK
questions.explanation: it's a donation, thus its not compulsory. Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses. Giving blood only takes about an hour to do.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How can you help looking after the environment?
questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. Using recycled materials to make new products uses less energy and means that we do not need to extract more raw materials from the earth. It also means that less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced.

questions.question: Which TWO industries developed during the Great Depression?
questions.explanation: During the Great Depression (1929),he traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries - including the automobile and aviation industries - developed.

questions.question: What is the currency used in the UK?
questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound.

questions.question: Which TWO are associated with the 'Dunkirk Spirit'?
questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. Although many lives and a lot of equipment were lost, the evacuation was a success and meant that Britain was better able to continue the fight against the Germans. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

possible_answers.text: Small boats coming to the rescue

correct_answers: Small boats coming to the rescue

questions.question: George Frederick wrote which oratorio, which is sung regularly by choirs, often at Easter time?
questions.explanation: The German-born composer George Frideric Handel (1695-1759) spent many years in the UK and became a British citizen in 1727. He wrote the Water Music for King George I and Music for the Royal Fireworks for his son, George II. Both these pieces continue to be very popular. Handel also wrote an oratorio, Messiah, which is sung regularly by choirs, often at Easter time.

questions.question: How many ski centres are there in Scotland?
questions.explanation: There are five ski centres in Scotland, as well as Europe's longest dry ski slope near Edinburgh.

questions.question: What type of literature are 'The Canterbury Tales' written by Geoffrey Chaucer?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales. It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press. Many of the stories are still popular. Some have been made into plays and television programmes.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Scottish Parliament has 33 members
questions.explanation: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation. The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters which are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament.

questions.question: What did the Queen Elizabeth II celebrate in 2012?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her Diamond Jubilee in 2012. The clock tower 'Big Ben' was named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of this event.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is currently the Head of State of the UK?
questions.explanation: King Charles III is the head of state of the UK. He is also the monarch or head of state for many countries in the Commonwealth.

questions.question: Why was Mary known as 'Bloody Mary'?
questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

possible_answers.text: She put her sister in prison

questions.question: What was encouraged to develop the UK economy in 1950?
questions.explanation: During the 1950s, there was still a shortage of labour in the UK. Further immigration was therefore encouraged for economic reasons, and many industries advertised for workers from overseas.

questions.question: What was the first war to be extensively covered by the media?
questions.explanation: From 1853 to 1856, Britain fought with Turkey and France against Russia in the Crimean War. It was the first war to be extensively covered by the media through news stories and photographs

questions.question: Which of these countries was NOT UK's ally in the WWII?
questions.explanation: The war was initially fought between the Axis powers (fascist Germany and Italy and the Empire of Japan) and the Allies

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The members of the Armed Forces can stand for Public Office
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for Public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

questions.question: Where is the SECC located?
questions.explanation: There are many large venues that host music events throughout the year, such as: Wembley Stadium; The O2 in Greenwich, south-east London; and the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) in Glasgow.

questions.question: People of the Iron Age sometimes defended sites. What were these sites?
questions.explanation: People still lived in roundhouses, grouped together into larger settlements, and sometimes defended sites called hill forts. A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

questions.question: What is the capital of Wales?
questions.explanation: Cardiff is the capital city of Wales

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often are the European Parliament elections held?
