questions.explanation: Elections for the European Parliament are also held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs). Elections to the European Parliament use a system of proportional representation, where seats are allocated to each party in proportion to the total number of votes it has won.

questions.question: How is the Church of England often called?
questions.explanation: In England, there is a constitutional link between Church and state. The official Church of the state is the Church of England called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States.

questions.question: What do the Brit Awards celebrate?
questions.explanation: The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

questions.question: Which TWO houses formed the House of Tudor?
questions.explanation: King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII. Henry then married King Richard's niece, Elizabeth of York, and united the two families. Henry was the first king of the House of Tudor. The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous UK sports stars?
questions.explanation: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939-) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times. Sir Chris Hoy (1976-) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

questions.question: Which Monarch entered the House of Commons to arrest 5 parliamentary leaders?
questions.explanation: Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there. (No monarch has set foot in the Commons since.) Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who appoints life peers to the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.question: Which government was elected in 1945?
questions.explanation: Clement Attlee was Winston Churchill's Deputy Prime Minister in the wartime coalition government and became Prime Minister after the Labour Party won the 1945 election. He was Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951 and led the Labour Party for 20 years. Attlee's government undertook the nationalisation of major industries (like coal and steel), created the National Health Service and implemented many of Beveridge's plans for a stronger welfare state.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous British sailors?
questions.explanation: A British sailor, Sir Francis Chichester, was the first person to sail single-handed around the world, in 1966/67. Two years later, Sir Robin Knox-Johnston became the first person to do this without stopping.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are major horse-racing events in the UK?
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

questions.question: Which TWO are associated with a Bank Holiday?
questions.explanation: Bank holidays are public holidays, when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day.

possible_answers.text: A day when most people have an official day off
A holiday which is always on a Monday
A day off for all the banks in the country

correct_answers: A day when most people have an official day off

questions.question: Which of the following is a William Wordsworth's poem?
questions.explanation: All 4 options are poems, but all written by different poets.(Robert Browning, 1812-89 'Home Thoughts from Abroad'), (Lord Byron, 1788-1824 'She Walks in Beauty'), (William Blake, 1757-1827 'The Tyger'), (William Wordsworth, 1770-1850 'The Daffodils' - 'I wander'd lonely as a cloud, That floats on high o'er vales and hills, When all at once I saw a crowd, A host of golden daffodils').

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Pakistan is part of the Commonwealth
questions.explanation: Pakistan is currently part of the Commonwealth

questions.question: Which of the following traditional heavy industries were badly affected during the great depression?
questions.explanation: The effects of the depression of the 1930s were felt differently in different parts of the UK. The traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries - including the automobile and aviation industries - developed.

questions.question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Who designed the new St Paul Cathedral?
questions.explanation: Christopher Wren designed a new St Paul Cathedral after the previous one was destroyed by a great fire in 1666.

questions.question: Who won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Dame Kelly Holmes (1970-) won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the Corn Laws in 1846?
questions.explanation: Corn Laws in 1846 had prevented the import of cheap grain.

possible_answers.text: To prevent the import of cheap grain

correct_answers: To prevent the import of cheap grain

questions.question: Where did the Vikings come from?
questions.explanation: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

questions.question: Which movement campaigned for the women's rights?
questions.explanation: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, an increasing number of women campaigned and demonstrated for greater rights and, in particular, the right to vote. They formed the women's suffrage movement and became known as 'suffragettes'.

questions.question: Who became famous in silent movies for his tramp character?
questions.explanation: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

questions.question: What do many theatres in the UK produce at Christmas time?
questions.explanation: One British tradition is the pantomime. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences. One of the traditional characters is the Dame, a woman played by a man.

questions.question: What does St Patrick's cross look like?
questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

possible_answers.text: A red cross on a white ground
A diagonal red cross on a white ground
A diagonal white cross on a blue ground

correct_answers: A diagonal red cross on a white ground

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The House of Lords is more independent of the government than the House of Commons
questions.explanation: The House of Lords is normally more independent of the government than the House of Commons. It can suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by MPs. The House of Lords checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose.

questions.question: Who should you contact to get your National Insurance number?
questions.explanation: You will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

questions.question: What is the name given to the conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the UK government?
questions.explanation: The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as 'the Troubles'.

questions.question: During the Middle Ages, which TWO wars were fought abroad?
questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, the English kings also fought a number of wars abroad. Many knights took part in the Crusades, in which European Christians fought for control of the Holy Land. English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which party forms the government?
questions.explanation: Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

possible_answers.text: The party with the majority of the members of Parliament (MPs)
The party appointed by the Monarch
The party with the most votes
The party which is the most popular

correct_answers: The party with the majority of the members of Parliament (MPs)

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who appoints the government, which most people have chosen in a democratic election?
questions.explanation: The monarch does not rule the country but appoints the government, which the people have chosen in a democratic election. The monarch invites the leader of the party with the largest number of MPs, or the leader of a coalition between more than one party, to become the Prime Minister.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Those who don't respect the law should not expect to be allowed to become permanent residents
questions.explanation: If you don't respect the law you should not expect to be allowed to settle in the UK

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often do the PM's questions take place?
questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister's Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting

questions.question: The Anglo-Saxons established Christianity when they invaded Britain
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons were not Christians when they first came to Britain but, during this period, missionaries came to Britain to preach about Christianity.

questions.question: Which of these international events was held in London in 2012?
questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The Paralympic Games for 2012 were also hosted in London.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Pressure groups and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy
questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The National Citizen Service provides military training to young people
questions.explanation: The National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Monarch appoints the members of the Cabinet
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister (PM) is the leader of the political party in power. He or she appoints the members of the Cabinet and has control over many important public appointments.

questions.question: Which TWO of the athletes are paralympians?
questions.explanation: Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games. David Weir (1979-) is a Paralympian who uses a wheelchair and has won six gold medals over two Paralympic Games. He has also won the London Marathon six times.

questions.question: After Cromwell defeated Charles II at Worcester, where did Charles II hide?
questions.explanation: The Scots had not agreed to the execution of Charles I and declared his son Charles II to be king. He was crowned king of Scotland and led a Scottish army into England. Cromwell defeated this army in the Battles of Dunbar and Worcester. Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

questions.question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What is not a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: Driving a car is NOT one of the fundamental principles of British life

questions.question: Which style of architecture became popular in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, the medieval 'gothic' style became popular once again.

questions.question: Who was the first man to be called the 'Prime Minister'?
questions.explanation: The first man to be called 'Prime Minister' was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

questions.question: What were the Canterbury Tales about?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

possible_answers.text: The stories people told each other

correct_answers: The stories people told each other

questions.question: Who is Andy Murray?
questions.explanation: Andy Murray (1987-) is a Scottish tennis player who in 2012 won the men's singles in the US Open. He is the first British man to win a singles title in a Grand Slam tournament since 1936. In the same year, he won Olympic gold and silver medals.

questions.question: How long does Diwali normally last for?
questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

questions.question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Romans had left?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

questions.question: What was the Spanish Armada?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of the devolved administrations has been suspended a few times?
questions.explanation: There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

questions.question: Who designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India?
questions.explanation: In the 20th century, Sir Edwin Lutyens had an influence throughout the British Empire. He designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India. He was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The UK has a constitutional monarchy
questions.explanation: The UK has a constitutional monarchy. This means that the king or queen does not rule the country but appoints the government, which the people have chosen in a democratic election.

questions.question: Rudyard Kipling reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good
questions.explanation: Kipling wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

questions.question: When did the British troops leave Iraq?
questions.explanation: Since 2000, British armed forces have been engaged in the global fight against international terrorism and against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. British combat troops left Iraq in 2009.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance
questions.explanation: The statement is true

questions.question: What is the national flower of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: A Shamrock is the national flower of Northern Ireland.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In England and Wales, the small claims procedure is used for claims of less than what amount?
questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £5,000 in Northern Ireland (Changed from £3000).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Many people volunteer simply because they want to help other people
questions.explanation: Volunteering and helping your community are an important part of being a good citizen. They enable you to integrate and get to know other people. It helps to make your community a better place if residents support each other.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In Northern Ireland, what letter does a newly qualified driver has to display for one year after passing the test?
questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an 'R' place (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: EEC was set up in 1957 by six countries
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After the Brexit vote to leave in 2020, there are now 27 EU member states

questions.question: People over 70 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 75% discount
questions.explanation: People over 75 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 50% discount. You will receive a fine of up to £1,000 if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: There are some MPs (Members of Parliament) who do not represent any of the main political parties
questions.explanation: There are a few MPs who do not represent any of the main political parties. They are called 'independents' and usually represent an issue important to their constituency.

questions.question: How many national parks are there in England, Wales and Scotland?
questions.explanation: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What should you do to make a complaint about the Police?
questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body: the Independent Police Complaints Commission in England and Wales, the Police Complaints Commissioner for Scotland or the Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland.

possible_answers.text: Write to the Chief Constable of the Police force
Write a complaint letter to the House of Commons
Complain to the Police force directly

correct_answers: Write to the Chief Constable of the Police force

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955-), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

questions.question: How long did the Romans stay in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years.

questions.question: How old is Big Ben?
questions.explanation: Big Ben, also known as 'Elizabeth Tower', is over 150 years of age.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What must the police officer tell you if you get arrested?
questions.explanation: A Police officer will tell you the reason for your arrest and you will be able to seek legal advice.

possible_answers.text: To put your arms in the air

questions.question: When did Ireland split into 2 countries?
questions.explanation: Ireland became two countries in 1922.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 (can change) member states.

questions.question: When did England win the World Cup?
questions.explanation: Bobby Moore (1941-93) captained the English football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

questions.question: Who led the Labour Government from 2007 to 2010?
questions.explanation: Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister in 2007 and led the Labour Party.

questions.question: Which Castles are in use to this day?
questions.explanation: Castles were built in many places in Britain and Ireland, partly for defence. Today many are in ruins, although some, such as Windsor and Edinburgh, are still in use.

questions.question: How many National Parks are there in the UK?
questions.explanation: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: NATO aims to maintain peace between all of its members
questions.explanation: NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

questions.question: First professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century
questions.explanation: its True. The first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: There are 9 National Parks in the UK
questions.explanation: The UK has a large network of public footpaths in the countryside. There are also many opportunities for mountain biking, mountaineering and hill walking. There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Prime Minister is the head of the Commonwealth
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III at the time of writing) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 member states.

questions.question: Who was the Queen of the Iceni? She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London
questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

possible_answers.text: During Queen Victoria's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen
During Queen Elizabeth's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen

correct_answers: During Queen Victoria's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: If you think someone is trying to persuade you to join an extremist or terrorist cause, who should you notify?
questions.explanation: If you think someone is trying to persuade you to join an extremist or terrorist cause, you should notify your local police force.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How can you look after the environment? (Choose TWO)
questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

possible_answers.text: Shop for products locally as this reduces your carbon footprint
Recycle as much as you can

correct_answers: Shop for products locally as this reduces your carbon footprint
Recycle as much as you can

questions.question: The Blitz is associated which event?
questions.explanation: Despite winning the Battle of Britain, the German air force was able to continue bombing London and other British cities at night-time. This was called the Blitz.

possible_answers.text: The UK and Germany bombing French cities
The UK evacuating troops from Dunkirk

questions.question: In which year was Britain's first woman Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, elected to join the parliament of United Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher was the daughter of a grocer from Grantham in Lincolnshire. She trained as a chemist and lawyer. She was elected as a Conservative MP in 1959 and became a cabinet minister in 1970 as the Secretary of State for Education and Science. In 1975 she was elected as Leader of the Conservative Party and so became Leader of the Opposition.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Civil servants cannot stand for Office
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often is the electoral register updated?
questions.explanation: The electoral register is updated every year in September or October. An electoral registration form is sent to every household and this has to be completed and returned with the names of everyone who is resident in the household and eligible to vote.

questions.question: Women over 30 were allowed to vote as a result of their contribution towards the war effort. Which war was it?
questions.explanation: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: Admiral Nelson died in which battle?
questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. Who did he become?
questions.explanation: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury (see the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Church in Britain today).

questions.question: When did the first Christian communities appear in Britain?
questions.explanation: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

questions.question: When do pubs usually open?
questions.explanation: Public Houses, also known as Pubs, usually open at 11:00 AM, 12:00 PM on Sundays.

questions.question: Who led the Scottish Army during the Battle of Bannockburn?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

questions.question: When did the development of a free press happen?
questions.explanation: From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of the Houses is more important in today's Britain?
questions.explanation: The House of Commons is regarded as the more important of the two chambers in Parliament because its members are democratically elected.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What does the UN aim to do?
questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security.

questions.question: What was the population of the UK in 1801?
questions.explanation: The population of the UK was just 8 million in 1801.

questions.question: When did the Industrial Revolution take place?
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

questions.question: When were films first shown publicly in the UK?
questions.explanation: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular

questions.question: Where did the Jutes come from?
questions.explanation: Britain was invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons. The languages they spoke are the basis of modern-day English.

questions.question: Which TWO buildings were built during the Middle Ages?
questions.explanation: The Middle Ages also saw a change in the type of buildings in Britain. Castles were built in many places in Britain and Ireland, partly for defence. Today many are in ruins, although some, such as Windsor and Edinburgh, are still in use. Great cathedrals - for example, Lincoln Cathedral - were also built, and many of these are still used for worship.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than _____ years old
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

questions.question: The Mousetrap','Jesus Christ Superstar' and 'Evita' are examples of British what?
questions.explanation: They are examples of theatre plays.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How old do you have to be to stand for election as an MP?
questions.explanation: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties

questions.question: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, the English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in which Irish province?
questions.explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders.

questions.question: The UK is a diverse and dynamic nation which welcomes those who want to make a positive contribution to the society
questions.explanation: The UK is a diverse and welcoming country. It welcomes those who want to make a positive contribution to the society

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: It is a criminal offence to owe money to someone and you might be taken to court
questions.explanation: Owing money is a civil offence

questions.question: The Boer War took place in which country of the British Empire?
questions.explanation: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

questions.question: Which Battle is commemorated in the Bayeux Tapestry?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.question: A treaty gave independence to the south of Ireland in 1921
questions.explanation: In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries. The six counties in the north which were mainly Protestant remained part of the UK under the name Northern Ireland. The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.

questions.question: Who was the British scientist who was awarded the Nobel prize for the discovery of the structure of the DNA molecule?
questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime. Francis Crick (1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Members of the European Union can vote in all public UK elections
questions.explanation: Prior to Brexit, adult citizens of other EU states who are resident in the UK could vote in all elections except General Elections. As of 2020, EU citizens' local voting rights have also changed and are now set on individual, per-country basis.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy
questions.explanation: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs from the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

questions.question: The King Charles III's eldest son, Prince William, is also known as?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952, (she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee i.e. 60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. She was married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, King Charles III (previously known as the Prince of Wales) became the sovereign monarch in 2022. His eldest son, heir to the throne, Prince William is the new Prince of Wales.

questions.question: As per 2021 census, what percentage of the England and Wales population identified as Sikh?
questions.explanation: In the 2021 England and Wales census, around 525,000 people from the sampled population of 60 million identified as Sikh. 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (6.5%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often do the ministers meet to discuss important issues?
questions.explanation: Ministers form the cabinet, a committee which usually meets weekly and makes important decisions about government policy. Many of these decisions have to be debated or approved by Parliament.

questions.question: Where can you get help if you can't afford to pay a vet?
questions.explanation: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

questions.question: Which of these are British Overseas Territories?
questions.explanation: There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

possible_answers.text: St Helena and the Isle of Man
The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man

questions.question: What percentage of the workforce are women?
questions.explanation: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce. On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. More women than men study at university.

questions.question: Which country invented Cricket?
questions.explanation: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The most famous Cricket competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

questions.question: What celebrates the end of Ramadan?
questions.explanation: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast.

questions.question: How many Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain between 1870-1914?
questions.explanation: People continued to come to Britain from other parts of the world. For example, between 1870 and 1914, around 120,000 Russian and Polish Jews came to Britain to escape persecution.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Everything found in Hansard is available online
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries and online.

questions.question: On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys
questions.explanation: The Statement is true

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where can you get details about the small claims procedure?
questions.explanation: You can get details about the small claims procedure from your local County Court or Sheriff Court.

questions.question: Who was John Constable?
questions.explanation: John Constable (1776-1837) was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk, Essex border in the east of England.

possible_answers.text: An important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s
A landscape painter, most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the East of England
A very successful Northern Irish portrait painter
A Welsh artist, best known for his engravings and stained glass

correct_answers: A landscape painter, most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the East of England

questions.question: What food is traditionally associated with Wales?
questions.explanation: Welsh cakes - a traditional Welsh snack made from flour, dried fruits and spices, and served either hot or cold.

possible_answers.text: Roast beef, which is served with potatoes, vegetables, Yorkshire puddings

questions.question: Who of the following is associated with the Bonfire Night?
questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: The Domesday Book gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest
questions.explanation: William the Conqueror (the Duke of Normandy) sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who invented the Jet Engine?
questions.explanation: The Jet Engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907-96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

questions.question: What religion did Queen Elizabeth I practise?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I was a Protestant. She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England. Everyone had to attend their local church and there were laws about the type of religious services and the prayers which could be said, but Elizabeth did not ask about people's real beliefs. She succeeded in finding a balance between the views of Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.

questions.question: Who will remain the longest reigning monarch until 9 September 2015?
questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years. Her reign is known as the Victorian Age. On September 9 2015, Queen Elizabeth II will pass the record set by her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria.

questions.question: Which TWO developments are associated with the 'Swinging Sixties'?
questions.explanation: The Swinging Sixties was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland. The position of women in the workplace also improved. It was quite common at the time for employers to ask women to leave their jobs when they got married, but Parliament passed new laws giving women the right to equal pay and made it illegal for employers to discriminate against women because of their gender.

questions.question: Which of these is a British invention/discovery?
questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime. Francis Crick (1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

possible_answers.text: The structure of the DNA molecule

correct_answers: The structure of the DNA molecule

questions.question: When are Pantomimes usually produced?
questions.explanation: One British tradition is the pantomime. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences. One of the traditional characters is the Dame, a woman played by a man. There is often also a pantomime horse or cow played by two actors in the same costume.

questions.question: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to
questions.explanation: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to. It reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God. Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during this festival. In Britain this has to be done in a slaughterhouse.

questions.question: What was the longest British War with France called?
questions.explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years). One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

questions.question: William Orange was asked by Protestants to invade England. This event was later known as what?
questions.explanation: James II's elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament.

questions.question: What did the 'Bill of Rights' confirm?
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

questions.question: Where was Florence Nightingale born?
questions.explanation: Florence Nightingale was born in Italy to English parents in 1820.

questions.question: Which of these gardens is located in Wales?
questions.explanation: Bodnant Garden is in Wales.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence?
questions.explanation: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is an example of a Criminal Offence?
questions.explanation: Examples of criminal laws are - Carrying a weapon: it is a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind, even if it is for self-defence. This includes a gun, a knife or anything that is made or adapted to cause injury; Drugs: selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK; Racial crime: it is a criminal offence to cause harassment, alarm or distress to someone because of their religion or ethnic origin; Selling tobacco: it is illegal to sell tobacco products (for example, cigarettes, cigars, roll-up tobacco) to anyone under the age of 18; Smoking in public places: it is against the law to smoke tobacco products in nearly every enclosed public place in the UK. There are signs displayed to tell you where you cannot smoke; Buying alcohol: it is a criminal offence to sell alcohol to anyone who is under 18 or to buy alcohol for people who are under the age of 18; Drinking in public: some places have alcohol-free zones where you cannot drink in public. The police can also confiscate alcohol or move young people on from public places. You can be fined or arrested.

questions.question: What UK landmark was voted as Britain's favourite view?
questions.explanation: The Lake District is England's largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors. The biggest stretch of water is Windermere. In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain's favourite view.

questions.question: How many people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 due to violence in Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What do the National Insurance Contributions fund?
questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions. The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

questions.question: How many people lost their lives in Northern Ireland in the decades after 1969?
questions.explanation: The 1970s were also a time of serious unrest in Northern Ireland. In 1972, the Northern Ireland Parliament was suspended and Northern Ireland was directly ruled by the UK government. Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What method is used to elect UK MPs?
questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected. The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

questions.question: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC but this was unsuccessful. For how many years did Britain remain separate from the Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

questions.question: Hanukkah is celebrated to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom and it is in November or December for how many days?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The leader of the Opposition appoints senior opposition MPs to be what?
questions.explanation: The leader of the Opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be 'shadow ministers'. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO of these countries are currently in the EU?
questions.explanation: Following a referendum held in the UK on 23 June 2016, the UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. France are Poland are still part of the EU.

questions.question: Christmas Day celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

questions.question: What is the second biggest country in the UK?
questions.explanation: Scotland has the second highest population and area.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The EU was set up by 6 western countries who signed the Treaty of Rome on which date?
questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973.

questions.question: When Queen Anne died, a German, George of Hanover, became the next King of England
questions.explanation: When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next King, because he was Anne's nearest Protestant relative. An attempt by Scottish Jacobites to put James II's son on the throne instead was quickly defeated.

questions.question: Which of these TWO lines from Shakespeare's plays and poems are often still quoted?
questions.explanation: Lines from Shakespeare's plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V); To be or not to be (Hamlet); A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet); All the world's a stage (As You Like It); The darling buds of May (Sonnet 18 'Shall I Compare Thee To a Summer's Day).

possible_answers.text: To be or not to be

correct_answers: To be or not to be

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: People who are self-employed need to pay National Insurance Contributions themselves
questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions.

questions.question: The Swinging Sixties was a period of new ideas about politics, philosophy and science
questions.explanation: he decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as 'the Swinging Sixties'. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. People started to become better off and many bought cars and other consumer goods. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question: In year 1066, William the Conqueror invaded England in which battle?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.question: Which of the following discoveries contributed to the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: What is the Church of England known as in Scotland and the US?
questions.explanation: The official Church of the state is the Church of England is called the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States. It is a Protestant Church.

questions.question: Which countries are in Great Britain?
questions.explanation: Great Britain consists of 3 countries: England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question: What language did the Iron Age people speak?
questions.explanation: Their language was part of the Celtic language family.

questions.question: When did the UK join the EEC?
questions.explanation: West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is able to change the Prime Minister during his/her term?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister can be changed if the MPs in the governing party decide to do so, or if he or she wishes to resign. The Prime Minister usually resigns if his or her party loses a General Election.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What can schools do to raise money?
questions.explanation: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

possible_answers.text: Ask the local council for extra funding

questions.question: Which of Henry VIII's wives were executed?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London. Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

possible_answers.text: Catherine Parr and Anne of Cleves
Catherine of Aragon and Anne Boleyn
Anne of Cleves and Jane Seymour

questions.question: Who led a team to clone a mammal for the first time?
questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep. This has led to further research into the possible use of cloning to preserve endangered species and for medical purposes.

possible_answers.text: Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell

correct_answers: Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell

questions.question: What tells us about how people lived just after the Norman Conquest?
questions.explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: Where was William Shakespeare born?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare (1564-1616) was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

questions.question: What tools did the Bronze age people introduce?
questions.explanation: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkers who made many beautiful objects in bronze and gold, including tools, ornaments and weapons.

questions.question: How many colonies were granted independence in 1947?
questions.explanation: Another aspect of change was self-government for former colonies. In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). Other colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific achieved independence over the next 20 years.

questions.question: The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in a piece of embroidery , known as the Bayeux Tapestry
questions.explanation: The battle of Hastings is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What are TWO responsibilities of members of Parliament (MPs)?
questions.explanation: MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They:; represent everyone in their constituency; ; help to create new laws; ; scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing; ; debate important national issues;

possible_answers.text: Represent only those who voted for them
They represent everyone in their constituency
Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing

correct_answers: They represent everyone in their constituency
Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing

questions.question: Where was Anne Boleyn, the wife of Henry VIII who was accused of taking lovers, executed?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London.

questions.question: What is the percentage of Sikh living in the UK?
questions.explanation: In the 2021 England and Wales census, around 525,000 (0.9%) people from the sampled population of 60 million identified as Sikh. 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (6.5%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

questions.question: Where can you find Crown Jewels?
questions.explanation: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building's history. People can also see the Crown Jewels there.

questions.question: How is the Queen Elizabeth II's husband, Prince Philip, often called?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952, in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. She was married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales) became the sovereign monarch in 2022.

questions.question: What name is given to the official flag that represents the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack.

questions.question: Which TWO describe the Wimbledon Championships?
questions.explanation: Modern tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century. The first tennis club was founded in Leamington Spa in 1872. The most famous tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. It is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only 'Grand Slam' event played on grass.

possible_answers.text: Only 'Grand Slam' event played on grass
Oldest tennis tournament in the world
Only 'Major' tournament held outside the US
Only tennis tournament that Andy Murray won

correct_answers: Only 'Grand Slam' event played on grass
Oldest tennis tournament in the world

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is a good way to support your local community?
questions.explanation: A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

possible_answers.text: Shop for products locally where you can

correct_answers: Shop for products locally where you can

questions.question: What is the geographic position of the UK in Europe?
questions.explanation: The UK is located in the North West of Europe.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

questions.question: When is St Patrick's day?
questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

questions.question: Which charity works to preserve important buildings?
questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust. It aims to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

questions.question: What is the capital of England?
questions.explanation: London is the capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

questions.question: Who became Prime Minister during WWII?
questions.explanation: Hitler invaded Poland and took control of Belgium and the Netherlands. At this time of national crisis, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister.

questions.question: When is Boxing Day?
questions.explanation: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

questions.question: What is the capital of Wales?
questions.explanation: Cardiff is the capital of Wales.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are the most serious civil cases heard in England and Wales?
questions.explanation: More serious civil cases - for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed - are dealt with in the High Court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: Where is the Millennium Stadium located?
questions.explanation: Sporting events take place at major stadiums such as Wembley Stadium in London and the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff.

questions.question: What event is known as the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

questions.question: Which river banks the London eye?
questions.explanation: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall. It was originally built as part of the UK's celebration of the new millennium and continues to be an important part of New Year celebrations.

questions.question: How many years did Charles I try to rule without Parliament?
questions.explanation: For 11 years, Charles I found ways in which to raise money without Parliament's approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.

questions.question: When did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
questions.explanation: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where are the most serious criminal cases in Scotland heard at?
questions.explanation: The most serious cases in Scotland, such as murder, are heard at a High Court with a judge and jury.

questions.question: Clans lost a lot of their power and influence after which event?
questions.explanation: The clans lost a lot of their power and influence after the Battle of Culloden (1746). Chieftains became landlords if they had the favour of the English king, and clansmen became tenants who had to pay for the land they used.

questions.question: Where in Scotland is known as the home of golf?
questions.explanation: Game of golf can be traced back to 15th century Scotland. It is a popular sport played socially as well as professionally. There are public and private golf courses all over the UK. St Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

questions.question: Which of the following was written by Lord Byron?
questions.explanation: She Walks in Beauty is a short poem by Lord Byron

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who gets appointed by local authorities to be the ceremonial leader of the council?
questions.explanation: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.

questions.question: Which country (or colony) did NOT gain its independence from the British Empire in 1947?
questions.explanation: In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). Other colonies in Africa, the Caribbean (e.g. The British West Indies) and the Pacific achieved independence over the next 20 years.

questions.question: What language did the peasants speak after the Norman conquest?
questions.explanation: The Middle Ages saw the development of a national culture and identity. After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

questions.question: EastEnders and Coronation Street are popular soap operas.
questions.explanation: British television shows a wide variety of programmes. Popular programmes include regular soap operas such as Coronation Street and EastEnders.

questions.question: Which TWO are used in making an Ulster fry?
questions.explanation: Ulster fry - a fried meal with bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding, white pudding, tomatoes, mushrooms, soda bread and potato bread.

questions.question: In 1998, what was the estimated population of the UK?
questions.explanation: (1951, 50 million), (1998, 57 million), (2005, Just under 60 million), (2010, Just over 62 million)

questions.question: Mary Stuart, often now called Mary Queen of Scots was a Protestant
questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called 'Mary, Queen of Scots') was a Catholic. She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO are some of the key roles of Governors and school boards?
questions.explanation: Governors and school boards have an important part to play in raising school standards. They have three key roles: setting the strategic direction of the school; ensuring accountability; monitoring and evaluating school performance.

questions.question: Which of the following flowers represents England?
questions.explanation: The national flower of England is the Rose.

questions.question: Which of these is a famous classical music event in the UK?
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of classical music (orchestral or solo instrumental and nowadays may feature non-classical music) that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London.

questions.question: When did the Enlightenment happen?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.

questions.question: What is the period after the Norman Conquest up until 1485 called?
questions.explanation: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages or the medieval period. It was a time of almost constant war.

questions.question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: A shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland. A rose is associated with England, a thistle with Scotland and a daffodil with Wales.

questions.question: Where did the canal builders come from in the middle ages?
questions.explanation: People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question: What percentage of the total population lives in England?
questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

questions.question: Who wrote music for King George I?
questions.explanation: The German-born composer George Frideric Handel (1695-1759) spent many years in the UK and became a British citizen in 1727. He wrote the Water Music for King George I and Music for the Royal Fireworks for his son, George II.

questions.question: When did Britain recognise the American colonies' independence?
questions.explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.

questions.question: Which TWO are located in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Loch Lomond and the Edinburgh Castle are located in Scotland.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many volunteers is The National Trust run by?
questions.explanation: The National Trust was set up by just 3 volunteers. Now over 61,000 people help to run it.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities
questions.explanation: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Many of the painters working in Britain in the 16th and 17th centuries were from abroad
questions.explanation: Many of the painters working in Britain in the 16th and 17th centuries were from abroad - for example, Hans Holbein and Sir Anthony Van Dyck.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What will happen to any driver who has either taken more than the acceptable quantity of alcohol or refused to take the test?
questions.explanation: If you are found driving while exceeding the alcohol limit you will be arrested.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Women over 21 were allowed to vote for the first time in 1969
questions.explanation: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

questions.question: Who wrote the Canterbury Tales?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage.

questions.question: When did the Wars of the Roses end with the Battle of Bosworth?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

questions.question: What kind of battle was the Battle of Britain (1940)?
questions.explanation: The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called 'the Battle of Britain', in the summer of 1940. The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain were the Spitfire and the Hurricane - which were designed and built in Britain.

questions.question: Mince pies are traditionally eaten on which day?
questions.explanation: Christmas is celebrated in a traditional way. People usually spend the day at home and eat a special meal, which often includes roast turkey, Christmas pudding and mince pies.

questions.question: David Hockney was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s
questions.explanation: David Hockney (1937-) was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s and continues to be influential today.

questions.question: Which TWO are notable British artists?
questions.explanation: Joseph Turner (1775-1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting. John Constable (1776-1837) was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk, Essex border in the east of England.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What are elected members of the National Assembly of Wales known as?
questions.explanation: In Wales the elected members, known as AMs, meet in the Welsh Assembly in the Senedd in Cardiff Bay

questions.question: In 1745, who was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army?
questions.explanation: In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army. Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746. Charles escaped back to Europe.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Northern Ireland has its own banknotes which are valid everywhere in the UK
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Wales and Scotland use a system called 'individual registration'.All those entitled to vote must complete their own registration forms
questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland a system called 'individual registration' operates and all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form. Once registered, people stay on the register provided their personal details do not change.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the monarch's ceremonial role?
questions.explanation: The Monarch has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year.

possible_answers.text: Travelling abroad for banquets and to negotiate with foreign dignitaries
