questions.question: Under which king did the people unite to defeat the Vikings?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

questions.question: What did the first farmers build in Britain?
questions.explanation: The first farmers built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

questions.question: Which operas were written by Gilbert and Sullivan?
questions.explanation: Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

questions.question: What were the working conditions like during the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: Working conditions during the Industrial Revolution were very poor. There were no laws to protect employees, who were often forced to work long hours in dangerous situations. Children also worked and were treated in the same way as adults.

questions.question: Which of these is not a valid bank note?
questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

questions.question: Who is known as William the Conqueror?
questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

questions.question: When were the last Welsh rebellions defeated?
questions.explanation: By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.

questions.question: The Glorious Revolution was called the 'Glorious revolution' because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament
questions.explanation: The Glorious Revolution was called the 'Glorious revolution' because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament

questions.question: Which TWO are compulsory in the UK if you own an old car?
questions.explanation: It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old or without car insurance.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these is a charity working with animals?
questions.explanation: People's Dispensary for Sick Animals (PDSA)is the charity that works with animals

questions.question: Which of these names was Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn's child's name?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead?
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III at the time of writing) has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Monarch makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

questions.question: Until what time do people play jokes on one another on April Fool's Day?
questions.explanation: April Fool's Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

questions.question: In which UK country can you find the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe?
questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question: In the middle of the 19th century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine
questions.explanation: In the middle of the 19th century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation. Another million and a half left Ireland.

questions.question: What are the parliaments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also known as?
questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. These powers are also known as devolved administrations.

questions.question: Select TWO famous Paralympians
questions.explanation: Baroness Tanni-Grey Thompson (1969-) is an athlete who uses a wheelchair and won 16 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold medals, in races over five Paralympic Games. She won the London Marathon six times and broke a total of 30 world records. Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What does the abbreviation PTA stand for?
questions.explanation: Sometimes school events are organised by parent-teacher associations (PTAs)

questions.question: Which TWO of these are associated with Sir Francis Drake?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition. His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.

questions.question: Which TWO major welfare changes were introduced between 1945 and 1950?
questions.explanation: In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS). A national system of benefits was also introduced to provide 'social security', so that the population would be protected from the 'cradle to the grave'.

possible_answers.text: A social security system for everyone

correct_answers: A social security system for everyone

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: Democracy; The rule of law; Individual liberty; Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs; Participation in community life.

questions.question: Which comedy double act by Nick Park won many Oscars?
questions.explanation: Nick Park, who has won four Oscars for his animated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 (can change) member states.

questions.question: When is Christmas Eve?
questions.explanation: Christmas Day is on the 25th of December. Christmas Eve is the day before that which is the 24th of December.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the system that automatically deducts tax called?
questions.explanation: This system that deducts tax automatically is called 'Pay As You Earn', also known as PAYE.

questions.question: Where did the ancestors of the first farmers come from?
questions.explanation: The first farmers came to Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

questions.question: Where is Loch Lomond located?
questions.explanation: Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of freshwater in mainland Britain and probably the best-known part of the park. It is located in Scotland.

questions.question: When were films first shown in the UK?
questions.explanation: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular.

questions.question: When did the Parliament begin developing into the institution it is now?
questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages, Parliament began to develop into the institution it is today. Its origins can be traced to the king's council of advisers, which included important noblemen and the leaders of the Church.

questions.question: Who set up the first formal anti-slavery campaigns?
questions.explanation: The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.

questions.question: What type of painter was Joseph Turner?
questions.explanation: Joseph Turner (1775-1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting.

questions.question: When was the Magna Carta established?
questions.explanation: There were few formal limits to the king's power until 1215. In that year, King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king's power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

questions.question: What is the Mercury Music Prize awarded for?
questions.explanation: The Mercury Music Prize is awarded each September for the best album from the UK and Ireland. The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

possible_answers.text: The best music producer in the UK and Ireland
The best classical song in the UK and Ireland
The best song in the UK and Ireland
The best album from the UK and Ireland

correct_answers: The best album from the UK and Ireland

questions.question: What percentage of the total population lives in Scotland?
questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who should you write to if you wish to make a complaint about the Police?
questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does the Scottish Parliament have?
questions.explanation: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation. The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters which are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament. The matters on which the Scottish Parliament can legislate include: civil and criminal law, health, education, planning, additional tax-raising powers.

questions.question: When was Charles I executed?
questions.explanation: The king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

questions.question: What kind of event is The Wimbledon Championship?
questions.explanation: Tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century. The first tennis club was founded in Leamington Spa in 1872. The most famous tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. It is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only 'Grand Slam' event played on grass.

questions.question: Who wrote the popular operas HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and the Mikado?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Local councils, in the UK, are often called local authorities
questions.explanation: The statement is correct

questions.question: James Watt was famous for his work on what?
questions.explanation: James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 established the idea that the British Empire is a force for good
questions.explanation: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers. The Boers fought fiercely and the war went on for over three years. Many died in the fighting and many more from disease. There was some public sympathy for the Boers and people began to question whether the Empire could continue.

questions.question: Who is the author of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'?
questions.explanation: Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. His best-known works include Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and George's Marvellous Medicine.

questions.question: In which year did John Logie Baird make the first TV broadcast between Glasgow and London?
questions.explanation: The television was developed by Scotsman John Logie Baird (1888-1946) in the 1920s. In 1932 he made the first television broadcast between London and Glasgow.

questions.question: Who founded a monastery on the Island of Iona?
questions.explanation: Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland, and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Which stories are associated with Geoffrey Chaucer?
questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

questions.question: The BBC is controlled by the UK government
questions.explanation: The BBC is the largest broadcaster in the world. It is the only wholly state-funded media organisation that is independent of government. Other UK channels are primarily funded through advertisements and subscriptions.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The UK government has used the power to suspend the Northern Ireland Assembly
questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is also a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

questions.question: Where was Robert Burns from?
questions.explanation: Robert Burns is a famous Scottish Poet

questions.question: Where did the engineers come from in the middle ages?
questions.explanation: People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Engineers came from Germany.

questions.question: Which party did Margaret Thatcher belong to?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, Britain's first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.question: Who is a Patron St of Scotland?
questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

questions.question: Who lost a lot of their power after the Battle of Culloden in 1746?
questions.explanation: The clans lost a lot of their power and influence after Culloden. Chieftains became landlords if they had the favour of the English king, and clansmen became tenants who had to pay for the land they used.

questions.question: What medal was introduced during the Crimean War?
questions.explanation: Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during the Crimean war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

questions.question: What is the day before Lent called?
questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day.

questions.question: What were the refugees that came from France called?
questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

questions.question: When did the first professional football clubs form?
questions.explanation: Football is the UK's most popular sport. It has a long history in the UK and the first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

questions.question: What is 'Snowdon'?
questions.explanation: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. It covers an area of 838 square miles (2,170 square kilometres). Its most well-known landmark is Snowdon, which is the highest mountain in Wales.

questions.question: Where is the Cenotaph located?
questions.explanation: At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

questions.question: What created The Kingdom of Great Britain in 1707?
questions.explanation: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

possible_answers.text: The act of Government of Wales

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The UN was set up straight after the First World War. It now has over 190 countries as members
questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security. There are 15 members on the UN Security Council, which recommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace. The UK is one of five permanent members of the Security Council.

questions.question: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Choose TWO examples of a civil law offence
questions.explanation: Examples of civil laws are - Housing law: this includes disputes between landlords and tenants over issues such as repairs and eviction; Consumer rights: an example of this is a dispute about faulty goods or services; Employment law: these cases include disputes over wages and cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace; Debt: people might be taken to court if they owe money to someone.

possible_answers.text: Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

correct_answers: Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

questions.question: In what year was Germany comprehensively defeated by the Allies during the WWII?
questions.explanation: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germany in May 1945.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be _____ , so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints
questions.explanation: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be balanced, so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints.

questions.question: Which of these athletes is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming?
questions.explanation: Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games.

questions.question: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait
questions.explanation: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the Former Republic of Yugoslavia. Since 2000, British armed forces have been engaged in the global fight against international terrorism and against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.

questions.question: Which novel is the satirical novelist Evelyn Waugh best known for?
questions.explanation: Evelyn Waugh (1903-66) wrote satirical novels, including Decline and Fall and Scoop. He is perhaps best known for Brideshead Revisited.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO are major political parties in the UK?
questions.explanation: The Conservative Party, the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats are big political parties

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Complaints against the Police can only be made by writing to the Police Complaints Commissioner
questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body: the Independent Police Complaints Commission in England and Wales, the Police Complaints Commissioner for Scotland or the Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The UK government hasn't used the power to suspend the Northern Ireland Assembly
questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is also a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

questions.question: Who built the Tower of London?
questions.explanation: The Tower of London was built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

questions.question: Where is the best preserved prehistoric village 'Skara Brae on Orkney' located?
questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

questions.question: What do you require by law to watch TV using any medium?
questions.explanation: If you watch or record live TV programmes on any channel, or download or watch BBC programmes on BBC iPlayer on any digital devices, you need to be covered by a TV Licence.

questions.question: Who became the first Briton to win the Tour de France?
questions.explanation: Bradley Wiggins (1980-) is a cyclist. In 2012, he became the first Briton to win the Tour de France. He has won seven Olympic medals, including gold medals in the 2004, 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games.

questions.question: How many years did Mary, the Queen of Scots spend in prison?
questions.explanation: Mary was Elizabeth I's cousin and hoped that Elizabeth might help her, but Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years. Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Scottish Parliament was formed in 1998 and sits in Edinburgh
questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament was formed in 1999.

questions.question: Who requested to write The Domesday book?
questions.explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: Since the Middle Ages, when did the first Jews come to Britain to settle in London?
questions.explanation: The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.

questions.question: The British constitution is described as 'unwritten'
questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government. Our most important institutions have developed over hundreds of years.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO roles are school governors and school boards responsible for?
questions.explanation: Governors and school boards have an important part to play in raising school standards. They have three key roles: setting the strategic direction of the school, ensuring accountability, monitoring and evaluating school performance.

possible_answers.text: Setting the strategic direction of the school

correct_answers: Setting the strategic direction of the school

questions.question: What is the origin of Parliament?
questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages, Parliament began to develop into the institution it is today. Its origins can be traced to the king's council of advisers, which included important noblemen and the leaders of the Church.

questions.question: There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay for a vet
questions.explanation: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What are TWO of the roles of the House of Lords?
questions.explanation: The House of Lords can suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by MPs. It checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose. It also holds the government to account to make sure that it is working in the best interests of the people.

possible_answers.text: Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing
Check laws that have been passed to ensure that they are fit for purpose
Suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by the MPs

correct_answers: Check laws that have been passed to ensure that they are fit for purpose
Suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by the MPs

questions.question: Who was made a Dame of the British Empire in 2000?
questions.explanation: Born in Manchester, Mary Peters moved to Northern Ireland as a child. She was a talented athlete who won an Olympic gold medal in the pentathlon in 1972. After this, she raised money for local athletics and became the team manager for the women's British Olympic team. She continues to promote sport and tourism in Northern Ireland and was made a Dame of the British Empire in 2000 in recognition of her work.

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: Which TWO will you be agreeing with when applying to become a permanent resident?
questions.explanation: You should accept all responsibilities that come with permanent residency and fundamental principles of British life

possible_answers.text: To accept the responsibilities which come with 'Settlement'
To remain in the UK forever
To respect the law, values and traditions of the UK

correct_answers: To accept the responsibilities which come with 'Settlement'
To respect the law, values and traditions of the UK

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with the Elizabethan period in England?
questions.explanation: The Elizabethan period in England was a time of growing patriotism: a feeling of pride in being English. The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO of the following are examples of criminal law?
questions.explanation: Examples of criminal laws are: Carrying a weapon; Selling or buying illegal drugs; Racial crime; Selling tobacco; Smoking in public places; Buying alcohol; Drinking in public.

possible_answers.text: Selling tobacco to anyone under the age of 18

correct_answers: Selling tobacco to anyone under the age of 18

questions.question: Which king defeated the Vikings?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings. Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain - especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who receives ambassadors and high commissioners, entertains visiting heads of state and makes state visits overseas in support of diplomatic and economic relationships with other countries?
questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) represents the UK to the rest of the world. He receives foreign ambassadors and high commissioners, entertains visiting heads of state, and makes state visits overseas in support of diplomatic and economic relationships with other countries.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service
questions.explanation: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.

questions.question: What is known as 'canvassing'?
questions.explanation: Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates - for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support.

possible_answers.text: Persuade people to vote for the party you represent
Filling in the ballot paper for those who cannot do it themselves

correct_answers: Persuade people to vote for the party you represent

questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
questions.question: What is your responsibility as UK citizen? Select TWO answers.
questions.explanation: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities include: to obey and respect the law; to be aware of the rights of others and respect those rights; to treat others with fairness; to behave responsibly; to help and protect your family; to respect and preserve the environment; to treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, religion, age, disability, class or sexual orientation; to work to provide for yourself and your family; to help others; to vote in local and national government elections.

possible_answers.text: To vote in local and national government elections
To go to your local pub
To help and protect your family

correct_answers: To vote in local and national government elections
To help and protect your family

questions.question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
questions.explanation: The United Kingdom consists of Wales,England,Scotland and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: When is Boxing Day?
questions.explanation: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who appoints 'Life peers'?
questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.question: Where did Charles II hide to escape from Cromwell's army?
questions.explanation: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

questions.question: Which General remains a controversial figure in Ireland?
questions.explanation: Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament in Ireland but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is MP's responsibility?
questions.explanation: MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They: represent everyone in their constituency, help to create new laws, scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing, debate important national issues.

possible_answers.text: To represent everyone in their constituency
To represent everyone in the UK
To get as many votes as possible

correct_answers: To represent everyone in their constituency

questions.question: What was 'Shampooing' when it was first introduced?
questions.explanation: Mahomet and his wife also introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

possible_answers.text: The Indian art of head massage

correct_answers: The Indian art of head massage

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many AMs does the Welsh government have?
questions.explanation: The Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales. The National Assembly (Senedd) consists of 60 elected Assembly members (AMs) and elections are held every four years using a form of proportional representation. Members can speak in either Welsh or English and all of the Assembly’s publications are in both languages.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where do you have to be registered to be able to vote?
questions.explanation: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register.

questions.question: Who designed the Dumfries House in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In the 18th century, simpler designs became popular. The Scottish architect Robert Adam influenced the development of architecture in the UK, Europe and America. He designed the inside decoration as well as the building itself in great houses such as Dumfries House in Scotland. His ideas influenced architects in cities such as Bath, where the Royal Crescent was built.

questions.question: How many crosses does the Union flag have?
questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO are part of the Government?
questions.explanation: In the UK, there are several different parts of government. The main ones are: the monarchy, Parliament (the House of Commons and the House of Lords), the Prime Minister, the cabinet, the judiciary (courts) ,the police, the civil service, local government.

questions.question: What was the name of plague that killed one third of the population of England in 1348?
questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague called 'the Black Death', came to Britain.

questions.question: Names of places, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe come from which language?
questions.explanation: Many places names, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages

questions.question: What profession was Florence Nightingale famous for?
questions.explanation: At the age of 31, Florence Nightingale trained as a nurse in Germany. In 1854, she went to Turkey and worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War.

questions.question: Which ship was one of the first to circumnavigate the world?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition. His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.

questions.question: What country is Swansea in?
questions.explanation: Swansea is a Welsh city.

questions.question: Who led a team of scientists to develop the atomic bomb?
questions.explanation: Scientists led by Ernest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to 'split the atom' and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

questions.question: The Restoration' refers to the reestablishment of Roman Catholicism
questions.explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland. Charles II made it clear that he had 'no wish to go on his travels again'. There was a restoration of the monarchy.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: In Youth Courts, the name or photographs of the accused young person can be published in newspapers or used by the media
questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which TWO principles are included in the European Convention on Human Rights?
questions.explanation: Some of the principles included in the European Convention on Human Rights are: right to life; prohibition of torture; prohibition of slavery and forced labour; right to liberty and security; right to a fair trial; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of expression (speech).

questions.question: Rudyard Kipling was born in South Africa
questions.explanation: Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. He wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

questions.question: When King Charles I tried to impose a revised Prayer Book on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland, which TWO events occurred?
questions.explanation: Charles I wanted the worship of the Church of England to include more ceremony and introduced a revised Prayer Book. He tried to impose this Prayer Book on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland and this led to serious unrest. A Scottish army was formed and Charles could not find the money he needed for his own army without the help of Parliament. In 1640, he recalled Parliament to ask it for funds. Many in Parliament were Puritans, a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship. They did not agree with the king's religious views and disliked his reforms of the Church of England. Parliament refused to give the king the money he asked for, even after the Scottish army invaded England.

possible_answers.text: A Scottish army was formed and it invaded England
King Charles I formed his own army without asking for help from Parliament
Parliament only gave the money to King Charles when the Scottish army invaded England
King Charles I recalled Parliament to ask it for funds to form his own army

correct_answers: A Scottish army was formed and it invaded England
King Charles I recalled Parliament to ask it for funds to form his own army

questions.question: Which TWO are correct about Mary Stuart?
questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called 'Mary, Queen of Scots') was a Catholic. She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen. Much of her childhood was spent in France. When she returned to Scotland, she was the centre of a power struggle between different groups. When her husband was murdered, Mary was suspected of involvement and fled to England. She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland. Mary was Elizabeth I's cousin and hoped that Elizabeth might help her, but Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years. Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

possible_answers.text: She died of the Black Death
She was only a week old when she became queen
She spent much of her childhood in France

correct_answers: She was only a week old when she became queen
She spent much of her childhood in France

questions.question: The 39 steps was directed by David Lean in 1980
questions.explanation: The 39 Steps (1935), directed by Alfred Hitchcock

questions.question: What celebration takes place on the 25th of December each year?
questions.explanation: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How often are the General Elections held?
questions.explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

questions.question: How long is the Bayeux Tapestry?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry which is 70 meters long.

questions.question: Who invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982?
questions.explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic.

questions.question: Who first introduced James Bond?
questions.explanation: Ian Fleming's books introduced James Bond.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who is responsible for the economy?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments. These include: Chancellor of the Exchequer: responsible for the economy; Home Secretary:responsible for crime, policing and immigration; Foreign Secretary: responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries; other ministers (called 'Secretaries of State') are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

questions.question: What was an important English export in the Middle Ages?
questions.explanation: English wool became a very important export in the middle ages. People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

questions.question: Who sat in the House of Commons in the Middle Ages?
questions.explanation: In the middle ages, the nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Where can you find a solicitor in the UK?
questions.explanation: Solicitors are trained lawyers who give advice on legal matters. They take action for their clients and represent them in court. The Citizens Advice Bureau can give you names of local solicitors and which areas of law they specialise in. You can also get this information from the Law Society.

possible_answers.text: Paying expensive Law firms to find one
Go to one of the Youth Courts

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
questions.explanation: A jury is made up of members of the public chosen at random from the local electoral register (see The Electoral Register). In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

questions.question: The Commonwealth is made up of countries which were once part of the British Empire only
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

questions.question: During the civil war of 1455, what colour rose was the symbol of the House of Lancaster?
questions.explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous British fashion designers?
questions.explanation: Britain has produced many great designers, from Thomas Chippendale (who designed furniture in the 18th century) to Clarice Cliff (who designed Art Deco ceramics) to Sir Terence Conran (a 20th-century interior designer). Leading fashion designers of recent years include Mary Quant, Alexander McQueen and Vivienne Westwood.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Which of these is correct?
questions.explanation: Rape in a romantic relationship and marriage is considered Marital Rape. This includes forced sex and sexual assault between spouses. It is an offense.

possible_answers.text: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including her husband, can be charged with rape
Any man who forces a woman to have sex, excluding her husband, can be charged with rape

correct_answers: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including her husband, can be charged with rape

questions.question: In 1982, which country invaded the Falklands prompting UK to send its naval force in defense?
questions.explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic. A naval task force was sent from the UK and military action led to the recovery of the islands.

questions.question: What service does the TV licence pay for?
questions.explanation: The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC).

questions.question: Who directed the British movie the Belles of St Trinian's in 1954?
questions.explanation: The Belles of St Trinian's (1954) was directed by Frank Launder

questions.question: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explanation: Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland, and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: How many ski centres are there in Scotland?
questions.explanation: Skiing is increasingly popular in the UK. Many people go abroad to ski and there are also dry ski slopes throughout the UK. Skiing on snow may also be possible during the winter. There are five ski centres in Scotland, as well as Europe's longest dry ski slope near Edinburgh.

questions.question: Which TWO are 20th century British inventions?
questions.explanation: Britain and France developed Concorde, the world's only supersonic passenger aircraft. It first flew in 1969 and began carrying passengers in 1976. Concorde was retired from service in 2003. The television was developed by Scotsman John Logie Baird in the 1920s. In 1932 he made the first television broadcast between London and Glasgow.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: When walking your dog in a public place, what must you ensure?
questions.explanation: A lot of people in the UK have pets such as cats or dogs. They might have them for company or because they enjoy looking after them. It is against the law to treat a pet cruelly or to neglect it. All dogs in public places must wear a collar showing the name and address of the owner. The owner is responsible for keeping the dog under control and for cleaning up after the animal in a public place.

possible_answers.text: That your dog wears a special dog coat
That your dog never strays more than 3 metres away from you
That your dog does not come into contact with other dogs
That your dog wears a collar showing the name and address of the owner

correct_answers: That your dog wears a collar showing the name and address of the owner

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Arranged marriages are allowed in the UK
questions.explanation: A marriage should be entered into with the full and free consent of both people involved. Arranged marriages, where both parties agree to the marriage, are acceptable in the UK.

questions.question: What lead the American colonies to declare their independence?
questions.explanation: By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America. The colonies were wealthy and largely in control of their own affairs. Many of the colonist families had originally gone to North America in order to have religious freedom. They were well educated and interested in ideas of liberty. The British government wanted to tax the colonies.

possible_answers.text: The UK not providing enough health care
The UK not sending enough money
The UK wanting to tax the colonies
The UK wanting to stop the slave trade

correct_answers: The UK wanting to tax the colonies

questions.question: What did Sir Frank Whittle invent in the 1930s?
questions.explanation: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907-96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

questions.question: Where is Tate Britain and Tate Modern located?
questions.explanation: Works by British and international artists are displayed in galleries across the UK. Some of the most well-known galleries are The National Gallery, Tate Britain and Tate Modern in London, the National Museum in Cardiff, and the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh.

questions.question: For how long did England remain a republic?
questions.explanation: Britain had been a republic for 11 years.

questions.question: Where was one of the Anglo Saxon kings buried with treasure and armour?
questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth. Scotland and Wales remained free of Anglo Saxon rule.

questions.question: When did the Glorious Revolution happen?
questions.explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

questions.question: Who designed the Cenotaph?
questions.explanation: Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen and many others.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What service can you use to find a lawyer or a solicitor?
questions.explanation: The Citizens Advice Bureau can give you names of local solicitors and which areas of law they specialise in. You can also get this information from the Law Society.

questions.question: What is the longest distance on the mainland in the UK?
questions.explanation: The longest distance on the mainland is from John O'Groats on the north coast of Scotland to Land's End in the south-west corner of England. It is about 870 miles (approximately 1,400 kilometres).

questions.question: Haggis is a traditional food of which country?
questions.explanation: Scotland's food is Haggis - a sheep's stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: Who appoints the local Chief Constable?
questions.explanation: PCCs (Police and Crime Commissioners) set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the Chief Constable.

questions.question: Who took the title 'King of Ireland'?
questions.explanation: Henry VII and Henry VIII had extended English control outside the Pale. Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland' and English laws were introduced.

questions.question: Who was Robert Burns?
questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: The Council of Europe has no power to make laws
questions.explanation: The Council of Europe is separate from the EU. It has 47 member countries, including the UK, and is responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries. It has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, the most well-known of which is the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, usually called the European Convention on Human Rights.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

possible_answers.text: Northern Ireland makes up 4% of the total population
England makes up 83% of the total population
Wales makes up 6% of the total population
Scotland makes up 8% of the total population

correct_answers: Scotland makes up 8% of the total population

questions.question: What percentage of the UK population lives in England?
questions.explanation: England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

questions.question: The people of which age made the first coins to be minted in Britain?
questions.explanation: The people of the Iron Age had a sophisticated culture and economy. They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings. This marks the beginnings of British history.

questions.question: As per 2021 census, what is the percentage of Muslims living in England and Wales?
questions.explanation: Islam is the second largest religion in the United Kingdom. The 2021 Census results released so far show a population of 3,868,133 (6.5%) in England and Wales (from a total sampled 60 million). 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

questions.question: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes valid everywhere in the UK
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

questions.question: Who governs the Church of Scotland?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

questions.question: In what year was there a revolution in France which led to a war with Britain?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, Britain fought a number of wars with France. In 1789, there was a revolution in France and the new French government soon declared war on Britain. Napoleon, who became Emperor of France, continued the war.

questions.question: Which language was spoken by people during the Iron Age?
questions.explanation: Most Iron age people were farmers, craft workers or warriors. The language they spoke was part of the Celtic language family.

questions.question: What do the Brit Awards celebrate?
questions.explanation: The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

questions.question: When did the English settlers first begin to colonise the eastern coast of America?
questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. This colonisation, particularly by people who disagreed with the religious views of the next two kings, greatly increased in the next century.

questions.question: Which of these is a Crown Dependency of the UK and not a part of it?
questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
questions.question: What is the judiciary responsible for?
questions.explanation: Judges, who are together called 'the judiciary', are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

possible_answers.text: Deciding whether a person is guilty

questions.question: Why was Mary known as 'Bloody Mary'?
questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

possible_answers.text: She put her sister in prison

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: Which TWO are British Overseas territories?
unique_questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

unique_questions.question: What Palace was a cast-iron and plate-glass building originally erected in Hyde Park, London, England, to house the Great Exhibition of 1851?
unique_questions.explanation: British industry led the world in the 19th century. The UK produced more than half of the world's iron, coal and cotton cloth. The UK also became a centre for financial services, including insurance and banking. In 1851, the Great Exhibition opened in Hyde Park in the Crystal Palace, a huge building made of steel and glass. Exhibits ranged from huge machines to handmade goods. Countries from all over the world showed their goods but most of the objects were made in Britain.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The UK government has used the power to suspend the Northern Ireland Assembly
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is also a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

unique_questions.question: Which Two British film actors have recently won Oscars?
unique_questions.explanation: Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What is not a fundamental principle of British life?
unique_questions.explanation: Driving a car is NOT one of the fundamental principles of British life

unique_questions.question: When did the first Christian communities appear in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

unique_questions.question: Which charity works to preserve important buildings?
unique_questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust. It aims to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

unique_questions.question: Which flower is associated with England?
unique_questions.explanation: A rose is the flower associated with England.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The United Kingdom consists of Wales,England,Scotland and Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Where was Robert Burns from?
unique_questions.explanation: Robert Burns is a famous Scottish Poet

unique_questions.question: Which flag has a white cross on a blue background?
unique_questions.explanation: Scottish flag has a white cross on a blue background because St Andrew was the Patron Saint of Scotland.

unique_questions.question: What is the capital of England?
unique_questions.explanation: London is the capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

unique_questions.question: When is St David's day?
unique_questions.explanation: St David's day is on the 1st of March. He is a Patron St of Wales.

unique_questions.question: When is Christmas Eve?
unique_questions.explanation: Christmas Day is on the 25th of December. Christmas Eve is the day before that which is the 24th of December.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first Briton to win the Olympic gold medal in the 10,000 meters?
unique_questions.explanation: Mo Farah was the first British runner to win the gold medal in the 10 km.

unique_questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
unique_questions.explanation: The Chartists demanded the vote for the working classes and other people without property.

possible_answers.text: The right to vote for the 21 year olds
The right to vote for the working class
The right to vote for the women
The right to vote for the 18 year olds

correct_answers: The right to vote for the working class

unique_questions.question: What created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: The Act of Union of 1800 created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Where is the Cenotaph located?
unique_questions.explanation: The Cenotaph can be visited in London in Whitehall.

unique_questions.question: Which of these is a famous classical music event in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of classical music (orchestral or solo instrumental and nowadays may feature non-classical music) that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London.

unique_questions.question: Roast beef is a traditional food of which country?
unique_questions.explanation: Roast beef, which is served with potatoes is an example of English traditional food.

unique_questions.question: Which of these UK landmarks is in Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. It covers an area of 838 square miles. Its most well-known landmark is Snowdon, which is the highest mountain in Wales.

unique_questions.question: Who built the Tower of London?
unique_questions.explanation: The Tower of London was built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

unique_questions.question: Who was Queen Elizabeth II married to?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952, (she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee i.e. 60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. She was married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, King Charles III (previously known as the Prince of Wales) became the sovereign monarch in 2022. His eldest son, heir to the throne, Prince William is the new Prince of Wales.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who appoints 'Life peers'?
unique_questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

unique_questions.question: Hadrian's Wall is a popular UNESCO World Heritage Site
unique_questions.explanation: Parts of Hadrian's Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen. It is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.

unique_questions.question: Who was Henry Purcell?
unique_questions.explanation: Henry Purcell (1659-95) was the organist at Westminster Abbey. He wrote church music and operas.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What do you need to apply for UK citizenship?
unique_questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to: speak and read English; have a good understanding of life in the UK.

possible_answers.text: Be able to use computers in English

unique_questions.question: When did people learn how to make bronze?
unique_questions.explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze

unique_questions.question: Where did the people of the Bronze Age bury their dead?
unique_questions.explanation: People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

unique_questions.question: How long did the Romans stay in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years.

unique_questions.question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
unique_questions.explanation: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia.

unique_questions.question: Who became Prime Minister during WWII?
unique_questions.explanation: Hitler invaded Poland and took control of Belgium and the Netherlands. At this time of national crisis, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister.

unique_questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
unique_questions.explanation: World Wide Web was invented by Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955-) who is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

unique_questions.question: What was the population of the UK in 1901?
unique_questions.explanation: The population of the UK was 40 million in 1901.

unique_questions.question: What is the Church of England known as in Scotland and the US?
unique_questions.explanation: The official Church of the state is the Church of England is called the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States. It is a Protestant Church.

unique_questions.question: What is known as Lent?
unique_questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent.

unique_questions.question: Who won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Steve Redgrave won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain's greatest Olympians.

unique_questions.question: Where in Scotland is known as the home of golf?
unique_questions.explanation: St Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

unique_questions.question: Where does the Fringe take place?
unique_questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Festival takes place in Edinburgh, Scotland, every summer. The most well-known is the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, also known as the Fringe.

unique_questions.question: What does the TV licence money pay for?
unique_questions.explanation: The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation also known as the BBC.

unique_questions.question: When do pubs usually open?
unique_questions.explanation: Public Houses, also known as Pubs, usually open at 11:00 AM, 12:00 PM on Sundays.

unique_questions.question: How old is Big Ben?
unique_questions.explanation: Big Ben, also known as 'Elizabeth Tower', is over 150 years of age.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the monarch's ceremonial role?
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year.

possible_answers.text: Travelling abroad for banquets and to negotiate with foreign dignitaries

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where does the Prime Minister reside?
unique_questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What must the police officer tell you if you get arrested?
unique_questions.explanation: A Police officer will tell you the reason for your arrest and you will be able to seek legal advice.

possible_answers.text: To put your arms in the air

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the money limit for the small claims procedure in England and Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the system that automatically deducts tax called?
unique_questions.explanation: This system that deducts tax automatically is called 'Pay As You Earn', also known as PAYE.

unique_questions.question: What did the 'Bill of Rights' confirm?
unique_questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What is the fundamental principle of British life?
unique_questions.explanation: The rule of law is one of the fundamental principles of British Life.

unique_questions.question: Which countries are in Great Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: Great Britain consists of 3 countries: England, Wales and Scotland.

unique_questions.question: Where did the ancestors of the first farmers come from?
unique_questions.explanation: The first farmers came to Britain 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

unique_questions.question: What language did the Iron Age people speak?
unique_questions.explanation: Their language was part of the Celtic language family.

unique_questions.question: When did the Roman army leave Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

unique_questions.question: Under which king did the people unite to defeat the Vikings?
unique_questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

unique_questions.question: What proportion of the population died because of the Black Death?
unique_questions.explanation: One third of the population of England and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales died because of the Black Death.

unique_questions.question: Where did the engineers come from in the middle ages?

unique_questions.question: Who became one of the most popular monarchs in the 16th century?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada.

unique_questions.question: Who was one of the founders of England's naval tradition?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition. His ship (The Golden Hind) was one of the first to sail around the world.

unique_questions.question: Who designed the new St Paul Cathedral?
unique_questions.explanation: Christopher Wren designed a new St Paul Cathedral after the previous one was destroyed by a great fire in 1666.

unique_questions.question: What marked the beginning of 'constitutional monarchy'?
unique_questions.explanation: The laws passed after the Glorious Revolution are the beginning of what is called 'constitutional monarchy'.

unique_questions.question: Who developed important Human Nature ideas?
unique_questions.explanation: David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

unique_questions.question: Which country's flag is not part of the Union Flag?
unique_questions.explanation: The Welsh dragon is not part of the Union Flag.

unique_questions.question: Where was Florence Nightingale born?

unique_questions.question: When did the WWI begin?
unique_questions.explanation: The first World War began in 1914 and ended in 1918.

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the population has a grandparent born outside of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Post-war immigration means that nearly 10% of the population has a parent or grandparent born outside the UK.

unique_questions.question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

unique_questions.question: When is Boxing Day?
unique_questions.explanation: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

unique_questions.question: Who won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games?

unique_questions.question: Which style of architecture became popular in the 19th century?

unique_questions.explanation: Bodnant Garden is in Wales.

unique_questions.question: How often are the General Elections held?
unique_questions.explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

unique_questions.question: What does the UK offer to its residents?
unique_questions.explanation: In return, the UK offers: freedom of belief and religion, freedom of speech, freedom from unfair discrimination, a right to a fair trial, a right to join in the election of a government.

unique_questions.question: Which of these are 'Crown Dependencies'?
unique_questions.explanation: The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man are closely related to the UK but are not part of it. They have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

unique_questions.question: What did the first farmers build in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The first farmers built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

unique_questions.question: Which word comes from the Viking language?
unique_questions.explanation: Grimsby and Scunthorpe are the examples of words that come from the Viking languages.

unique_questions.question: Who sat in the House of Lords in the middle ages?
unique_questions.explanation: The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords.

unique_questions.question: What did Henry VII do?
unique_questions.explanation: Henry VII wanted to make sure that England remained peaceful and that his position as king was secure. He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.

Reduced the power of the nobles
Increased the power of the nobles
