unique_questions.question: For how long did England remain a republic?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain had been a republic for 11 years.

unique_questions.question: When did the Enlightenment happen?
unique_questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.

unique_questions.question: Where can you find the ship HMS Victory now?
unique_questions.explanation: HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth. It was Admiral Nelson's ship.

unique_questions.question: When did Ireland split into 2 countries?
unique_questions.explanation: Ireland became two countries in 1922.

unique_questions.question: Who defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

unique_questions.question: What is the capital of Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Cardiff is the capital of Wales.

unique_questions.question: As per 2021 census, what percentage of the England and Wales population identified as Sikh?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 2021 England and Wales census, around 525,000 people from the sampled population of 60 million identified as Sikh. 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (6.5%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

unique_questions.question: When is Halloween celebrated?
unique_questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

unique_questions.question: Which operas were written by Gilbert and Sullivan?
unique_questions.explanation: Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

unique_questions.question: Who can get a 50% discount on their TV licence?
unique_questions.explanation: People over 75 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 50% discount.

unique_questions.question: Where is Loch Lomond located?
unique_questions.explanation: Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of freshwater in mainland Britain and probably the best-known part of the park. It is located in Scotland.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is 'God Save the King/Queen'. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King/Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: 'God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King!'.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence?
unique_questions.explanation: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
unique_questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the judiciary responsible for?
unique_questions.explanation: Judges, who are together called 'the judiciary', are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

possible_answers.text: Deciding whether a person is guilty

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are the most serious civil cases heard in England and Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: More serious civil cases - for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed - are dealt with in the High Court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these charities works with children?
unique_questions.explanation: The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) works with children.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first woman Prime Minister?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK. She was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.

unique_questions.question: When did the 'Battle of Agincourt' take place?
unique_questions.explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

unique_questions.question: What did the Statute of Rhuddlan do?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

unique_questions.question: What is the Turner Prize given for?
unique_questions.explanation: The Turner Prize is recognised as one of the most prestigious visual art awards in Europe. Previous winners include Damien Hirst and Richard Wright.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: Where did the supporters of Charles Edward Stuart come from?
unique_questions.explanation: Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army.

unique_questions.question: Where does the UK government sit?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

unique_questions.question: When was the first coin in Britain made?
unique_questions.explanation: The Iron Age people made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings.

unique_questions.question: Where was one of the Anglo Saxon kings buried with treasure and armour?
unique_questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth. Scotland and Wales remained free of Anglo Saxon rule.

unique_questions.question: Which languages were the basis of modern English?
unique_questions.explanation: After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

unique_questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

unique_questions.question: When did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
unique_questions.explanation: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for 'you must present the person in court'. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

unique_questions.question: What helped the progress of the industrial revolution?
unique_questions.explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

unique_questions.question: How many American colonies declared their independence in 1776?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.

unique_questions.question: Who designed the Clifton Suspension Bridge?
unique_questions.explanation: Brunel was originally from Portsmouth, England. He was an engineer who built tunnels, bridges, railway lines and ships. He was responsible for constructing the Great Western Railway and the Clifton Suspension Bridge.

unique_questions.question: Which of the events is the bombing of English cities by the Germans?
unique_questions.explanation: The Blitz was the German air force bombing London and other British cities at night-time. The phrase 'the Blitz spirit' is still used today to describe Britons pulling together in the face of adversity.

unique_questions.question: Who was the Prime Minister during 1945-1951?
unique_questions.explanation: Clement Attlee was born in London in 1883. He was Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951 and led the Labour Party for 20 years.

unique_questions.question: When did the UK join the EEC?
unique_questions.explanation: West Germany, France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. At first the UK did not wish to join the EEC but it eventually did so in 1973.

unique_questions.question: When is Valentine's Day?
unique_questions.explanation: Valentine's Day, 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they secretly admire.

unique_questions.question: Which of these is not a music festival?
unique_questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Festival takes place in Edinburgh, Scotland, every summer. The Fringe (One of the festivals) is a showcase of mainly theatre and comedy performances.

unique_questions.question: When were films first shown in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular.

unique_questions.question: What's the age requirement to drink wine with a meal with someone over 18?
unique_questions.explanation: 16 year olds can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant as long as they are with someone over 18.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is currently the Head of State of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: King Charles III is the head of state of the UK. He is also the monarch or head of state for many countries in the Commonwealth.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often do the ministers meet to discuss important issues?
unique_questions.explanation: Ministers form the cabinet, a committee which usually meets weekly and makes important decisions about government policy. Many of these decisions have to be debated or approved by Parliament.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many members does The Northern Ireland Assembly have?
unique_questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly was established soon after the Belfast Agreement (or Good Friday Agreement) in 1998. There is a power-sharing agreement which distributes ministerial Offices amongst the main parties. The Assembly has 90 elected members (reduced from 108 in 2016), known as MLAs (members of the Legislative Assembly). They are elected with a form of proportional representation. The Assembly is chaired by a Speaker and three deputy Speakers. At least 10 members (including the Speaker) must be present in order for a vote to be taken on any matter.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How long can you use an EU driving licence for?
unique_questions.explanation: If your driving licence is from a country in the European Union (EU), Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway, you can drive in the UK for as long as your licence is valid, subject to UK licence renewal requirements (at the age of 70, or three years after the driver becomes resident). If you have a licence from any other country, you may use it in the UK for up to 12 months.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 (can change) member states.

unique_questions.question: When did the Parliament begin developing into the institution it is now?
unique_questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages, Parliament began to develop into the institution it is today. Its origins can be traced to the king's council of advisers, which included important noblemen and the leaders of the Church.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What is the responsibility that you have as a UK citizen?
unique_questions.explanation: Flowing from the fundamental principles are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK and which we expect all residents to respect. If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law; respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions; treat others with fairness; look after yourself and your family; look after the area in which you live and the environment.

possible_answers.text: Look after yourself and your family

correct_answers: Look after yourself and your family

unique_questions.question: What is the official name of the country?
unique_questions.explanation: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

possible_answers.text: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

correct_answers: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

unique_questions.question: What did the Romans introduce to Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first Danish King?
unique_questions.explanation: The first Danish King was Cnut, also called Canute.

unique_questions.question: What is the period after the Norman Conquest up until 1485 called?
unique_questions.explanation: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages or the medieval period. It was a time of almost constant war.

unique_questions.question: When did English become the official language for documents?
unique_questions.explanation: By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.

unique_questions.question: Who won the Wars of the Roses?
unique_questions.explanation: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose. The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.

unique_questions.question: Who ordered to write the Book of Common Prayer?
unique_questions.explanation: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first man to be called the 'Prime Minister'?
unique_questions.explanation: The first man to be called 'Prime Minister' was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

unique_questions.question: Who set up the first formal anti-slavery campaigns?
unique_questions.explanation: The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.

unique_questions.question: What was the estimated population of the British Empire?
unique_questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

unique_questions.question: When were the women given the right to vote at the same age as men?
unique_questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

unique_questions.question: When did the BBC start the first radio broadcast?
unique_questions.explanation: The BBC started radio broadcasts in 1922 and began the world's first regular television service in 1936.

unique_questions.question: Which party did Margaret Thatcher belong to?
unique_questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, Britain's first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the total UK population lives in Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: UK population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. Wales makes around 5%.

unique_questions.question: Who is a Patron St of Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.question: Where is the Millennium Stadium located?
unique_questions.explanation: Sporting events take place at major stadiums such as Wembley Stadium in London and the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff.

unique_questions.question: When did England win the World Cup?
unique_questions.explanation: Bobby Moore (1941-93) captained the English football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

unique_questions.question: What does the Turner Prize celebrate?
unique_questions.explanation: The Turner Prize was established in 1984 and celebrates contemporary art.

unique_questions.question: Who wrote 'The Lord of the Rings'?
unique_questions.explanation: The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best-loved novel in 2003.

unique_questions.question: Where can you get help if you can't afford to pay a vet?
unique_questions.explanation: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What happens if an MP dies or resigns?
unique_questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

possible_answers.text: The closest MP will have to cover
A new General Election is held

unique_questions.question: Where is the best preserved prehistoric village 'Skara Brae on Orkney' located?
unique_questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

unique_questions.question: Why was Mary known as 'Bloody Mary'?
unique_questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

possible_answers.text: She put her sister in prison

unique_questions.question: Which of these are British Overseas Territories?
unique_questions.explanation: There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

possible_answers.text: St Helena and the Isle of Man
The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man

unique_questions.question: How long is the Bayeux Tapestry?
unique_questions.explanation: The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry which is 70 meters long.

unique_questions.question: How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have in the middle ages?
unique_questions.explanation: In the middle ages the Scottish Parliament had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

unique_questions.question: Where did Charles II hide to escape from Cromwell's army?
unique_questions.explanation: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

unique_questions.question: When did the Glorious Revolution happen?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

unique_questions.question: Which clan was killed because of not taking an oath?
unique_questions.explanation: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

unique_questions.question: What is known as the Bessemer process?
unique_questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

unique_questions.question: What was the purpose of the Corn Laws in 1846?
unique_questions.explanation: Corn Laws in 1846 had prevented the import of cheap grain.

possible_answers.text: To prevent the import of cheap grain

correct_answers: To prevent the import of cheap grain

unique_questions.question: Who discovered Insulin?
unique_questions.explanation: The Scottish physician and researcher John MacLeod (1876-1935) was the co-discoverer of insulin, used to treat diabetes.

unique_questions.question: Who invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic.

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the workforce are women?
unique_questions.explanation: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce. On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. More women than men study at university.

unique_questions.question: How long is Hanukkah celebrated for?
unique_questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

unique_questions.question: How many times has the UK hosted the Olympic Games?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London.

unique_questions.question: Where do the Laurence Olivier Awards take place?
unique_questions.explanation: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director, best actor and best actress. The awards are named after the British actor Sir Laurence Olivier, later Lord Olivier, who was best known for his roles in various Shakespeare plays.

unique_questions.question: Which organization looks after the Edinburgh Castle?
unique_questions.explanation: The Edinburgh Castle has a long history, dating back to the early Middle Ages. It is looked after by Historic Scotland, a Scottish government agency.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the British Constitution often described as?
unique_questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is able to change the Prime Minister during his/her term?
unique_questions.explanation: The Prime Minister can be changed if the MPs in the governing party decide to do so, or if he or she wishes to resign. The Prime Minister usually resigns if his or her party loses a General Election.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is an example of a Criminal Offence?
unique_questions.explanation: Examples of criminal laws are - Carrying a weapon: it is a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind, even if it is for self-defence. This includes a gun, a knife or anything that is made or adapted to cause injury; Drugs: selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK; Racial crime: it is a criminal offence to cause harassment, alarm or distress to someone because of their religion or ethnic origin; Selling tobacco: it is illegal to sell tobacco products (for example, cigarettes, cigars, roll-up tobacco) to anyone under the age of 18; Smoking in public places: it is against the law to smoke tobacco products in nearly every enclosed public place in the UK. There are signs displayed to tell you where you cannot smoke; Buying alcohol: it is a criminal offence to sell alcohol to anyone who is under 18 or to buy alcohol for people who are under the age of 18; Drinking in public: some places have alcohol-free zones where you cannot drink in public. The police can also confiscate alcohol or move young people on from public places. You can be fined or arrested.

unique_questions.question: What does the 'R' Plate stand for?
unique_questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an 'R' plate (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What can schools do to raise money?
unique_questions.explanation: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

possible_answers.text: Ask the local council for extra funding

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How long does it take to give blood?
unique_questions.explanation: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses, it takes about an hour to do so.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

unique_questions.question: Which party formed the government in 2010?
unique_questions.explanation: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

unique_questions.question: Who were the first people to start living in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The first people to live in Britain were hunter-gatherers, in what we call the Stone Age.

unique_questions.question: Where did the Vikings come from?
unique_questions.explanation: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

unique_questions.question: Which Scottish poet wrote 'The Bruce'?
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland, many people continued to speak Gaelic and the Scots language also developed. A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.

unique_questions.question: When did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?
unique_questions.explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

unique_questions.question: What is the 'King James' Bible?
unique_questions.explanation: One achievement of King James' reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'. It was not the first English Bible but is a version which continues to be used in many Protestant churches today.

unique_questions.question: When did the English Civil war begin?
unique_questions.explanation: Civil war between the king and Parliament began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

unique_questions.question: Why is it called 'The Glorious Revolution'?
unique_questions.explanation: This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

possible_answers.text: Women were given the right to vote

unique_questions.question: Who lost a lot of their power after the Battle of Culloden in 1746?
unique_questions.explanation: The clans lost a lot of their power and influence after Culloden. Chieftains became landlords if they had the favour of the English king, and clansmen became tenants who had to pay for the land they used.

unique_questions.question: What were the working conditions like during the Industrial Revolution?
unique_questions.explanation: Working conditions during the Industrial Revolution were very poor. There were no laws to protect employees, who were often forced to work long hours in dangerous situations. Children also worked and were treated in the same way as adults.

unique_questions.question: Which country(s) did Britain fight against during the Battle of Trafalgar?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

unique_questions.question: What medal was introduced during the Crimean War?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during the Crimean war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

unique_questions.question: What event is known as the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
unique_questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

unique_questions.question: What country is Swansea in?
unique_questions.explanation: Swansea is a Welsh city.

unique_questions.question: What is the Church of England usually known as in other countries?
unique_questions.explanation: The official Church of the state is the Church of England, called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States.

unique_questions.question: What is the day before Lent called?
unique_questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day.

unique_questions.question: Which country invented Cricket?
unique_questions.explanation: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The most famous Cricket competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

unique_questions.question: Which of these venues is located in Greenwich?
unique_questions.explanation: There are many large venues that host music events throughout the year, such as: The O2 in Greenwich and the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) in Glasgow.

unique_questions.question: Who designed the Cenotaph?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen and many others.

unique_questions.question: Which river banks the London eye?
unique_questions.explanation: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall. It was originally built as part of the UK's celebration of the new millennium and continues to be an important part of New Year celebrations.

unique_questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote;elections every year;for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

possible_answers.text: Anyone to be able to stand as an MP
Every man to have a vote

correct_answers: Every man to have a vote

unique_questions.question: Who is responsible for crime and immigration?
unique_questions.explanation: Home Secretary is responsible for crime, policing and immigration.

unique_questions.question: What organisations try to influence government policy?
unique_questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many member states does the UN have?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What programme helps teenagers develop their skills?
unique_questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often do you have to take the MOT test for an old vehicle?
unique_questions.explanation: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What service can you use to find a lawyer or a solicitor?
unique_questions.explanation: The Citizens Advice Bureau can give you names of local solicitors and which areas of law they specialise in. You can also get this information from the Law Society.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are the youth cases heard in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland a system called the Children's Hearings System is used to deal with children and young people who have committed an offence.

possible_answers.text: There is a Children's Hearings System

correct_answers: There is a Children's Hearings System

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which is an example of a Civil Offence?
unique_questions.explanation: Examples of civil laws are - Housing law: this includes disputes between landlords and tenants over issues such as repairs and eviction; Consumer rights: an example of this is a dispute about faulty goods or services; Employment law: these cases include disputes over wages and cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace; Debt: people might be taken to court if they owe money to someone.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: When did the UK leave the EU following the Brexit Vote?
unique_questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote in 2020, there are now 27 EU member states.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What information about you is asked at the polling station?
unique_questions.explanation: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification.

possible_answers.text: Your name, contact details and age

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the main purpose of the Opposition?
unique_questions.explanation: The opposition form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

possible_answers.text: To represent the people of the UK

unique_questions.question: What UK landmark was voted as Britain's favourite view?
unique_questions.explanation: The Lake District is England's largest national park. It covers 885 square miles (2,292 square kilometres). It is famous for its lakes and mountains and is very popular with climbers, walkers and sailors. The biggest stretch of water is Windermere. In 2007, television viewers voted Wastwater as Britain's favourite view.

unique_questions.question: What do you require by law to watch TV using any medium?
unique_questions.explanation: If you watch or record live TV programmes on any channel, or download or watch BBC programmes on BBC iPlayer on any digital devices, you need to be covered by a TV Licence.

unique_questions.question: What is an important part of the UK character?
unique_questions.explanation: The traditions of comedy and satire, and the ability to laugh at ourselves, are an important part of the UK character.

To have fish and chips every lunch
Go to the pub every Friday

correct_answers: The ability to laugh at ourselves

unique_questions.question: Which flower is associated with Northern Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: A shamrock is associated with Northern Ireland. A rose is associated with England, a thistle with Scotland and a daffodil with Wales.

unique_questions.question: Who first introduced James Bond?
unique_questions.explanation: Ian Fleming's books introduced James Bond.

unique_questions.question: What type of painter was Joseph Turner?
unique_questions.explanation: Joseph Turner (1775-1851) was an influential landscape painter in a modern style. He is considered the artist who raised the profile of landscape painting.

unique_questions.question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
unique_questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

unique_questions.question: Who became the first Briton to win the Tour de France?
unique_questions.explanation: Bradley Wiggins (1980-) is a cyclist. In 2012, he became the first Briton to win the Tour de France. He has won seven Olympic medals, including gold medals in the 2004, 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games.

unique_questions.question: What celebrates the end of Ramadan?
unique_questions.explanation: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast.

unique_questions.question: What does an aged population have an impact on?
unique_questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

unique_questions.question: Which of these is not a valid bank note?
unique_questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

unique_questions.question: Who developed a radar?
unique_questions.explanation: Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt (1892-1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

unique_questions.question: Who led the Labour Government from 2007 to 2010?
unique_questions.explanation: Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister in 2007 and led the Labour Party.

unique_questions.question: What treaty was signed in 1707?
unique_questions.explanation: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was therefore agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

possible_answers.text: The Act for Government of Wales

unique_questions.question: Who tried to arrest 5 parliamentary leaders from the House of Commons?
unique_questions.explanation: Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there. This led to the English Civil war in 1642.

unique_questions.question: When did Scotland abolish the authority of the Pope?
unique_questions.explanation: Scotland had also been strongly influenced by Protestant ideas. In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.

unique_questions.question: Which play was written by Shakespeare?
unique_questions.explanation: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet. Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V); To be or not to be (Hamlet); A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet); All the world's a stage (As You Like It); The darling buds of May (Sonnet 18, Shall I Compare Thee To a Summer's Day).

unique_questions.question: When did Britain become separated from the continent?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.

unique_questions.question: Where can you find Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni statue?
unique_questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.

unique_questions.question: Who built the Hadrian's Wall to keep out the Picts?
unique_questions.explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

unique_questions.question: Who is known as William the Conqueror?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

unique_questions.question: When was the Magna Carta established?
unique_questions.explanation: There were few formal limits to the king's power until 1215. In that year, King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king's power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

unique_questions.question: What were the Canterbury Tales about?
unique_questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

possible_answers.text: The stories people told each other

correct_answers: The stories people told each other

unique_questions.question: Which of Henry VIII's wives were executed?
unique_questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London. Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

possible_answers.text: Catherine Parr and Anne of Cleves
Catherine of Aragon and Anne Boleyn
Anne of Cleves and Jane Seymour

unique_questions.question: What is the 'Divine Right of Kings'?
unique_questions.explanation: Divine Right of Kings' is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

possible_answers.text: Reduced the power of the nobles
Reduced the power of the King
The King was Appointed by God

unique_questions.question: When did the 'Battle of the Boyne' happen?
unique_questions.explanation: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army. William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

unique_questions.question: What were the refugees that came from France called?
unique_questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

unique_questions.question: How is the New Year often called in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. His best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

unique_questions.question: When did Queen Victoria become queen?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years.

unique_questions.question: What was the main crop in Ireland in the 19th century?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 19th century, many people in Ireland depended on potatoes as a large part of their diet. In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

unique_questions.question: Who led a team to clone a mammal for the first time?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1996, two British scientists, Sir Ian Wilmot (1944-) and Keith Campbell (1954-2012), led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep. This has led to further research into the possible use of cloning to preserve endangered species and for medical purposes.

possible_answers.text: Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell

correct_answers: Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell

unique_questions.question: What was the population of the UK in 1998?
unique_questions.explanation: Population growth in the UK (Year, Population): (1600, Just over 4 million), (1700, 5 million), (1801, 8 million), (1851, 20 million), (1901, 40 million), (1951, 50 million), (1998, 57 million), (2005, Just under 60 million), (2010, Just over 62 million).

unique_questions.question: When is St Patrick's day?
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.question: When is the Bonfire Night celebrated?
unique_questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

unique_questions.question: Who is Andy Murray?
unique_questions.explanation: Andy Murray (1987-) is a Scottish tennis player who in 2012 won the men's singles in the US Open. He is the first British man to win a singles title in a Grand Slam tournament since 1936. In the same year, he won Olympic gold and silver medals.

unique_questions.question: What is the Mercury Music Prize awarded for?
unique_questions.explanation: The Mercury Music Prize is awarded each September for the best album from the UK and Ireland. The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

The best classical song in the UK and Ireland
The best song in the UK and Ireland
The best album from the UK and Ireland
