unique_questions.question: What prehistoric village (off the north coast of Scotland) has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age?
unique_questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

unique_questions.question: In what county can you see a hill fort at Maiden Castle?
unique_questions.explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

unique_questions.question: When were the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in England?
unique_questions.explanation: By about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain. These kingdoms were mainly in what is now England.

unique_questions.question: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk
unique_questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO did the Romans establish in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals

unique_questions.question: Robert the Bruce is associated with which country?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

unique_questions.question: The Scottish Parliament (after the Magna Carta was established in England) was split into two estates: the Lords and the Commons
unique_questions.explanation: In England, the nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons. Only a small part of the population was able to join in electing the members of the Commons. In Scotland, the parliament had three Houses, called Estates: the Lords, the Commons and the Clergy.

unique_questions.question: Oliver Cromwell took the title 'King of Ireland'
unique_questions.explanation: Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658. Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'

unique_questions.question: When William of Orange re-conquered Ireland (in 1690) he took the title 'William the Conqueror'
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

unique_questions.question: Who was Robert Burns?
unique_questions.explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

unique_questions.question: After the Emancipation Act, how many Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the slaves?
unique_questions.explanation: The Emancipation Act of 1833 abolished slavery throughout British Empire. William Wilberforce was leading abolitionist and Quakers set up first anti-slavery groups. More than 2 million migrants came from India and China to replace labour force.

unique_questions.question: What does St Patrick's cross look like?
unique_questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

possible_answers.text: A red cross on a white ground
A diagonal red cross on a white ground
A diagonal white cross on a blue ground

correct_answers: A diagonal red cross on a white ground

unique_questions.question: Rudyard Kipling reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good
unique_questions.explanation: Kipling wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

unique_questions.question: Which of these countries was NOT UK's ally in the WWII?
unique_questions.explanation: The war was initially fought between the Axis powers (fascist Germany and Italy and the Empire of Japan) and the Allies

unique_questions.question: Who led a team of scientists to develop the atomic bomb?
unique_questions.explanation: Scientists led by Ernest Rutherford, working at Manchester and then Cambridge University, were the first to 'split the atom' and took part in the Manhattan Project in the United States, which developed the atomic bomb.

unique_questions.question: When was a Turing machine invented?
unique_questions.explanation: A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912-54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s. The theory was influential in the development of computer science and the modern-day computer.

unique_questions.question: How many people lost their lives in Northern Ireland in the decades after 1969?
unique_questions.explanation: The 1970s were also a time of serious unrest in Northern Ireland. In 1972, the Northern Ireland Parliament was suspended and Northern Ireland was directly ruled by the UK government. Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: When did the British troops leave Iraq?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 2000, British armed forces have been engaged in the global fight against international terrorism and against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. British combat troops left Iraq in 2009.

unique_questions.question: The British constitution is described as 'unwritten'
unique_questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government. Our most important institutions have developed over hundreds of years.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO roles are school governors and school boards responsible for?
unique_questions.explanation: Governors and school boards have an important part to play in raising school standards. They have three key roles: setting the strategic direction of the school, ensuring accountability, monitoring and evaluating school performance.

possible_answers.text: Setting the strategic direction of the school

correct_answers: Setting the strategic direction of the school

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Volunteering is compulsory in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: Volunteering is working for good causes without payment. It is not compulsory.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Can the devolved administrations control sectors such as immigration, foreign affairs and taxation?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. Policy and laws governing defence, foreign affairs, immigration, taxation and social security all remain under central UK government control. However, many other public services, such as education, are controlled by the devolved administrations.

possible_answers.text: Only if the local people support them

unique_questions.question: Which TWO are NOT part of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many members does the Welsh Assembly have?
unique_questions.explanation: The Welsh Assembly has 60 members, with forty members chosen to represent individual Senedd constituencies, and twenty to represent the five electoral regions of the Senedd in Wales.

unique_questions.question: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, what English county does it stand in?
unique_questions.explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

unique_questions.question: Why is 1928 an important date for women's rights?
unique_questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

possible_answers.text: Women could vote at 21, the same age as men
Women could vote at 18, the same age as men
Women could vote if they were over 30 years old

correct_answers: Women could vote at 21, the same age as men

unique_questions.question: What is the correct order of the Patron Saints' Days? (Starting from January)
unique_questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their patron saint's day as an official holiday. Events are held across Scotland, Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, especially where there are a lot of people of Scottish, Northern Irish and Irish heritage.

possible_answers.text: St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St Andrew's Day, St George's Day
St George's Day, St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St Andrew's Day
St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St George's Day, St Andrew's Day
St Patrick's Day, St David's Day, St Andrew's Day, St George's Day

correct_answers: St David's Day, St Patrick's Day, St George's Day, St Andrew's Day

unique_questions.question: What are Halloween lanterns traditionally made out of?
unique_questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

unique_questions.question: What is the 'Grand National'?
unique_questions.explanation: The Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr are well known horse racing events.

unique_questions.question: On Valentine's Day people exchange gifts and cards and send anonymous cards to people they secretly admire
unique_questions.explanation: Valentine's Day, 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they secretly admire.

unique_questions.question: On what day does 'Lent' begin?
unique_questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food. The day before Lent starts is called Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day. Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

unique_questions.question: In the 20th century, what did Sir Edwin Lutyens design to be the seat of government in India?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 20th century, Sir Edwin Lutyens had an influence throughout the British Empire. He designed New Delhi to be the seat of government in India. After the First World War, he was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

unique_questions.question: A 60 second silence is observed on the Remembrance Day
unique_questions.explanation: Remembrance Day, 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies. Originally it commemorated the dead of the First World War, which ended on 11 November 1918. People wear poppies (the red flower found on the battlefields of the First World War). At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

unique_questions.question: Select TWO early members of the Royal Society
unique_questions.explanation: Charles II was interested in science. During his reign, the Royal Society was formed to promote 'natural knowledge'. This is the oldest surviving scientific society in the world. Among its early members were Sir Edmund Halley, who successfully predicted the return of the comet now called Halley's Comet, and Sir Isaac Newton.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The UN was set up straight after the First World War. It now has over 190 countries as members
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security. There are 15 members on the UN Security Council, which recommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace. The UK is one of five permanent members of the Security Council.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities
unique_questions.explanation: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is the next heir to the throne?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952 (in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee - 60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. Her eldest son, King Charles III (previously the Prince of Wales) became the new monarch. His elder son, William, Prince of Wales is next in line.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Nowadays, the House of Commons has more power than the House of Lords
unique_questions.explanation: The House of Commons has powers to overrule the House of Lords, but these are not used often.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In Northern Ireland, minor cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court. In Northern Ireland, cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What method is used to elect UK MPs?
unique_questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected. The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The European Convention on Human Rights is incorporated into UK law
unique_questions.explanation: The Human Rights Act 1998 incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law. The government, public bodies and the courts must follow the principles of the Convention.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What should all new citizens do as part of the citizenship ceremony?
unique_questions.explanation: New citizens swear or affirm loyalty to the Queen as part of the citizenship ceremony.

possible_answers.text: Swear or affirm loyalty to the King (or Queen)
Prepare and make an individual speech during the ceremony
Sign passports and official citizenship certificates

correct_answers: Swear or affirm loyalty to the King (or Queen)

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What do you have to pay tax on in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes: wages from paid employment; profits from self-employment, taxable benefits; pensions; income from property, savings and dividends.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What system can be used to complete a tax return if you are self-employed?
unique_questions.explanation: For most people, the right amount of income tax is automatically taken from their income from employment by their employer and paid directly to HM Revenue Customs (HMRC), the government department that collects taxes. This system is called 'Pay As You Earn' (PAYE). If you are self-employed, you need to pay your own tax through a system called 'self-assessment', which includes completing a tax return.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead?
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III at the time of writing) has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Monarch makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Members in the Welsh Assembly can speak English and Welsh, and all publications of the Assembly are in both languages
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In Scotland, judges developed 'common law' by following previous decisions. It was referred to as 'unwritten'
unique_questions.explanation: In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition. In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).

unique_questions.question: What is the origin of Parliament?
unique_questions.explanation: In the Middle Ages, Parliament began to develop into the institution it is today. Its origins can be traced to the king's council of advisers, which included important noblemen and the leaders of the Church.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true

unique_questions.question: When did the First World War end?
unique_questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

unique_questions.question: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC but this was unsuccessful. For how many years did Britain remain separate from the Roman Empire?
unique_questions.explanation: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

unique_questions.question: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni. What is it known as now?
unique_questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.

unique_questions.question: Easter eggs are often given as presents at Easter as a symbol of new life
unique_questions.explanation: Easter is also celebrated by people who are not religious. 'Easter eggs' are chocolate eggs often given as presents at Easter as a symbol of new life.

unique_questions.question: What do many theatres produce at Christmas time?
unique_questions.explanation: One British tradition is the pantomime. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences. One of the traditional characters is the Dame, a woman played by a man. There is often also a pantomime horse or cow played by two actors in the same costume.

unique_questions.question: Which country's national flower is a thistle?
unique_questions.explanation: A thistle is a national flower of Scotland.

unique_questions.question: Select TWO popular social networking websites
unique_questions.explanation: Social networking websites such as Facebook and Twitter are a popular way for people to stay in touch with friends, organise social events, and share photos, videos and opinions. Many people use social networking on their mobile phones when out and about.

unique_questions.question: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of which river?
unique_questions.explanation: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall. It was originally built as part of the UK's celebration of the new millennium and continues to be an important part of New Year celebrations.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Speaker also represents Parliament on ceremonial occasions
unique_questions.explanation: The Speaker keeps order during political debates to make sure the rules are followed. This includes making sure the opposition (see The government) has a guaranteed amount of time to debate issues which it chooses. The Speaker also represents Parliament on ceremonial occasions.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who resides in 10 Downing Street?
unique_questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Council of Europe has no power to make laws
unique_questions.explanation: The Council of Europe is separate from the EU. It has 47 member countries, including the UK, and is responsible for the protection and promotion of human rights in those countries. It has no power to make laws but draws up conventions and charters, the most well-known of which is the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, usually called the European Convention on Human Rights.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Choose TWO examples of a civil law offence
unique_questions.explanation: Examples of civil laws are - Housing law: this includes disputes between landlords and tenants over issues such as repairs and eviction; Consumer rights: an example of this is a dispute about faulty goods or services; Employment law: these cases include disputes over wages and cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace; Debt: people might be taken to court if they owe money to someone.

possible_answers.text: Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

correct_answers: Unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What can be done to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage?
unique_questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007. Court orders can be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage. Similar Protection Orders were introduced in Scotland in November 2011.

possible_answers.text: Court orders can be obtained by a potential victim or someone acting for them
Ask the priest to verify the identities
Check the age of both people to make sure they are over 18
Check the age of both people to make sure they are over 25

correct_answers: Court orders can be obtained by a potential victim or someone acting for them

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: There are 9 National Parks in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: The UK has a large network of public footpaths in the countryside. There are also many opportunities for mountain biking, mountaineering and hill walking. There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the National Citizen Service?
unique_questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

possible_answers.text: It provides free, independent, impartial advice on your rights and responsibilities
It provides free, confidential and impartial advice on consumer issues
It is a volunteering programme for young people who want to do voluntary development work abroad
It helps you build your skills for work and life

correct_answers: It helps you build your skills for work and life

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections
unique_questions.explanation: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and the Irish Republic who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register
unique_questions.explanation: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register. If you are eligible to vote, you can register by contacting your local council electoral registration Office.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than _____ years old
unique_questions.explanation: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: On which TWO occasions will there be a fresh election, called a by-election, in MP's constituency?
unique_questions.explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years. If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency. MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How is the Speaker elected?
unique_questions.explanation: Debates in the House of Commons are chaired by the Speaker. This person is the chief Officer of the House of Commons. The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP. The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

possible_answers.text: The Archbishop of Canterbury chooses the Speaker

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What can the Scottish Parliament do?
unique_questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters which are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament. The matters on which the Scottish Parliament can legislate include: civil and criminal law, health, education, planning and additional tax-raising powers.

possible_answers.text: May pass laws on anything in Scotland
May pass laws on general economic policy
May pass laws on foreign and defence affairs
May pass legislation on anything not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament

correct_answers: May pass legislation on anything not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The members of the Armed Forces can stand for Public Office
unique_questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for Public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the Shadow Cabinet?
unique_questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. The leader of the opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be 'shadow ministers'. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

possible_answers.text: The cabinet that is in trouble
The cabinet where the Prime Minister had to resign
Senior members of the main opposition party who 'shadow' Government ministers in different departments
The name of the office of the Leader of the Opposition in the Parliament

correct_answers: Senior members of the main opposition party who 'shadow' Government ministers in different departments

unique_questions.question: Who designed the new St Paul's?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1666, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul's Cathedral. London was rebuilt with a new St Paul's, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: You must treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, age, religion, disability, class or sexual orientation
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true.

unique_questions.question: How many counties in Ireland remained in the UK under Northern Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries. The six counties in the north which were mainly Protestant remained part of the UK under the name Northern Ireland. The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.

unique_questions.question: Winston Churchill lost the General Election in 1945
unique_questions.explanation: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship. He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.

unique_questions.question: Protestant Christian groups include Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers
unique_questions.explanation: Protestant Christian groups in the UK are Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers. There are also other denominations of Christianity, the biggest of which is Roman Catholic.

unique_questions.question: In what year did the Troubles break out?
unique_questions.explanation: Some 3,000 people lost their lives in the decades after 1969 in the violence in Northern Ireland. The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as 'the Troubles'.

unique_questions.question: Why is 1969 a very important year in British history?
unique_questions.explanation: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

possible_answers.text: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 30
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18
Women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, same as men
Women were given the right to vote

correct_answers: Women were given the right to vote at the age of 18

unique_questions.question: What is the national flower of Northern Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: A Shamrock is the national flower of Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Where does the Grand National takes place?
unique_questions.explanation: There are racecourses all over the UK. Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

unique_questions.question: Who wrote music for George VI and Queen Elizabeth II?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir William Walton (1902-83) wrote a wide range of music, from film scores to opera. He wrote marches for the coronations of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth II but his best-known works are probably Facade, which became a ballet, and Balthazar's Feast, which is intended to be sung by a large choir.

unique_questions.question: Where is the SECC located?
unique_questions.explanation: There are many large venues that host music events throughout the year, such as: Wembley Stadium; The O2 in Greenwich, south-east London; and the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre (SECC) in Glasgow.

unique_questions.question: Who wrote about their experiences in the First World War?
unique_questions.explanation: Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon - were inspired to write about their experiences in the First World War.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

possible_answers.text: Northern Ireland makes up 4% of the total population
England makes up 83% of the total population
Wales makes up 6% of the total population
Scotland makes up 8% of the total population

correct_answers: Scotland makes up 8% of the total population

unique_questions.question: Who wrote the popular operas HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and the Mikado?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 19th century, Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

unique_questions.question: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel
unique_questions.explanation: In 2003, The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best loved novel

unique_questions.question: What can 'Carry on' be associated with?
unique_questions.explanation: The 1950s and 1960s were a high point for British comedies, including Passport to Pimlico, The Ladykillers and, later, the Carry On films.

unique_questions.question: Select TWO famous Athletes
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Roger Bannister (1929-) was the first man in the world to run a mile in under four minutes, in 1954. Mo Farah (1983-) is a British distance runner, born in Somalia. He won gold medals in the 2012 Olympics for the 5,000 and 10,000 metres and is the first Briton to win the Olympic gold medal in the 10,000 metres.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many members does a jury have in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: A jury is made up of members of the public chosen at random from the local electoral register (see The Electoral Register). In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Many of the painters working in Britain in the 16th and 17th centuries were from abroad
unique_questions.explanation: Many of the painters working in Britain in the 16th and 17th centuries were from abroad - for example, Hans Holbein and Sir Anthony Van Dyck.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The House of Lords is more independent of the government than the House of Commons
unique_questions.explanation: The House of Lords is normally more independent of the government than the House of Commons. It can suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by MPs. The House of Lords checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Blood and organ donations are compulsory in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: it's a donation, thus its not compulsory. Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses. Giving blood only takes about an hour to do.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: NSPCC is a charity for which of the following?
unique_questions.explanation: Children - the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC); The homeless - Crisis and Shelter; Medical research charities - Cancer Research UK; Environmental charities- the National Trust and Friends of the Earth; Animals - People's Dispensary for Sick Animals (PDSA).

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you help looking after the environment?
unique_questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. Using recycled materials to make new products uses less energy and means that we do not need to extract more raw materials from the earth. It also means that less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced.

unique_questions.question: Who should you contact to get your National Insurance number?
unique_questions.explanation: You will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where can you get details about the small claims procedure?
unique_questions.explanation: You can get details about the small claims procedure from your local County Court or Sheriff Court.

unique_questions.question: After the Black Death, a new social class appeared, - owners of large areas of land. What were they called?
unique_questions.explanation: New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land called 'the gentry', and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

unique_questions.question: What is the name given to the conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the UK government?
unique_questions.explanation: The conflict between those wishing for full Irish independence and those wishing to remain loyal to the British government is often referred to as 'the Troubles'.

unique_questions.question: In what year was Germany comprehensively defeated by the Allies during the WWII?
unique_questions.explanation: Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France and eventually into Germany. The Allies comprehensively defeated Germany in May 1945.

unique_questions.question: English laws and the English language were introduced in Wales by the middle of which century?
unique_questions.explanation: By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.

unique_questions.question: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished glassworkers
unique_questions.explanation: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkers

unique_questions.question: People of the Iron Age sometimes defended sites. What were these sites?
unique_questions.explanation: People still lived in roundhouses, grouped together into larger settlements, and sometimes defended sites called hill forts. A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

unique_questions.question: Who was the monarch when the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI, who was strongly Protestant. During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England. A version of this book is still used in some churches today.

unique_questions.question: Who developed ideas about economics during the Enlightenment period which are still referred to today?
unique_questions.explanation: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

unique_questions.question: Until what time do people play jokes on one another on April Fool's Day?
unique_questions.explanation: April Fool's Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

unique_questions.question: There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay for a vet
unique_questions.explanation: Vaccinations and medical treatment for animals are available from veterinary surgeons (vets). There are charities which may help people who cannot afford to pay a vet.

unique_questions.question: Hanukkah is celebrated to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom and it is in November or December for how many days?
unique_questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. It is to remember the Jews' struggle for religious freedom. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

unique_questions.question: What is the capital of Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Cardiff is the capital city of Wales

unique_questions.question: Who was John Constable?
unique_questions.explanation: John Constable (1776-1837) was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk, Essex border in the east of England.

possible_answers.text: An important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s
A landscape painter, most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the East of England
A very successful Northern Irish portrait painter
A Welsh artist, best known for his engravings and stained glass

correct_answers: A landscape painter, most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the East of England

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the UK population lives in England?
unique_questions.explanation: England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What will happen to any driver who has either taken more than the acceptable quantity of alcohol or refused to take the test?
unique_questions.explanation: If you are found driving while exceeding the alcohol limit you will be arrested.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of the options given below is not necessary for a new car?
unique_questions.explanation: If your vehicle is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: On election day, you will get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in front of the polling officer
unique_questions.explanation: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification. You will then get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in privately

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The leader of the Opposition appoints senior opposition MPs to be what?
unique_questions.explanation: The leader of the Opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be 'shadow ministers'. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Prime Minister is the head of the Commonwealth
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III at the time of writing) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 member states.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are the more serious civil cases dealt with in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: More serious civil cases - for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed - are dealt with in the High Court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In Scotland, they are dealt with in the Court of Session in Edinburgh.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: When did hereditary peers lose the automatic right to attend the House of Lords?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: One TV licence covers all of the equipment at one address, but people who rent different rooms in a shared house must buy a separate TV licence
unique_questions.explanation: One TV licence covers all of the equipment at one address, but people who rent different rooms in a shared house must buy a separate TV licence

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: You can find copies of Hansard report in large libraries and on the Internet
unique_questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Written reports can be found in large libraries and online.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: You need to buy a TV Licence if there are no TVs in your house but you watch TV programs on your mobile phone
unique_questions.explanation: You must pay for a licence to watch TV through any medium.

unique_questions.question: What is the BBC funded by?
unique_questions.explanation: Money from TV licences goes to the BBC.

unique_questions.question: How old was the Queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart when her father died and she became Queen?
unique_questions.explanation: The queen of Scotland, Mary Stuart (often now called 'Mary, Queen of Scots') was a Catholic. She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen.

unique_questions.question: Who was the Queen of the Iceni? She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London
unique_questions.explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

unique_questions.question: People don't celebrate Christmas as much as they used to before
unique_questions.explanation: Christmas remains very popular in the UK. People usually spend the day at home and eat a special meal, which often includes roast turkey, Christmas pudding and mince pies.

unique_questions.question: In the 2021 England and Wales census, what percentage of people identified themselves as Christian?
unique_questions.explanation: The 2021 Census results released so far show that 46% of people in England and Wales (from a total sampled 60 million) identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 37% stated not to follow any religion and 0.5% of people followed another religion

unique_questions.question: Where in Scotland is known as the home of golf?
unique_questions.explanation: Game of golf can be traced back to 15th century Scotland. It is a popular sport played socially as well as professionally. There are public and private golf courses all over the UK. St Andrews in Scotland is known as the home of golf.

unique_questions.question: What is Boxing Day?(Choose TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: Boxing Day is the day after Christmas Day and is a public holiday.

unique_questions.question: When is Halloween (an ancient festival) celebrated?
unique_questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

unique_questions.question: What food is traditionally associated with Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Welsh cakes - a traditional Welsh snack made from flour, dried fruits and spices, and served either hot or cold.

possible_answers.text: Roast beef, which is served with potatoes, vegetables, Yorkshire puddings

unique_questions.question: When was the first public film shown in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Films were first shown publicly in the UK in 1896 and film screenings very quickly became popular. From the beginning, film makers became famous for clever special effects and this continues to be an area of British expertise.

unique_questions.question: In Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic
unique_questions.explanation: In Wales, many people speak Welsh - a completely different language from English - and it is taught in schools and universities. In Scotland, Gaelic (again, a different language) is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you make a complaint about the Police? (Choose TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved.

possible_answers.text: Writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved

correct_answers: Writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development
unique_questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many senior MPs get appointed by the Prime Minister to become ministers in charge of departments?
unique_questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments. These include: Chancellor of the Exchequer: responsible for the economy; Home Secretary:responsible for crime, policing and immigration; Foreign Secretary: responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries; other ministers (called 'Secretaries of State') are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In England and Wales, the small claims procedure is used for claims of less than what amount?
unique_questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £5,000 in Northern Ireland (Changed from £3000).

unique_questions.question: Queen Elizabeth II was married to Prince Phillip
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What should you do when you move into a new house or apartment?
unique_questions.explanation: When you move into a new house or apartment, introduce yourself to the people who live near you. Getting to know your neighbours can help you to become part of the community and make friends.

possible_answers.text: Tell the people who live near you not to make noise
Introduce yourself to the people who live near you so they can help you
Warn the people who live near you not to talk to you

correct_answers: Introduce yourself to the people who live near you so they can help you

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often are the European Parliament elections held?
unique_questions.explanation: Elections for the European Parliament are also held every five years. Elected members are called members of the European Parliament (MEPs). Elections to the European Parliament use a system of proportional representation, where seats are allocated to each party in proportion to the total number of votes it has won.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be _____ , so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints
unique_questions.explanation: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be balanced, so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: When was the Scottish Parliament formed?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What does the money raised from National Insurance Contributions pay for? (Choose TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: The money raised from National Insurance Contributions is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election
unique_questions.explanation: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition. The leader of the opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: It is illegal to sell tobacco products such as cigarettes, cigars, roll-up tobacco to anyone under what age?
unique_questions.explanation: It is illegal to sell tobacco products (for example, cigarettes, cigars, roll-up tobacco) to anyone under the age of 18.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of British Life?
unique_questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: Democracy; The rule of law; Individual liberty; Tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs; Participation in community life.

unique_questions.question: The Welsh language, spoken in Wales and is taught in schools and universities, is a completely different language from English
unique_questions.explanation: The English language has many accents and dialects. In Wales, many people speak Welsh - a completely different language from English - and it is taught in schools and universities. In Scotland, Gaelic (again, a different language) is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

unique_questions.question: Henry VIII's fourth wife, Anne of Cleves was a Spanish princess
unique_questions.explanation: Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.

unique_questions.question: How is the Church of England often called?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, there is a constitutional link between Church and state. The official Church of the state is the Church of England called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States.

unique_questions.question: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country
unique_questions.explanation: At the beginning of the Middle Ages, Ireland was an independent country. The English first went to Ireland as troops to help the Irish king and remained to build their own settlements. By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin. Some of the important lords in other parts of Ireland accepted the authority of the English king.

unique_questions.question: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers began to colonise which part of the world?
unique_questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.

unique_questions.question: People living and working in towns after Black Death led to the development of what?
unique_questions.explanation: Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages. New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

unique_questions.question: In which UK country can you find the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe?
unique_questions.explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO British Actors have recently won Oscars?
unique_questions.explanation: British actors continue to be popular and continue to win awards throughout the world. Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

unique_questions.question: In which years did British Film Studios flourish?
unique_questions.explanation: British studios flourished in the 1930s. The 1950s and 1960s were a high point for British comedies, including Passport to Pimlico, The Ladykillers and, later, the Carry On films.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following was written by Lord Byron?
unique_questions.explanation: She Walks in Beauty is a short poem by Lord Byron

unique_questions.question: Which official holiday is celebrated on the 30th November in Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their patron saint's day as an official holiday. Events are held across Scotland, Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, especially where there are a lot of people of Scottish, Northern Irish and Irish heritage.

unique_questions.question: St George is the national saint of Northern Ireland
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.question: What do the Brit Awards celebrate?
unique_questions.explanation: The Brit Awards is an annual event that gives awards in a range of categories, such as best British group and best British solo artist.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How long does it take to give blood?
unique_questions.explanation: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses. Giving blood only takes about an hour to do.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of what?
unique_questions.explanation: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the local community. In England, Wales and Scotland they usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications. They receive training to do the job and are supported by a legal adviser.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for Public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

possible_answers.text: People found guilty of all criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office
People found guilty of certain criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office

correct_answers: People found guilty of certain criminal offences cannot stand for Public Office

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Only members of the public who have their name on the electoral register can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster in the House of Lords
unique_questions.explanation: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Discrimination in the workplace is a criminal offence
unique_questions.explanation: An example of civil laws are disputes over wages and cases of unfair dismissal or discrimination in the workplace.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: It is illegal for shops and businesses to not accept the banknotes of Northern Ireland and Scotland
unique_questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is considered ineligible to do jury service?
unique_questions.explanation: Everyone who is summoned to do jury service must do it unless they are not eligible (for example, because they have a criminal conviction) or they provide a good reason to be excused, such as ill health.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who gets appointed by local authorities to be the ceremonial leader of the council?
unique_questions.explanation: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What are TWO of the activities that you might be involved in when canvassing?
unique_questions.explanation: Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates - for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support. This is called 'canvassing'.

possible_answers.text: Handing out leaflets in the street
Knocking on people's doors and asking for their support
Getting paid for each vote obtained in commission
Getting paid for the time spent advertising

correct_answers: Handing out leaflets in the street
Knocking on people's doors and asking for their support

unique_questions.question: Falkland Islands are a Crown Dependency
unique_questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

unique_questions.question: The people of which age made the first coins to be minted in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The people of the Iron Age had a sophisticated culture and economy. They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings. This marks the beginnings of British history.

unique_questions.question: Who led the Scottish, in 1314, to defeat the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland, the English kings were less successful. In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO houses formed the House of Tudor?
unique_questions.explanation: King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII. Henry then married King Richard's niece, Elizabeth of York, and united the two families. Henry was the first king of the House of Tudor. The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

unique_questions.question: The Chartists are associated with the Civil War which took place in the 17th century
unique_questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote; elections every year; for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

unique_questions.question: Whose powers were increased by the Bill of Rights of 1689?
unique_questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power. Parliament took control of who could be monarch and declared that the king or queen must be a Protestant. A new Parliament had to be elected at least every three years.

unique_questions.question: During the Middle Ages, which TWO wars were fought abroad?
unique_questions.explanation: During the Middle Ages, the English kings also fought a number of wars abroad. Many knights took part in the Crusades, in which European Christians fought for control of the Holy Land. English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

possible_answers.text: During Queen Victoria's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen
During Queen Elizabeth's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen

correct_answers: During Queen Victoria's reign the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen

unique_questions.question: A 2 minutes silence is observed on Easter to commemorate the death of Jesus Christ
unique_questions.explanation: Remembrance Day, 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies. Originally it commemorated the dead of the First World War, which ended on 11 November 1918. People wear poppies (the red flower found on the battlefields of the First World War). At 11.00 am there is a two-minute silence and wreaths are laid at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, London.

unique_questions.question: When is St George's Day?
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the population has a parent or a grandparent born outside of the UK due to post-war immigration?
unique_questions.explanation: Post-war immigration means that nearly 10% of the population has a parent or grandparent born outside the UK.

unique_questions.question: Which popular yearly sporting event takes place between Oxford and Cambridge universities?
unique_questions.explanation: Rowing is also popular, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport. There is a popular yearly race on the Thames between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

unique_questions.question: Which of these TWO is correct about Halloween?
unique_questions.explanation: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play 'trick or treat'. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

possible_answers.text: It is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter
It is when lovers exchange cards and gifts
It is celebrated on the 31 October
It is not celebrated in Scotland

correct_answers: It is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter
It is celebrated on the 31 October

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Many people volunteer simply because they want to help other people
unique_questions.explanation: Volunteering and helping your community are an important part of being a good citizen. They enable you to integrate and get to know other people. It helps to make your community a better place if residents support each other.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: If you think someone is trying to persuade you to join an extremist or terrorist cause, who should you notify?
unique_questions.explanation: If you think someone is trying to persuade you to join an extremist or terrorist cause, you should notify your local police force.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What are TWO of the roles of the House of Lords?
unique_questions.explanation: The House of Lords can suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by MPs. It checks laws that have been passed by the House of Commons to ensure they are fit for purpose. It also holds the government to account to make sure that it is working in the best interests of the people.

possible_answers.text: Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing
Check laws that have been passed to ensure that they are fit for purpose
Suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by the MPs

correct_answers: Check laws that have been passed to ensure that they are fit for purpose
Suggest amendments or propose new laws, which are then discussed by the MPs

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What are TWO responsibilities of members of Parliament (MPs)?
unique_questions.explanation: MPs have a number of different responsibilities. They:; represent everyone in their constituency; ; help to create new laws; ; scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing; ; debate important national issues;

possible_answers.text: Represent only those who voted for them
They represent everyone in their constituency
Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing

correct_answers: They represent everyone in their constituency
Scrutinise and comment on what the government is doing

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Peers nominated by the Prime Minister can only serve for their lifetime
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. They have usually had an important career in politics, business, law or another profession. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you look after the environment? (Choose TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

possible_answers.text: Shop for products locally as this reduces your carbon footprint
Recycle as much as you can

correct_answers: Shop for products locally as this reduces your carbon footprint
Recycle as much as you can

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which party forms the government?
unique_questions.explanation: Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

possible_answers.text: The party with the majority of the members of Parliament (MPs)
The party appointed by the Monarch
The party with the most votes
The party which is the most popular

correct_answers: The party with the majority of the members of Parliament (MPs)

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What are TWO core values of a civil servant?
unique_questions.explanation: Civil servants are expected to carry out their role with dedication and a commitment to the civil service and its core values. These are: integrity, honesty, objectivity and impartiality

possible_answers.text: Must belong to a political party

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Local councils, in the UK, are often called local authorities
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is correct

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Forced marriages are an offence in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership. Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Members of the public are allowed to attend Youth Courts hearings
unique_questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these statements is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. They have usually had an important career in politics, business, law or another profession. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

possible_answers.text: Life peers are appointed by the Prime Minister on the advice of the monarchy
Life peers are appointed by the monarchy on the advice of the Prime Minister

correct_answers: Life peers are appointed by the monarchy on the advice of the Prime Minister

unique_questions.question: The Restoration' refers to the reestablishment of Roman Catholicism
unique_questions.explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.
