Charles II made it clear that he had 'no wish to go on his travels again'. There was a restoration of the monarchy.

unique_questions.question: Who led the invasion of England in 1066?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

unique_questions.question: Where was Anne Boleyn, the wife of Henry VIII who was accused of taking lovers, executed?
unique_questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth. Anne was unpopular in the country and was accused of taking lovers. She was executed at the Tower of London.

unique_questions.question: The Commonwealth is made up of countries which were once part of the British Empire only
unique_questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

unique_questions.question: During the civil war of 1455, what colour rose was the symbol of the House of Lancaster?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England. It was fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO of these are English civil war battles?
unique_questions.explanation: During the civil war, the king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

unique_questions.question: Why was the Habeas Corpus Act (1679) so important?
unique_questions.explanation: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for 'you must present the person in court'. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

possible_answers.text: It gave women their property rights
It gave women the right to vote
It guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully
It limited the power of the monarch

correct_answers: It guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully

unique_questions.question: What is the Giant's Causeway made of?
unique_questions.explanation: Located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland, the Giant's Causeway is a land formation of columns made from volcanic lava. It was formed about 50 million years ago. There are many legends about the Causeway and how it was formed.

unique_questions.question: Dame Ellen MacArthur is famous for her achievements in which sport?
unique_questions.explanation: Dame Ellen MacArthur (1976-) is a yachtswoman and in 2004 became the fastest person to sail around the world single handed.

unique_questions.question: Sir Kingsley Amis was a famous English novelist and poet who wrote more than 20 novels, including 'Lucky Jim'
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Kingsley Amis (1922-95) was an English novelist and poet. He wrote more than 20 novels. The most well-known is Lucky Jim.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO are famous UK sports stars?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939-) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times. Sir Chris Hoy (1976-) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO are famous British fashion designers?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain has produced many great designers, from Thomas Chippendale (who designed furniture in the 18th century) to Clarice Cliff (who designed Art Deco ceramics) to Sir Terence Conran (a 20th-century interior designer). Leading fashion designers of recent years include Mary Quant, Alexander McQueen and Vivienne Westwood.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In Youth Courts, the name or photographs of the accused young person can be published in newspapers or used by the media
unique_questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In Northern Ireland, what letter does a newly qualified driver has to display for one year after passing the test?
unique_questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an 'R' place (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these statements is incorrect?
unique_questions.explanation: Owing money is a civil offence

possible_answers.text: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin is illegal in the UK
It's a criminal offence to offend one's religion or ethnic origin
It's a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind
It's a criminal offence to owe someone money

correct_answers: It's a criminal offence to owe someone money

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the name given to the PM's country house?
unique_questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Reform Act of 1832 took away the automatic right of hereditary peers to attend the House of Lords
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. The Reform Act of 1832 had greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs and more parliamentary seats were given to the towns and cities.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you visit the Welsh Assembly?
unique_questions.explanation: The Senedd is an open building. You can book guided tours or seats in the public galleries for the Welsh Assembly. To make a booking, contact the Assembly Booking Service

possible_answers.text: By queuing at the public entrance all day

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the name of the building where the Northern Irish Assembly meets?
unique_questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland elected members, known as MLAs, meet in the Northern Ireland Assembly at Stormont, in Belfast.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who appoints the government, which most people have chosen in a democratic election?
unique_questions.explanation: The monarch does not rule the country but appoints the government, which the people have chosen in a democratic election. The monarch invites the leader of the party with the largest number of MPs, or the leader of a coalition between more than one party, to become the Prime Minister.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: Rape in a romantic relationship and marriage is considered Marital Rape. This includes forced sex and sexual assault between spouses. It is an offense.

possible_answers.text: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including her husband, can be charged with rape
Any man who forces a woman to have sex, excluding her husband, can be charged with rape

correct_answers: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including her husband, can be charged with rape

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In Northern Ireland, Deputy District Judges hear minor criminal cases
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court. In Northern Ireland, cases are heard by a District Judge or Deputy District Judge, who is legally qualified and paid.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO of these countries are currently in the EU?
unique_questions.explanation: Following a referendum held in the UK on 23 June 2016, the UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. France are Poland are still part of the EU.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.
unique_questions.explanation: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In which TWO countries were PCCs elected in?
unique_questions.explanation: In November 2012, the public elected Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) in England and Wales. These are directly elected individuals who are responsible for the delivery of an efficient and effective police force that reflects the needs of their local communities. PCCs set local police priorities and the local policing budget. They also appoint the Chief Constable.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: Those who don't respect the law should not expect to be allowed to become permanent residents
unique_questions.explanation: If you don't respect the law you should not expect to be allowed to settle in the UK

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: Which TWO of these are core values and responsibilities of the British society?
unique_questions.explanation: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities include: to obey and respect the law; to be aware of the rights of others and respect those rights; to treat others with fairness; to behave responsibly; to help and protect your family; to respect and preserve the environment; to treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, religion, age, disability, class or sexual orientation; to work to provide for yourself and your family; to help others; to vote in local and national government elections.

possible_answers.text: Always share the same views as your partner
To vote in local and national government elections
To work to provide for yourself and your family

correct_answers: To vote in local and national government elections
To work to provide for yourself and your family

unique_questions.question: What is the Church of England also known as in Scotland and the US?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, there is a constitutional link between Church and state. The official Church of the state is the Church of England (called the Anglican Church in other countries and the Episcopal Church in Scotland and the United States). It is a Protestant Church and has existed since the Reformation in the 1530s

unique_questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

unique_questions.question: Who had a great influence on the English language?
unique_questions.explanation: Shakespeare had a great influence on the English language and invented many words that are still common today.

unique_questions.question: Where were the MacDonalds of Glencoe originally from?
unique_questions.explanation: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed. The memory of this massacre meant some Scots distrusted the new government.

unique_questions.question: Which patron Saint has a white cross on a blue ground?
unique_questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground; The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground; The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

unique_questions.question: Conditions in Ireland in the 19th century were much better than in the rest of the UK
unique_questions.explanation: Conditions in Ireland were not as good as in the rest of the UK. Two-thirds of the population still depended on farming to make their living, often on very small plots of land. Many depended on potatoes as a large part of their diet. In the middle of the century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation.

unique_questions.question: The Blitz is associated which event?
unique_questions.explanation: Despite winning the Battle of Britain, the German air force was able to continue bombing London and other British cities at night-time. This was called the Blitz.

possible_answers.text: The UK and Germany bombing French cities
The UK evacuating troops from Dunkirk

unique_questions.question: James Watt was famous for his work on what?
unique_questions.explanation: James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

unique_questions.question: Christmas Day celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ
unique_questions.explanation: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

unique_questions.question: Who of the following is associated with the Bonfire Night?
unique_questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

unique_questions.question: Sir Edward Elgar is known for his famous music work - 'The Planets'
unique_questions.explanation: More recently, important composers include Gustav Holst (1874-1934), whose work includes The Planets, a suite of pieces themed around the planets of the solar system. He adapted Jupiter, part of the Planets suite, as the tune for I vow to thee my country, a popular hymn in British churches.

unique_questions.question: The Mousetrap','Jesus Christ Superstar' and 'Evita' are examples of British what?
unique_questions.explanation: They are examples of theatre plays.

unique_questions.question: Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt
unique_questions.explanation: Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt (1892-1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Women over 21 were allowed to vote for the first time in 1969
unique_questions.explanation: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often do the PM's questions take place?
unique_questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister's Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: When did newspapers begin to operate without a government licence?
unique_questions.explanation: This was also an important time for the development of a free press (newspapers and other publications which are not controlled by the government). From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence. Increasing numbers of newspapers began to be published.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO countries took part in the development of Concorde?
unique_questions.explanation: The 1960s was also a time of technological progress. Britain and France developed the world's only supersonic commercial airliner, Concorde. New styles of architecture, including high-rise buildings and the use of concrete and steel, became common.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: £10 £20 £50 £100 are the only banknotes currently allowed in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Big Ben was named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth I
unique_questions.explanation: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London. Many people call the clock Big Ben as well. The clock is over 150 years old and is a popular tourist attraction. The clock tower is named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee in 2012.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How old do you have to be to stand for election as an MP?
unique_questions.explanation: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: EEC was set up in 1957 by six countries
unique_questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After the Brexit vote to leave in 2020, there are now 27 EU member states

unique_questions.question: The Anglo-Saxons established Christianity when they invaded Britain
unique_questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons were not Christians when they first came to Britain but, during this period, missionaries came to Britain to preach about Christianity.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first Danish king in England?
unique_questions.explanation: Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also called Canute.

unique_questions.question: How long did the Hundred Years War last for?
unique_questions.explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years). One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

unique_questions.question: Who wrote the Canterbury Tales?
unique_questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage.

unique_questions.question: Queen Mary was a Protestant and persecuted Catholics (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary')
unique_questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary'). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

unique_questions.question: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, the English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in which Irish province?
unique_questions.explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders.

unique_questions.question: Which Monarch entered the House of Commons to arrest 5 parliamentary leaders?
unique_questions.explanation: Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there. (No monarch has set foot in the Commons since.) Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

unique_questions.question: When was the Emancipation Act signed? It abolished slavery throughout the British Empire
unique_questions.explanation: Along with other abolitionists (people who supported the abolition of slavery), William Wilberforce succeeded in turning public opinion against the slave trade. In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

unique_questions.question: When did the BBC begin the world's first regular TV service?
unique_questions.explanation: The BBC started radio broadcasts in 1922 and began the world's first regular television service in 1936.

unique_questions.question: Satirical magazines began to be published in the 19th century. When was 'Punch' first published?
unique_questions.explanation: Punch' was published for the first time in the 1840s

unique_questions.question: Britain became fully democratic in the 19th century
unique_questions.explanation: The UK has had a fully democratic voting system since 1928 (20th century). The present voting age of 18 was set in 1969 and (with a few exceptions) all UK-born and naturalised adult citizens have the right to vote.

unique_questions.question: Who was made a Dame of the British Empire in 2000?
unique_questions.explanation: Born in Manchester, Mary Peters moved to Northern Ireland as a child. She was a talented athlete who won an Olympic gold medal in the pentathlon in 1972. After this, she raised money for local athletics and became the team manager for the women's British Olympic team. She continues to promote sport and tourism in Northern Ireland and was made a Dame of the British Empire in 2000 in recognition of her work.

unique_questions.question: What is the percentage of Sikh living in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 2021 England and Wales census, around 525,000 (0.9%) people from the sampled population of 60 million identified as Sikh. 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (6.5%), Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

unique_questions.question: The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for the whole lifetime to speak on behalf of that Church.
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

unique_questions.question: The Patron Saints' days are NOT public holidays in which TWO countries?
unique_questions.explanation: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their Patron Saint's day as an official holiday. While the Patron Saints' days are no longer public holidays in England and Wales, they are still celebrated. Parades and small festivals are held all over the two countries.

unique_questions.question: Mothering Sunday is the third Sunday in June
unique_questions.explanation: Mothering Sunday (or Mother's Day) is the Sunday three weeks before Easter. Children send cards or buy gifts for their mothers.

unique_questions.question: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games three times. When did the UK host the games in the 20th century? (Choose TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London. The British team was very successful, across a wide range of Olympic sports, finishing third in the medal table.

unique_questions.question: Which of these athletes is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming?
unique_questions.explanation: Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games.

unique_questions.question: When did motor-car racing start in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Motor-car racing in the UK started in 1902. The UK continues to be a world leader in the development and manufacture of motor-sport technology. A Formula 1 Grand Prix event is held in the UK each year and a number of British Grand Prix drivers have won the Formula 1 World Championship. Recent British winners include Damon Hill, Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button.

unique_questions.question: People over 70 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 75% discount
unique_questions.explanation: People over 75 can apply for a free TV licence and blind people can get a 50% discount. You will receive a fine of up to £1,000 if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

unique_questions.question: Where can you find Crown Jewels?
unique_questions.explanation: The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066. Tours are given by the Yeoman Warders, also known as Beefeaters, who tell visitors about the building's history. People can also see the Crown Jewels there.

unique_questions.question: How is the Queen Elizabeth II's husband, Prince Philip, often called?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952, in 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. She was married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, Prince Charles (the Prince of Wales) became the sovereign monarch in 2022.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: All Acts of Parliament are made in who's name?
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the King makes a speech which summarises the government’s policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who appoints life peers to the House of Lords?
unique_questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

unique_questions.question: When did the Wars of the Roses end with the Battle of Bosworth?
unique_questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

unique_questions.question: What were the first Women's Social and Political Union group members called?
unique_questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst (1858-1928) was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called 'suffragettes'.

unique_questions.question: In the middle of the 19th century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine
unique_questions.explanation: In the middle of the 19th century the potato crop failed, and Ireland suffered a famine. A million people died from disease and starvation. Another million and a half left Ireland.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The jury decides whether a person is 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard
unique_questions.explanation: The jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of 'guilty' or 'not guilty' based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of 'not proven' is also possible. If the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty. The judge is only responsible for interpreting the law.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What destroyed London in year 1666?
unique_questions.explanation: During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul's Cathedral.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO things are you required to have to apply for ILR or British Citizenship?
unique_questions.explanation: In order to apply for ILR or Naturalization as a British Citizen you must have a valid life in the UK pass certificate and good knowledge of English language

possible_answers.text: A relative in the UK with a British Passport
A Life in the UK pass certificate

unique_questions.explanation: You should accept all responsibilities that come with permanent residency and fundamental principles of British life

To remain in the UK forever
To respect the law, values and traditions of the UK

correct_answers: To accept the responsibilities which come with 'Settlement'
To respect the law, values and traditions of the UK

unique_questions.question: Where is Sutton Hoo?
unique_questions.explanation: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth.

unique_questions.question: You should respect someone's right in court. In return, you are offered the right to a fair trial.
unique_questions.explanation: You should always respect everyone rights in court. Vise versa everyone should respect your rights.

unique_questions.question: The UK is a diverse and dynamic nation which welcomes those who want to make a positive contribution to the society
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is a diverse and welcoming country. It welcomes those who want to make a positive contribution to the society

unique_questions.question: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 established the idea that the British Empire is a force for good
unique_questions.explanation: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers. The Boers fought fiercely and the war went on for over three years. Many died in the fighting and many more from disease. There was some public sympathy for the Boers and people began to question whether the Empire could continue.

unique_questions.question: Which process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways?
unique_questions.explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways. Manufacturing jobs became the main source of employment in Britain.

unique_questions.question: The Protestants formed their own churches during the Reformation
unique_questions.explanation: At the same time the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church. The Protestants formed their own churches. They read the Bible in their own languages instead of in Latin; they did not pray to saints or at shrines; and they believed that a person's own relationship with God was more important than submitting to the authority of the Church. Protestant ideas gradually gained strength in England, Wales and Scotland during the 16th century.

unique_questions.question: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait
unique_questions.explanation: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the Former Republic of Yugoslavia. Since 2000, British armed forces have been engaged in the global fight against international terrorism and against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.

unique_questions.question: The Domesday Book gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest
unique_questions.explanation: William the Conqueror (the Duke of Normandy) sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

unique_questions.question: Which of these countries did NOT fight on the side of the Allied Powers during the First World War?
unique_questions.explanation: The Allies fought against the Central Powers - mainly Germany, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, the Ottoman Empire and later Bulgaria.

unique_questions.question: In the Church of Scotland, who is the Moderator?
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

possible_answers.text: The chairperson of the General Assembly, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of the Church
A key figure who is responsible for all relations with the Church of England
A financial overseer who has overall responsibility for the accounts of the Church
The spiritual leader of the Church, who is appointed for life

correct_answers: The chairperson of the General Assembly, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of the Church

unique_questions.question: What is the second biggest country in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Scotland has the second highest population and area.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who invented the Jet Engine?
unique_questions.explanation: The Jet Engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907-96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

unique_questions.question: It is a criminal offence to owe money to someone and you might be taken to court
unique_questions.explanation: Owing money is a civil offence

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO principles are included in the European Convention on Human Rights?
unique_questions.explanation: Some of the principles included in the European Convention on Human Rights are: right to life; prohibition of torture; prohibition of slavery and forced labour; right to liberty and security; right to a fair trial; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of expression (speech).

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18-75 can be asked to serve on a jury
unique_questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 75 can be asked to do this. The age limit has been raised from 70 to 75 in Wales and England in 2016.

unique_questions.question: Great Britain' and 'the United Kingdom' have the same meaning
unique_questions.explanation: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: If you wish to be a permanent resident of the UK, you should look after yourself. In return you are guaranteed a job
unique_questions.explanation: You are not guaranteed a job if you settle in the UK.

unique_questions.question: Which country (or colony) did NOT gain its independence from the British Empire in 1947?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). Other colonies in Africa, the Caribbean (e.g. The British West Indies) and the Pacific achieved independence over the next 20 years.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following is associated with the Elizabethan period in England?
unique_questions.explanation: The Elizabethan period in England was a time of growing patriotism: a feeling of pride in being English. The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.

unique_questions.question: Wales wasn't under Anglo-Saxon rule
unique_questions.explanation: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

unique_questions.question: The Boer War took place in which country of the British Empire?
unique_questions.explanation: The Boer War of 1899 to 1902 made the discussions about the future of the Empire more urgent. The British went to war in South Africa with settlers from the Netherlands called the Boers.

unique_questions.question: Magna Carta is Latin for what?
unique_questions.explanation: In Latin Magna Carta means the Great Charter

unique_questions.question: When did the first farmers start settling in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago. The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe. These people built houses, tombs and monuments on the land.

unique_questions.question: Other than London universities, which university was credited with the discovery of the DNA molecule in 1953?
unique_questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime. Francis Crick (1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

unique_questions.question: Which novel is the satirical novelist Evelyn Waugh best known for?
unique_questions.explanation: Evelyn Waugh (1903-66) wrote satirical novels, including Decline and Fall and Scoop. He is perhaps best known for Brideshead Revisited.

unique_questions.question: What followed the Bronze Age?
unique_questions.explanation: The Bronze Age was followed by the Iron Age, when people learned how to make weapons and tools out of iron.

unique_questions.question: Who was Catherine of Aragon (the first of Henry VIII's six wives)?
unique_questions.explanation: Catherine was a Spanish princess. She and Henry had a number of children but only one, Mary, survived. When Catherine was too old to give him another child, Henry decided to divorce her, hoping that another wife would give him a son to be his heir.

unique_questions.question: In 1982, which country invaded the Falklands prompting UK to send its naval force in defense?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic. A naval task force was sent from the UK and military action led to the recovery of the islands.

unique_questions.question: Rudyard Kipling was born in South Africa
unique_questions.explanation: Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. He wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

unique_questions.question: Who is the author of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'?
unique_questions.explanation: Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. His best-known works include Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and George's Marvellous Medicine.

unique_questions.question: The invasion of which country by Germany provoked UK to declare war on Germany in 1939?
unique_questions.explanation: When Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

unique_questions.question: When did the American Colonies declare their independence?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.

unique_questions.question: What are the parliaments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also known as?
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. These powers are also known as devolved administrations.

unique_questions.question: In which year was Britain's first woman Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, elected to join the parliament of United Kingdom?
unique_questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher was the daughter of a grocer from Grantham in Lincolnshire. She trained as a chemist and lawyer. She was elected as a Conservative MP in 1959 and became a cabinet minister in 1970 as the Secretary of State for Education and Science. In 1975 she was elected as Leader of the Conservative Party and so became Leader of the Opposition.

unique_questions.question: What is Diwali?
unique_questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

unique_questions.question: Charles Dickens, Thomas Hardy and Jane Austen are famous writers
unique_questions.explanation: They are all famous authors and writers.

unique_questions.question: As per 2021 census, what is the percentage of Muslims living in England and Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Islam is the second largest religion in the United Kingdom. The 2021 Census results released so far show a population of 3,868,133 (6.5%) in England and Wales (from a total sampled 60 million). 46% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Hindu (2%), Sikh (1%), Jewish or Buddhist (both around 0.5%), 0.5% of people followed another religion and 37% stated not to follow any religion.

unique_questions.question: What percentage of the workforce are women?
unique_questions.explanation: Women in Britain today make up about half of the workforce. On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. More women than men study at university.

unique_questions.question: How many Olympic gold medals has the Scottish cyclist, Sir Chris Hoy, won?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Chris Hoy (1976-) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

unique_questions.question: What service does the TV licence pay for?
unique_questions.explanation: The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC).

unique_questions.question: The Channel Islands are self-governing
unique_questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

unique_questions.question: In which country was Charles II residing before he was invited to England by the Parliament?
unique_questions.explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Who directed the British movie the Belles of St Trinian's in 1954?
unique_questions.explanation: The Belles of St Trinian's (1954) was directed by Frank Launder

unique_questions.question: What religion did Queen Elizabeth I practise?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I was a Protestant. She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England. Everyone had to attend their local church and there were laws about the type of religious services and the prayers which could be said, but Elizabeth did not ask about people's real beliefs. She succeeded in finding a balance between the views of Catholics and the more extreme Protestants.

unique_questions.question: At what age did Queen Victoria become Queen of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years. At the date of writing (2013) this is the longest reign of any British monarch. Her reign is known as the Victorian Age.

unique_questions.question: During the Victorian period, transport link improved, enabling goods and people to move easily around the country
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true

unique_questions.question: What is the name of the song sung by people in the UK and other countries when celebrating the New Year?
unique_questions.explanation: One of the songs sung by people in the UK at New Year is Auld Lang Syne.

unique_questions.question: During the WWII, the evacuation of more than 300,000 British and French soldiers from France gave rise to which phrase?
unique_questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. Although many lives and a lot of equipment were lost, the evacuation was a success and meant that Britain was better able to continue the fight against the Germans. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

unique_questions.question: Which government was elected in 1945?
unique_questions.explanation: Clement Attlee was Winston Churchill's Deputy Prime Minister in the wartime coalition government and became Prime Minister after the Labour Party won the 1945 election. He was Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951 and led the Labour Party for 20 years. Attlee's government undertook the nationalisation of major industries (like coal and steel), created the National Health Service and implemented many of Beveridge's plans for a stronger welfare state.

unique_questions.question: In which year did John Logie Baird make the first TV broadcast between Glasgow and London?
unique_questions.explanation: The television was developed by Scotsman John Logie Baird (1888-1946) in the 1920s. In 1932 he made the first television broadcast between London and Glasgow.

unique_questions.question: Who was the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
unique_questions.explanation: Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland, and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
unique_questions.explanation: The king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby. By 1646, it was clear that Parliament had won the war. Charles was held prisoner by the parliamentary army. He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

possible_answers.text: Charles I's army was defeated at the Battle of Marston Moor but won the Battle of Naseby
Parliament won the English Civil War

correct_answers: Parliament won the English Civil War

unique_questions.question: What is Sir Isaac Newton's famous published work?
unique_questions.explanation: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ('Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow

unique_questions.question: In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London?
unique_questions.explanation: During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas. The following year, a great fire destroyed much of the city, including many churches and St Paul's Cathedral.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO countries took part in the Battle of Agincourt?
unique_questions.explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years). One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

unique_questions.question: The Welsh Dragon doesn't appear on the Union Flag because Wales was already united with England in 1606
unique_questions.explanation: The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

unique_questions.question: What language did the peasants speak after the Norman conquest?
unique_questions.explanation: The Middle Ages saw the development of a national culture and identity. After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO industries developed during the Great Depression?
unique_questions.explanation: During the Great Depression (1929),he traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries - including the automobile and aviation industries - developed.

unique_questions.question: What was the system of land ownership used by the Normans known as?
unique_questions.explanation: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism. The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war. Landowners had to send certain numbers of men to serve in the army. Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.

unique_questions.question: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, where did the English government encourage Scottish and English Protestants to settle?
unique_questions.explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders. These settlements were known as plantations.

unique_questions.question: Who will remain the longest reigning monarch until 9 September 2015?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years. Her reign is known as the Victorian Age. On September 9 2015, Queen Elizabeth II will pass the record set by her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are minor criminal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland heard?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What did the Beveridge Report of 1942, by William Beveridge, provide the basis for?
unique_questions.explanation: William Beveridge (later Lord Beveridge) was a British economist and social reformer. He served briefly as a Liberal MP and was subsequently the leader of the Liberals in the House of Lords but is best known for the 1942 report Social Insurance and Allied Services (known as the Beveridge Report). The report was commissioned by the wartime government in 1941. It recommended that the government should find ways of fighting the five 'Giant Evils' of Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness and provided the basis of the modern welfare state.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Opposition is the second largest party in the House of Commons
unique_questions.explanation: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the Opposition. The leader of the Opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election.

unique_questions.question: What is the name of the first major railway built in Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Great Western Railway is the name of the first major railway built in Britain.

unique_questions.question: Who founded a monastery on the Island of Iona?
unique_questions.explanation: Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland, and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

unique_questions.question: What were the Irish people who favoured complete independence from the UK known as?
unique_questions.explanation: The Irish Nationalist movement had grown strongly through the 19th century. Some, such as the Fenians, favoured complete independence.

unique_questions.question: Which architectural style are the famous London buildings of the 19th century, such as the House of Parliament and St Pancras Station, associated with?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 19th century, the medieval 'gothic' style became popular again. As cities expanded, many great public buildings were built in this style. The Houses of Parliament and St Pancras Station were built at this time, as were the town halls in cities such as Manchester and Sheffield.

unique_questions.question: What name is given to the official flag that represents the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack.

unique_questions.question: Which prehistoric monument still stands in the English county of Wiltshire?
unique_questions.explanation: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

unique_questions.question: Which religion did the Huguenots follow?
unique_questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion. Many were educated and skilled and worked as scientists, in banking, or in weaving or other crafts.

unique_questions.question: What was the more probable use for the Stonehenge?
unique_questions.explanation: Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire. Stonehenge was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

possible_answers.text: A special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

correct_answers: A special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies

unique_questions.question: Who is credited with the introduction of the National Health Service (NHS) in 1948?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use

unique_questions.question: James VI of Scotland was not related to Queen Elizabeth I of England
unique_questions.explanation: Mary was suspected of murdering her husband and fled to England. She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland. Mary was Elizabeth I's cousin.

unique_questions.question: Which of these international events was held in London in 2012?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK has hosted the Olympic Games on three occasions: 1908, 1948 and 2012. The Paralympic Games for 2012 were also hosted in London.

unique_questions.question: Which of these flowers is closely associated with Remembrance Day?
unique_questions.explanation: The poppy has become the symbol of Remembrance worn during the weeks leading to Remembrance Sunday and Armistice Day.

unique_questions.question: What is a traditional pub game?
unique_questions.explanation: Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

unique_questions.question: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes valid everywhere in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

unique_questions.question: Who governs the Church of Scotland?
unique_questions.explanation: In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is a Presbyterian Church. It is governed by ministers and elders. The chairperson of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is the Moderator, who is appointed for one year only and often speaks on behalf of that Church.

unique_questions.question: What is the currency used in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound.

unique_questions.question: Where is the Royal Crescent is located?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 18th century, simpler designs became popular. The Scottish architect Robert Adam influenced the development of architecture in the UK, Europe and America. He designed the inside decoration as well as the building itself in great houses such as Dumfries House in Scotland. His ideas influenced architects in cities such as Bath, where the Royal Crescent was built.

unique_questions.question: Select TWO famous Paralympians
unique_questions.explanation: Baroness Tanni-Grey Thompson (1969-) is an athlete who uses a wheelchair and won 16 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold medals, in races over five Paralympic Games. She won the London Marathon six times and broke a total of 30 world records. Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which political party is still known as the Tories?
unique_questions.explanation: The modern Conservative Party is still sometimes referred to as the Tories

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of the following statements does NOT apply to the United Nations?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security. There are 15 members on the UN Security Council, which recommends action when there are international crises and threats to peace. The UK is one of five permanent members of the Security Council.

possible_answers.text: The UN has five members in total
It was set up after the Second World War
The UK is one of five permanent members of the UN Security Council

correct_answers: The UN has five members in total

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What can the Laws made by the EU also be called?
unique_questions.explanation: EU law is legally binding in the UK and all the other EU member states. European laws are called directives, regulations or framework decisions.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What does the abbreviation PTA stand for?
unique_questions.explanation: Sometimes school events are organised by parent-teacher associations (PTAs)

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who can stand for office as a Local Councillor?
unique_questions.explanation: British citizens can stand for Office as a local councillor, a member of Parliament (or the devolved equivalents). This is an opportunity to become even more involved in the political life of the UK. You may also be able to stand for Office if you are an Irish citizen, or an eligible Commonwealth citizen.

possible_answers.text: British, Irish and Eligible Commonwealth citizens
British citizens of the UK only

correct_answers: British, Irish and Eligible Commonwealth citizens

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of these drugs can you buy or sell legally in UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Selling or buying drugs such as heroin, cocaine, ecstasy and cannabis is illegal in the UK.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Pressure groups and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy
unique_questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO of these are associated with Sir Francis Drake?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition. His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.

unique_questions.question: Robert Browning, William Blake and Lord Byron were all famous poets
unique_questions.explanation: The statement is true

unique_questions.question: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome. Where did he spread Christianity?
unique_questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons were not Christians when they first came to Britain but, during this period, missionaries came to Britain to preach about Christianity. Missionaries from Ireland spread the religion in the north. The most famous of these were St Patrick, who would become the patron saint of Ireland and St Columba, who founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland. St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

unique_questions.question: Which sport often refers to the phrase 'rain stopped play'?
unique_questions.explanation: You may come across expressions such as 'rain stopped play', 'batting on a sticky wicket', 'playing a straight bat', 'bowled a googly' or 'it's just not cricket', which have passed into everyday usage. The most famous cricket competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

unique_questions.question: Who, in 1810 opened the first curry house in Britain called 'The Hindoostane Coffee House' in George Street, London?
