unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Speaker is an MP, he/she represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP
unique_questions.explanation: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents' problems like any other MP.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What are elected members of the National Assembly of Wales known as?
unique_questions.explanation: In Wales the elected members, known as AMs, meet in the Welsh Assembly in the Senedd in Cardiff Bay

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In which year did the UK join the European Union (EU)?
unique_questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Civil servants cannot stand for Office
unique_questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public Office. There are some exceptions, including: members of the armed forces; civil servants; people found guilty of certain criminal offences.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Speaker is elected by fellow MPs using the open ballot system
unique_questions.explanation: The Speaker is chosen by other MPs in a secret ballot.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the minimum age for serving on a jury?
unique_questions.explanation: As well as getting the right to vote, people on the electoral register are randomly selected to serve on a jury. Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18 to 70 can be asked to do this.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO are safe places to go and stay in for anyone facing domestic violence?
unique_questions.explanation: It is important for anyone facing domestic violence to get help as soon as possible. A solicitor or the Citizens Advice Bureau can explain the available options. In some areas there are safe places to go and stay in, called refuges or shelters.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: People who are self-employed need to pay National Insurance Contributions themselves
unique_questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The role and membership of the House of Lords has changed over the last 50 years
unique_questions.explanation: The role and membership of the House of Lords has changed over the last 50 years.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Monarch appoints the members of the Cabinet
unique_questions.explanation: The Prime Minister (PM) is the leader of the political party in power. He or she appoints the members of the Cabinet and has control over many important public appointments.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland
unique_questions.explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

unique_questions.question: What religion were Puritans?
unique_questions.explanation: Puritans, a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship.

unique_questions.question: The Swinging Sixties was a period of new ideas about politics, philosophy and science
unique_questions.explanation: he decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as 'the Swinging Sixties'. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. People started to become better off and many bought cars and other consumer goods. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland.

unique_questions.question: Catherine Howard was Anne Boleyn's cousin
unique_questions.explanation: Catherine was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

unique_questions.question: What is the name given to rented additional land which people use to grow fruit and vegetable?
unique_questions.explanation: A lot of people have gardens at home and will spend their free time looking after them. Some people rent additional land called 'an allotment', where they grow fruit and vegetables. Gardening and flower shows range from major national exhibitions to small local events.

unique_questions.question: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to
unique_questions.explanation: Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to. It reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God. Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during this festival. In Britain this has to be done in a slaughterhouse.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO are associated with a Bank Holiday?
unique_questions.explanation: Bank holidays are public holidays, when banks and many other businesses are closed for the day.

possible_answers.text: A day when most people have an official day off
A holiday which is always on a Monday
A day off for all the banks in the country

correct_answers: A day when most people have an official day off

unique_questions.question: Eid al-Fitr and Eid ul Adha are festivals celebrated by which religion?
unique_questions.explanation: Eid al-Fitr celebrates the end of Ramadan, when Muslims have fasted for a month. They thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast. The date when it takes place changes every year. Muslims attend special services and meals. Eid ul Adha remembers that the prophet Ibrahim was willing to sacrifice his son when God ordered him to. It reminds Muslims of their own commitment to God. Many Muslims sacrifice an animal to eat during this festival. In Britain this has to be done in a slaughterhouse.

unique_questions.question: What type of literature are 'The Canterbury Tales' written by Geoffrey Chaucer?
unique_questions.explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales. It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press. Many of the stories are still popular. Some have been made into plays and television programmes.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO are associated with rugby?
unique_questions.explanation: The most famous rugby union competition is the Six Nations Championship between England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France and Italy. The Super League is the most well-known rugby league (club) competition.

unique_questions.question: Which famous poet's work was inspired by Nature?
unique_questions.explanation: Other poets, including William Wordsworth, were inspired by nature. Sir Walter Scott wrote poems inspired by Scotland and the traditional stories and songs from the area on the borders of Scotland and England. He also wrote novels, many of which were set in Scotland.

unique_questions.question: Sir Ian Botham is famous for his achievements in which sport?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Ian Botham (1955-) captained the English cricket team and holds a number of English Test cricket records, both for batting and for bowling.

unique_questions.question: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.question: The UK has a declining elderly population
unique_questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How are members of Parliament (MPs) elected?
unique_questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. In each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected. The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO are major political parties in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The Conservative Party, the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats are big political parties

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Commonwealth can suspend any of its members
unique_questions.explanation: Membership is voluntary. The Commonwealth has no power over its members, although it can suspend membership.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Arranged marriages are allowed in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: A marriage should be entered into with the full and free consent of both people involved. Arranged marriages, where both parties agree to the marriage, are acceptable in the UK.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The Scottish Parliament has 33 members
unique_questions.explanation: There are 129 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), elected by a form of proportional representation. The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters which are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who can nominate life peers? (Select TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. They also include people nominated by the leaders of the other main political parties or by an independent Appointments Commission for non-party peers.

possible_answers.text: Leaders of other main political parties

correct_answers: Leaders of other main political parties

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The European Union was originally called the EEC
unique_questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service
unique_questions.explanation: The devolved administrations each have their own civil service.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The name or photograph of cases heard in the Youth Court can be published in the newspapers once the young person has been found guilty
unique_questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the name of the charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often is the electoral register updated?
unique_questions.explanation: The electoral register is updated every year in September or October. An electoral registration form is sent to every household and this has to be completed and returned with the names of everyone who is resident in the household and eligible to vote.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following is a William Wordsworth's poem?
unique_questions.explanation: All 4 options are poems, but all written by different poets.(Robert Browning, 1812-89 'Home Thoughts from Abroad'), (Lord Byron, 1788-1824 'She Walks in Beauty'), (William Blake, 1757-1827 'The Tyger'), (William Wordsworth, 1770-1850 'The Daffodils' - 'I wander'd lonely as a cloud, That floats on high o'er vales and hills, When all at once I saw a crowd, A host of golden daffodils').

unique_questions.question: Which Armed Force was used in the Battle of Britain?
unique_questions.explanation: The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called 'the Battle of Britain', in the summer of 1940. The most important planes used by the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain were the Spitfire and the Hurricane - which were designed and built in Britain.

unique_questions.question: In 1745, who was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland. He was supported by clansmen from the Scottish highlands and raised an army. Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746. Charles escaped back to Europe.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Complaints against the Police can only be made by writing to the Police Complaints Commissioner
unique_questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body: the Independent Police Complaints Commission in England and Wales, the Police Complaints Commissioner for Scotland or the Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Which comedy double act by Nick Park won many Oscars?
unique_questions.explanation: Nick Park, who has won four Oscars for his animated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: It is compulsory to join National Citizen Service programme for 16 and 17 year olds
unique_questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

unique_questions.question: Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. What was this known as?
unique_questions.explanation: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle. Evictions became very common in the early 19th century. Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which of the statements is true?
unique_questions.explanation: Solicitors' charges are usually based on how much time they spend on a case. It is very important to find out at the start how much a case is likely to cost.

possible_answers.text: Solicitors' charges are based on how serious the case is
Solicitors' charges are based on how much time they spend on a case

correct_answers: Solicitors' charges are based on how much time they spend on a case

unique_questions.question: In year 1066, William the Conqueror invaded England in which battle?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

unique_questions.question: What was the name of the movement which protested against the Roman Catholic church during Henry VIII's time?
unique_questions.explanation: During Henry III's reign, the Reformation was happening across Europe. This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

unique_questions.question: What are traditional pub games? (Select TWO)
unique_questions.explanation: Most communities will have a 'local' pub that is a natural focal point for social activities. Pub quizzes are popular. Pool and darts are traditional pub games.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What area is the Home Secretary responsible for?
unique_questions.explanation: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments. These include: Chancellor of the Exchequer: responsible for the economy; Home Secretary:responsible for crime, policing and immigration; Foreign Secretary: responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries; other ministers (called 'Secretaries of State') are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Northern Ireland has its own banknotes which are valid everywhere in the UK
unique_questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

unique_questions.question: Where was Rudyard Kipling born?
unique_questions.explanation: Rudyard Kipling was born in India in 1865 and later lived in India, the UK and the USA. He wrote books and poems set in both India and the UK. His poems and novels reflected the idea that the British Empire was a force for good. Kipling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907.

unique_questions.question: What is known as 'canvassing'?
unique_questions.explanation: Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates - for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support.

possible_answers.text: Persuade people to vote for the party you represent
Filling in the ballot paper for those who cannot do it themselves

correct_answers: Persuade people to vote for the party you represent

unique_questions.question: The band called Beatles was popular and some alteration to social laws occurred during which period?
unique_questions.explanation: The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as 'the Swinging Sixties'. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music. Two well-known pop music groups at the time were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. It was also a time when social laws were liberalised, for example in relation to divorce and to abortion in England, Wales and Scotland. The position of women in the workplace also improved.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Wales and Scotland use a system called 'individual registration'.All those entitled to vote must complete their own registration forms
unique_questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland a system called 'individual registration' operates and all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form. Once registered, people stay on the register provided their personal details do not change.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are all minor criminal cases heard in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What country did Hitler invade in 1939?
unique_questions.explanation: The British government tried to avoid another war. However, when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

unique_questions.question: Who is Sir Edward Elgar(1857-1934)?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Edward Elgar (1857-1934) was born in Worcester, England. His best-known work is probably the Pomp and Circumstance Marches. March No 1 (Land of Hope and Glory) is usually played at the Last Night of the Proms at the Royal Albert Hall.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: National Trust is a charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside
unique_questions.explanation: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

unique_questions.question: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690. This event is celebrated in which country?
unique_questions.explanation: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Every MP in the UK has his/her own constituency
unique_questions.explanation: Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs from the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is a good way to support your local community?
unique_questions.explanation: A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

possible_answers.text: Shop for products locally where you can

correct_answers: Shop for products locally where you can

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which TWO are some of the key roles of Governors and school boards?
unique_questions.explanation: Governors and school boards have an important part to play in raising school standards. They have three key roles: setting the strategic direction of the school; ensuring accountability; monitoring and evaluating school performance.

unique_questions.question: Which is a famous area in London for theatres?
unique_questions.explanation: There are theaters in most towns and cities throughout the UK, ranging from the large to the small. They are an important part of local communities and often show both professional and amateur productions. London's West End, also known as 'Theatreland', is particularly well known. The Mousetrap, a murder-mystery play by Dame Agatha Christie, has been running in the West End since 1952 and has had the longest initial run of any show in history.

unique_questions.question: What was the longest British War with France called?
unique_questions.explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years). One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French. The English left France in the 1450s.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The anthem 'God save the King/Queen' can only be played in presence of the Monarch
unique_questions.explanation: You can play the Anthem in anyone's presence

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What should you do to make a complaint about the Police?
unique_questions.explanation: Anyone can make a complaint about the police by going to a police station or writing to the Chief Constable of the police force involved. Complaints can also be made to an independent body: the Independent Police Complaints Commission in England and Wales, the Police Complaints Commissioner for Scotland or the Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland.

possible_answers.text: Write to the Chief Constable of the Police force
Write a complaint letter to the House of Commons
Complain to the Police force directly

correct_answers: Write to the Chief Constable of the Police force

unique_questions.question: What character did Charlie Chaplin play?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Charles (Charlie) Chaplin became famous in silent movies for his tramp character and was one of many British actors to make a career in Hollywood.

unique_questions.question: Women over 30 were allowed to vote as a result of their contribution towards the war effort. Which war was it?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights and the right to stand for Parliament, partly in recognition of the contribution women made to the war effort during the First World War. Shortly before Emmeline's death in 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

unique_questions.question: Who ran 1 mile in 4 minutes in 1954?
unique_questions.explanation: Sir Roger Bannister (1929-) was the first man in the world to run a mile in under four minutes, in 1954.

unique_questions.question: What was Isaac Newton famous for?
unique_questions.explanation: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica (Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe. Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow. Many of his discoveries are still important for modern science.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which one is not a valid UK coin?
unique_questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

unique_questions.question: Nick Park created the 'Wallace and Gromit' film. What kind of film was it?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain continues to be particularly strong in special effects and animation. One example is the work of Nick Park, who has won four Oscars for his animated films, including three for films featuring Wallace and Gromit.

unique_questions.question: What is the Cenotaph associated with?
unique_questions.explanation: After the First World War, Sir Edwin Lutyens was responsible for many war memorials throughout the world, including the Cenotaph in Whitehall. The Cenotaph is the site of the annual Remembrance Day service attended by the Queen/King, politicians and foreign ambassadors

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What's the Monarch's yearly parliamentary speech for?
unique_questions.explanation: The King has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Monarch makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in his name.

possible_answers.text: Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year
Give advice to the general public on upcoming legislations
Summarise all of the last year's policies

correct_answers: Set out the government's legislative plans for the next year

unique_questions.question: The BBC is controlled by the UK government
unique_questions.explanation: The BBC is the largest broadcaster in the world. It is the only wholly state-funded media organisation that is independent of government. Other UK channels are primarily funded through advertisements and subscriptions.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the money limit for the small claims procedure in England and Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £5,000 in Northern Ireland (Changed from £3000).

unique_questions.question: Admiral Nelson died in which battle?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

unique_questions.question: What is the geographic position of the UK in Europe?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is located in the North West of Europe.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What's the objective of the Commonwealth?
unique_questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined.

possible_answers.text: Achieve goals in democracy and development
Allow visa free migration across the member states

correct_answers: Achieve goals in democracy and development

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you arrange to get a National Insurance number?
unique_questions.explanation: If you have permission to work in the UK, you will need to telephone the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) to arrange to get a National Insurance number.

possible_answers.text: Contact the Department for Work and Pensions

correct_answers: Contact the Department for Work and Pensions

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy
unique_questions.explanation: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs from the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What is your responsibility as UK citizen? Select TWO answers.
unique_questions.explanation: Although Britain is one of the world's most diverse societies, there is a set of shared values and responsibilities that everyone can agree with. These values and responsibilities include: to obey and respect the law; to be aware of the rights of others and respect those rights; to treat others with fairness; to behave responsibly; to help and protect your family; to respect and preserve the environment; to treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, religion, age, disability, class or sexual orientation; to work to provide for yourself and your family; to help others; to vote in local and national government elections.

possible_answers.text: To vote in local and national government elections
To go to your local pub
To help and protect your family

correct_answers: To vote in local and national government elections
To help and protect your family

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: You have to be 21 years old to stand as an MP
unique_questions.explanation: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties. These are the Conservative Party, the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats, or one of the parties representing Scottish, Welsh or Northern Irish interests.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO of the athletes are paralympians?
unique_questions.explanation: Ellie Simmonds (1994-) is a Paralympian who won gold medals for swimming at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympic Games and holds a number of world records. She was the youngest member of the British team at the 2008 Games. David Weir (1979-) is a Paralympian who uses a wheelchair and has won six gold medals over two Paralympic Games. He has also won the London Marathon six times.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Where are the minor criminal cases dealt with in England, Wales and N. Ireland?
unique_questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

unique_questions.question: The King Charles III's eldest son, Prince William, is also known as?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned since her father's death in 1952, (she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee i.e. 60 years as queen) until she passed away in 2022. She was married to Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. Her eldest son, King Charles III (previously known as the Prince of Wales) became the sovereign monarch in 2022. His eldest son, heir to the throne, Prince William is the new Prince of Wales.

unique_questions.question: Who was the Prime minister and inspiration leader during the World War Two?
unique_questions.explanation: Churchill was the son of a politician and, before becoming a Conservative MP in 1900, was a soldier and journalist. In May 1940 he became Prime Minister. He refused to surrender to the Nazis and was an inspirational leader to the British people in a time of great hardship. He lost the General Election in 1945 but returned as Prime Minister in 1951.

unique_questions.question: What lead the American colonies to declare their independence?
unique_questions.explanation: By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America. The colonies were wealthy and largely in control of their own affairs. Many of the colonist families had originally gone to North America in order to have religious freedom. They were well educated and interested in ideas of liberty. The British government wanted to tax the colonies.

possible_answers.text: The UK not providing enough health care
The UK not sending enough money
The UK wanting to tax the colonies
The UK wanting to stop the slave trade

correct_answers: The UK wanting to tax the colonies

unique_questions.question: Which battle did William the Conqueror fight in?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror. The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

unique_questions.question: Queen Elizabeth I was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants
unique_questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary'). Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How often do PM's Questions take place in the parliament?
unique_questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government's failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister's Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting.

unique_questions.question: What did Sir Frank Whittle invent in the 1930s?
unique_questions.explanation: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907-96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The UK government hasn't used the power to suspend the Northern Ireland Assembly
unique_questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999. There is also a Northern Ireland Assembly, although this has been suspended on a few occasions.

unique_questions.question: The Man Booker Prize is awarded in which area?
unique_questions.explanation: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually for the best fiction novel written by an author from the Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. It has been awarded since 1968. Past winners include Ian McEwan, Hilary Mantel and Julian Barnes.

unique_questions.question: Name the most famous cricket competition, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia
unique_questions.explanation: The most famous competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

unique_questions.question: Which film or film franchise produced in UK has been the biggest gross earner?
unique_questions.explanation: Many of the films now produced in the UK are made by foreign companies, using British expertise. Some of the most commercially successful films of all time, including the two highest-grossing film franchises (Harry Potter and James Bond), have been produced in the UK.

unique_questions.question: When did the English settlers first begin to colonise the eastern coast of America?
unique_questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I's time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America. This colonisation, particularly by people who disagreed with the religious views of the next two kings, greatly increased in the next century.

unique_questions.question: Whom did the serfs serve?
unique_questions.explanation: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism. The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war. Landowners had to send certain numbers of men to serve in the army. Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: The National Citizen Service programme gives 16 and 17 year olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills
unique_questions.explanation: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project

unique_questions.question: William Orange was asked by Protestants to invade England. This event was later known as what?
unique_questions.explanation: James II's elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In the UK, under the Individual Electoral Registration (IER) system, every eligible person is individually responsible for their own registration.
unique_questions.explanation: The Individual Electoral Registration system replaced the old "head of household" method where one person could register everyone in the home. Now, each eligible person is legally responsible for their own registration.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Pakistan is part of the Commonwealth
unique_questions.explanation: Pakistan is currently part of the Commonwealth

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How can you contact your MP?
unique_questions.explanation: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons

unique_questions.question: Where is Tate Britain and Tate Modern located?
unique_questions.explanation: Works by British and international artists are displayed in galleries across the UK. Some of the most well-known galleries are The National Gallery, Tate Britain and Tate Modern in London, the National Museum in Cardiff, and the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh.

unique_questions.question: What is the Grand National?
unique_questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr.

unique_questions.question: What tells us about how people lived just after the Norman Conquest?
unique_questions.explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book. It still exists today and gives a picture of society in England just after the Norman Conquest.

unique_questions.question: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland, why was this postponed?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1913, the British government promised 'Home Rule' for Ireland. It was opposed by the Protestants in the north of Ireland, who threatened to resist Home Rule by force. The outbreak of the First World War led the British government to postpone any changes in Ireland. Irish Nationalists were not willing to wait and in 1916 there was an uprising (the Easter Rising) against the British in Dublin. A guerilla war against the British army and the police in Ireland followed. In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries.

possible_answers.text: The Scottish people also wanted to self-govern
The outbreak of World War I

correct_answers: The outbreak of World War I

unique_questions.question: What is the reason for more ageing population? Choose Two Answers
unique_questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. This is due to improved living standards and better health care. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over. This has an impact on the cost of pensions and health care.

unique_questions.question: Which TWO religions celebrate Diwali?
unique_questions.explanation: Diwali normally falls in October or November and lasts for five days. It is often called the Festival of Lights. It is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge. There are different stories about how the festival came about. There is a famous celebration of Diwali in Leicester.

unique_questions.question: What is the most famous competition which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia?
unique_questions.explanation: Cricket originated in England and is now played in many countries. Games can last up to five days but still result in a draw! The idiosyncratic nature of the game and its complex laws are said to reflect the best of the British character and sense of fair play. You may come across expressions such as 'rain stopped play', 'batting on a sticky wicket', 'playing a straight bat', 'bowled a googly' or 'it's just not cricket', which have passed into everyday usage. The most famous competition is the Ashes, which is a series of Test matches played between England and Australia.

unique_questions.question: Which one of the following is the most famous play written by Shakespeare?
unique_questions.explanation: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was a playwright and actor and wrote many poems and plays. His most famous plays include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hamlet, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which two things should you do if you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law; respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions; treat others with fairness; look after yourself and your family; look after the area in which you live and the environment.

possible_answers.text: Look after the area in which you live and the environment
Look after yourself and your family

correct_answers: Look after the area in which you live and the environment
Look after yourself and your family

unique_questions.question: Who helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) in 1903?
unique_questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst was born in Manchester in 1858. She set up the Women's Franchise League in 1889, which fought to get the vote in local elections for married women. In 1903 she helped found the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU).

unique_questions.question: After Cromwell defeated Charles II at Worcester, where did Charles II hide?
unique_questions.explanation: The Scots had not agreed to the execution of Charles I and declared his son Charles II to be king. He was crowned king of Scotland and led a Scottish army into England. Cromwell defeated this army in the Battles of Dunbar and Worcester. Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Which one of these countries in the UK requires you to complete your own registration form to get entitled to vote?
unique_questions.explanation: In Northern Ireland a different system operates. This is called 'individual registration' and all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form. Once registered, people stay on the register provided their personal details do not change.

unique_questions.question: Where is the UK geographically located with respect to Europe?
unique_questions.explanation: The UK is located in the North-West of Europe.

unique_questions.question: Which of these is a Crown Dependency of the UK and not a part of it?
unique_questions.explanation: There are also several islands which are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it: the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. These have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'. There are also several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are also linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

unique_questions.question: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. Who did he become?
unique_questions.explanation: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury (see the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Church in Britain today).

unique_questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
unique_questions.explanation: The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee (1955-), is British. Information was successfully transferred via the web for the first time on 25 December 1990.

unique_questions.question: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.
unique_questions.explanation: A constitution is a set of principles by which a country is governed. It includes all of the institutions that are responsible for running the country and how their power is kept in check. The constitution also includes laws and conventions. The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following flowers represents England?
unique_questions.explanation: The national flower of England is the Rose.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by civil servants who are appointed by the Government?
unique_questions.explanation: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called 'local authorities'. Some areas have both district and county councils, which have different functions. Most large towns and cities have a single local authority.

unique_questions.question: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. What was it called?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following discoveries contributed to the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
unique_questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following traditional heavy industries were badly affected during the great depression?
unique_questions.explanation: The effects of the depression of the 1930s were felt differently in different parts of the UK. The traditional heavy industries such as shipbuilding were badly affected but new industries - including the automobile and aviation industries - developed.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: You can contact MPs only at their office in the House of Commons
unique_questions.explanation: You can contact MPs by letter or telephone at their constituency Office, or at their Office in the House of Commons.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: In England & Wales, the small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes claims of less than?
unique_questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales; £5,000 in Scotland and £5,000 in Northern Ireland (Changed from £3000).

unique_questions.question: Christmas Day, which celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, is on which day?
unique_questions.explanation: Christmas Day, 25 December, celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a public holiday. Many Christians go to church on Christmas Eve (24 December) or on Christmas Day itself.

unique_questions.question: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of what?
unique_questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral (or solo instrumental) classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been organised by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) since 1927. The Last Night of the Proms is the most well-known concert and (along with others in the series) is broadcast on television.

unique_questions.question: Which Admiral's Column is in Trafalgar Square, London?
unique_questions.explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle. Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square, London, is a monument to him. His ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.

unique_questions.question: The Union Jack is comprised of four countries' crosses. They are: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
unique_questions.explanation: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack. The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. It is still used today as the official flag of the UK.

unique_questions.question: The Victoria Cross medal was introduced during which war?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Victoria introduced the Victoria Cross medal during the Crimean war. It honours acts of valour by soldiers.

unique_questions.question: What did the Queen Elizabeth II celebrate in 2012?
unique_questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her Diamond Jubilee in 2012. The clock tower 'Big Ben' was named 'Elizabeth Tower' in honour of this event.

unique_questions.question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The United Kingdom consists of Wales,England,Scotland and Northern Ireland.

unique_questions.question: Who built the Tower of London?
unique_questions.explanation: The Tower of London was built by William the Conqueror after he became king in 1066.

unique_questions.question: Who is the head of the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of the Church of England. The spiritual leader of the Church of England is the Archbishop of Canterbury.

unique_questions.question: When is Boxing Day?
unique_questions.explanation: Boxing Day (26th of December) is the day after Christmas Day (25th of December) and is a public holiday.

unique_questions.question: What is the capital of Wales?
unique_questions.explanation: Cardiff is the capital of Wales.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
unique_questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is 'God Save the King/Queen'. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King/Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: 'God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King!'.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the official report that contains everything said in Parliament called?
unique_questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: What is the judiciary responsible for?
unique_questions.explanation: Judges, who are together called 'the judiciary', are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

possible_answers.text: Deciding whether a person is guilty

unique_questions.question: Who established the Church of England?
unique_questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: How many member states does the Commonwealth have?
unique_questions.explanation: The Monarch (King Charles III) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 (can change) member states.

unique_questions.question: Who wrote 'The Lord of the Rings'?
unique_questions.explanation: The Lord of the Rings by JRR Tolkien was voted the country's best-loved novel in 2003.

unique_questions.question: What term arose after the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
unique_questions.explanation: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase 'the Dunkirk spirit'.

unique_questions.question: What did the Chartists campaign for?
unique_questions.explanation: In the 1830s and 1840s, a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform. They wanted six changes: for every man to have the vote; elections every year; for all regions to be equal in the electoral system; secret ballots; for any man to be able to stand as an MP; for MPs to be paid.

possible_answers.text: Anyone to be able to stand as an MP
Every man to have a vote

correct_answers: Every man to have a vote

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: When did the UK join the EU?
unique_questions.explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. The UK originally decided not to join this group but it became a member in 1973. After UK's Brexit vote, there are now 27 EU member states.

unique_questions.question: Where does the Scottish Grand National take place?
unique_questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr. There is a National Horseracing Museum in Newmarket, Suffolk.

unique_questions.question: Who is known as William the Conqueror?
unique_questions.explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

unique_questions.question: What is the 'Divine Right of Kings?
unique_questions.explanation: Divine Right of Kings' is the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule. The king should be able to act without having to seek approval from Parliament.

possible_answers.text: The King was Appointed by God
Reduced the power of the nobles
Reduced the power of the King

correct_answers: The King was Appointed by God

unique_questions.question: When is St Patrick's day?
unique_questions.explanation: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have a national saint, called a patron saint. Each saint has a special day: 1 March: St David's Day, Wales;17 March: St Patrick's Day, Northern Ireland; 23 April: St George's Day, England; 30 November: St Andrew's Day, Scotland.

unique_questions.topic_name: The Values and principles of the UK
unique_questions.question: What is the responsibility that you have as a UK citizen?
unique_questions.explanation: Flowing from the fundamental principles are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK and which we expect all residents to respect. If you wish to be a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you should: respect and obey the law; respect the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions; treat others with fairness; look after yourself and your family; look after the area in which you live and the environment.

possible_answers.text: Look after yourself and your family

correct_answers: Look after yourself and your family

unique_questions.question: How old do you have to be to buy a lottery ticket or a scratch card?
unique_questions.explanation: People under 18 (Changed in 2021) are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery. This includes buying Scratch Cards.

unique_questions.question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Romans had left?
unique_questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

unique_questions.topic_name: The UK government, the law and your role
unique_questions.question: Who is the heir to the throne?
unique_questions.explanation: The King's eldest son, Prince William (the Prince of Wales), is the heir to the throne.

unique_questions.question: Why was Mary known as 'Bloody Mary'?
unique_questions.explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants.

possible_answers.text: She put her sister in prison

unique_questions.question: What did the 'Bill of Rights' confirm?
unique_questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.
